DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 November, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude my remarks in this debate on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill by reminding the House that in 1982 the Fraser Government and the Northern Territory Go-vernment reached agreement on a legislative package designed, firstly, to improve the Northern Territory Land Rights Act; secondly, to advance the cause of Northern Territory Aborigines; and thirdly, to reduce the manifest community tensions being caused by the Act. It is now three years since the Labor Government came to office. In that period the Australian Labor Party has introduced legislation which achieves much less than the package of proposals agreed to by the Commonwealth with the Northern Territory in 1982. It has taken three years to bring forward a Bill which does less for the Aboriginals than the Fraser Government's proposals. It has taken three years to start to address the pro-blems in the Act which threaten the social harmony between the various groups in Australian society. They have been three years in which the Government has done nothing but damage the cause of Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party must take much of the re-sponsibility for the divisiveness on land rights issues and the resulting attitude among many Australians that Aboriginal communities are overprivileged rather than underprivileged. What irony! In Opposition the Labor Party opposed the Fraser Government's proposals. In government it has achieved less for the Aboriginal people, and in the process it has managed to damage badly the goodwill towards the Aboriginal community in Australian society. For anyone concerned--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are dealing with the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill. It proposes amendments to Aboriginal land rights legislation, particularly as it relates to the Northern Territory. This legislation was introduced, as honourable members know, by the Fraser Government. It was extremely far sighted legislation and gave a veto to the Aboriginal people over their land-the land that they were given-and this is a similar veto to that which exists in North America amongst Indians, Eskimos and such people.

SPEECH.PARA: The purport of the legislation that is before the House is to try to give the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory a place where they can live, where they can have their own self-esteem and their own dignity. It will apply particularly to about 4,000 Aboriginals in the Territory who are living literally in Third World conditions. In Australia, all up, according to the 1981 census, there are some 159,000 Aborigines. They are mostly in northern Australia, although there are 36,000 in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. In Western Australia there are 31,000 people who call themselves Aborigines; in the Northern Territory 29,000; and, in Queensland, 44,000. Through the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), the Government has been successful in inducing the States to grant land rights-to transfer the Aboriginal reserves and traditional Aboriginal lands to Aboriginal people. I note that in Queensland the titles to an enormous number of reserves and former Aboriginal lands have been transferred in perpetuity to Aboriginal people. This has happened also in New South Wales, and in Western Australia it is starting to happen. I praise the Minister for what he has achieved without cost to the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth is committed to assisting Aborigines who, as Mr Justice Woodward said, were deprived of their land without their consent and without compensation.

The Federal Budget this year contains approximately half a billion dollars which will go directly or indirectly to Aborigines. This is meant not only to assist them in improving their housing, water supplies, communications in remote areas and their health but also to be some sort of compensation for what has been taken from them in the past without their consent. In the Northern Territory there is a very big problem finding somewhere for people to live and somewhere that they can call their own land. I have been to the Territory on a number of occasions, but I have not seen groups of Aboriginal Australians who have been dispossessed and who have been wandering around with no place to call their own. I did see such a situation in Western Australia in 1982 when I visited the Kimberleys with the Labor Party Caucus committee on Aborigines. We came upon a community of Aborigines, say 50 people who were wandering around an enormous pastoral property of hundreds of thousands of acres. These people were there by the grace and favour of the manager, because a pastoral company owned by some overseas interests owned the land. The manager let them live on the property and wander around. We visited a school there that was nothing more than a lean-to with some sort of a roof that was made out of wire netting and branches, in which a young teacher from Melbourne was trying to teach the children how to read and write in English, because they did not speak in English; of course, their first language was one of the Aboriginal languages. It distressed me greatly to see Australians who have lived on this site probably for thousands upon thousands of years without any title to it and relying entirely on the good will of the manager of the property, who was a very fair man.

But not all pastoralists have such arrangements and such understanding for Aboriginal people. There are stories of black Australians being driven off the enormous grazing properties in the Territory and in Northern Australia where they have lived for perhaps hundreds of thousands of years. It is a very sad indictment of our society to have done so much which has hurt the Aborigines. With the intention of helping them we have brought them together-perhaps missions or governments-for education, for health purposes, and it was possibly the worst thing we could do, because we brought together into settlements groups that were antagonistic to each other, tribes that were natural enemies. As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, I found at Aurukun recently that in the school all of these tribal differences and antagonisms come out. The children fight, not because they do not like each other but because their tribes clash and resent each other. The kiddies will not go to school, and the attendance at the Aurukun State School in Queensland on the Gulf of Carpentaria was barely 15 per cent.

What hope do children have if they are brought into these settlements and the European way of living if they do not receive any education? They can never take over the jobs of the white advisers; they can never become the doctors, lawyers, surveyors or engineers to do the jobs of and replace the European people who are helping them. I have been encouraged when moving around with the Committee, to see the outstation movement. This is the movement, literally, of the people back to their traditional lands. It is a most encouraging situation because they get away from petrol sniffing amongst young people. They get away from alcohol dependence. They go back to their traditional areas. Even their health is better because there is bush tucker in the country. They can live off the land and do not have to rely on take-away items that they buy in local stores, fast food chain stores and such places in the European settlements. I think there is great hope for our Aboriginal Australians if they get their own communities.

Part of this idea of getting land of their own, a place of their own, is dealt with in this legislation before the House today. In the Northern Territory there is a great move to have excisions from pastoral leases. There is a movement to give the Aborigines a small area where they can live on the enormous pastoral leases that exist in the Northern Territory. But this has not moved very quickly and in the legislation before us today there is a measure to have the excisions move quickly. There are under 100 claims outstanding for the 3,000 or 4,000 people in the Territory who have nowhere to call their own. These are largely tribalised Aboriginals who just want somewhere about which they can say: `Well, that is our land and we control it'. We are talking about part of the land where they have lived since time immemorial but to which they have no claim. Should some antagonistic pastoralist take over the lease, they could be evicted tomorrow without any rights or redress.

The overriding problem in the Territory is to achieve a fair system of land rights peacefully and by agreement, because the pastoralists and the Aborigines have to live together. For many, many years the pastoralist received the labours of the Aborigines-the Aboriginal stockmen-for virtually nothing. They gave them sugar, tea and flour and the Aborigines worked hard for those provisions. Now they feel that it is their turn and they want title to some place that they can call their own. I do not think that that is an unfair demand. I think that is the least possible thing that the Aboriginal people in our nation can ask.

The Aborigines have been looking at making land claims through their three land councils in the Northern Territory on the stock routes which go right through the Territory. These routes are literally vacant land-or everyone thought that they were until a land commissioner in the Territory held otherwise. That has complicated the issue. The Government will clarify the situation over the stock routes because, although they are only a mile wide, they may go for hundreds of miles-or should I say kilometres-through the Territory. If the Government can obtain agreement with the pastoralists and the Northern Territory Government to push ahead with excisions to give black Australians a site of their own where they can live in peace and harmony with their families, the Government will co-operate with the pastoralists, and clarify the law which is in this Bill, to exclude claims from stock routes. The situation is worrying the pastoralists. It appears to me from the evidence that we have received in committee hearings that the pastoralists are holding back. Many of these people are great people, good Australians just like the Aborigines in the area. They are fair, honest business people who are trying to run their pastoral property with integrity and make enough profit to make a living to feed themselves. They do not want to fight with their Aboriginal neighbours, who are, perhaps, living on their property on a grace and favour basis with no rights. The pastoralists want to make excisions but they are being held back. A cooling of passions and calm negotiations are needed in the Territory. I am afraid, judging by some of the speeches in the House last night, there is not much evidence that Opposition members are encouraging this process.

Unless we have a peaceful settlement of the issue of Aboriginal land rights in the Territory, Australia will have to hang its head in shame. I believe very strongly in this matter. I was never prepared to vote in favour of watering down the existing legislation which gives the veto to Aborigines in the Northern Territory. I was not prepared to do that and I am delighted that the Government has not gone along that track. It has honoured the existing legislation and ALP policy and allowed the Aborigines to have the veto over their own land. I do not wish to delay the House any longer. I commend this legislation and I praise the Minister and the Labor Caucus committee, which have both worked very hard in conducting consultations with the Aboriginal land councils on this Bill. I also commend the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, which also works efficiently in educating members on both sides of the House about the problems of Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986, the purpose of which is to make a number of administrative changes to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. Unfortunately, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has ignored many of the areas in which change is needed most and in which decisions need to be made with some urgency-for example, exploration and mining on Aboriginal land, including calculating royalty payments and the removal of certain land from claim under the Act, such as public purpose land and pastoral property land owned by the Aborigines themselves. The Bill also ignores a number of reforms not only promised by the Minister but actually demanded by him when he was in opposition. It appears that the left wing of the Australian Labor Party has rolled the Minister yet again despite three years of negotiations and assurances between the Minister and interested parties in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act was legislated in 1976 following the investigations and reports of Mr Justice Woodward in 1973 and 1974. The present Act provides for grants of Aboriginal reserve land to Aboriginal land trusts and, as well, Aboriginal groups who have a traditional affiliation with crown land and can claim this land and have the titles to this land vested with Aboriginal land trusts. The 1976 Act also established land councils to manage Aboriginal land and protect the interests of the traditional owners. Where claims existed a special land commissioner was appointed to hear them, and such claims have been proceeding apace. Already 33 per cent of the total Northern Territory land area has been granted to Aborigines in the form of inalienable freehold title. A further 18 per cent is under claim. If all this is granted it will add up to over half the land mass of the Northern Territory and an area in the Northern Territory alone which is some hundreds of per cent greater than the land granted to Indians in Canada or the United States.

There is now virtually no vacant Crown land left in the Northern Territory that has not been claimed by Aborigines. The Northern Territory is 1,346,200 square kilometres in size. An area close to 686,000 square kilometres will be Aboriginal land to be shared amongst some of the 29,000 Aborigines who live in the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory also has several thousand kilometres of coastline, about two-thirds of which is under the control of the Aboriginal people.

I mention these figures so that we can compare them, for example, with Canadian native Indians, who number 491,460, and the Eskimos, who number 25,390. Those people live on 2,251 reserves which take up an area of 260,000 square kilometres. So the Northern Territory alone have three times the land mass of that group. American native Indians, who I am told number 1.4 million, live on an area of 172,528 square kilometres. So the Northern Territory is four times larger than that. What is happening in the Northern Territory now is that other land is being claimed, land that was not envisaged could or would be claimed under the original 1976 Act. I am referring to public purpose land and pastoral lease land.

In theory all pastoral land is claimable now. There are something like 235 pastoral leases in the Northern Territory ranging from about 3,000 square kilometres up to 12,000 square kilometres. The coalition has no objection whatsoever to individual Aborigines or Aboriginal groups purchasing these properties on the open market like anyone else. What we do object to is what happens to these properties afterwards. The pastoral leases are converted into inalienable freehold title. Put simply, this means that the land is locked up forever. It can never, for example, be sold. In practice that means that the Aborigines who own the land cannot borrow money against it for development because if the loan goes bad the banks cannot foreclose to recover their money. So no one will lend the Aborigines money and that obviously disadvantages the Aborigines themselves.

It also means that what is done or is not done to the land is not subject to the same rules that apply to the white neighbouring properties. The resources of this country that we have been blessed with should have responsibilities equally applicable to all citizens of Australia regardless of creed or colour. To exempt certain people from full responsibilities has only led to their long term detriment and the country's detriment in the past. The jurisdiction over these pastoral areas when the claims are successful also passes from the Northern Territory Government to the Commonwealth Government. Surely that is wrong, and is a further example of the undesirable centralisation of power in Canberra.

In recent years Aborigines have also been claiming stock routes and stock reserves, which come under the broader title of public purpose land. Most stock routes in the Northern Territory are a mile wide and cover the Territory in spider web fashion. The reserves vary in size from something like 10 to 500 square kilometres in area. To have the threat of these areas being claimed hanging over the pastoral people of the Northern Territory has been intolerable and I believe that the Federal Minister to some extent has appreciated this point. These areas should not be eligible for claim at all and the Minister should have no overriding say to grant exemptions. Repeat claims on land that has already been subject to unsuccessful claim should also not be allowed. To permit land to be claimed over and over again is quite ridiculous. We have been having Aboriginal land claims in the Northern Territory for some 10 years now and I believe that the time has come for a cut-off point. I see that the Minister has recommended 10 years. The coalition believes that 12 months is ample time and the cut-off for future claims should be applied then. Let us remember that many of the current land claims will not be finalised for three or four years, so to have the present position drag on past that for 10 more years would be very destabilising for the Northern Territory.

I note that the Minister wants the Land Commissioners who hear those claims to be selected not just from the Northern Territory Supreme Court but also from the bench of the Federal Court of Australia. Why does the Minister propose this? Does he not trust the Northern Territory judges? They have certainly been sympathetic to the Aboriginal land claims so far. Does the Minister intend to stack the Commission with a bunch of trendy judges from the south who might be on side with the Minister but know nothing of the Northern Territory situation? I would oppose this proposal. At the very least, the Northern Territory Government should have veto powers over judges appointed from outside the Northern Territory.

The Minister proposes also to extend the powers of the land councils to control land in the Northern Territory. There are three land councils in the Northern Territory; the small Tiwi Land Council with jurisdiction over Bathurst Island and Melville Island and the two main councils, the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council. There is considerable concern as to whether they have adequately represented the traditional Aboriginal owners of the land in all cases. In many cases they have become obstructive bureaucracies stacked with solicitors, a whole range of technical and legal people and white advisers. I believe that in many instances they have lost sight of the original goals for which they were appointed.

The legislation will remove the obligation to compile a register of the traditional owners of an area. This appears to be a move to remove control from the traditional owners to a more centralised control by the land councils. This move should be opposed. How can the interests of the traditional owners be met, or claims properly judged, if we do not know who the traditional owners are? Perhaps this provision has been included because so-called traditional owners are sometimes recent arrivals. That certainly seemed to be the case when control of the Uluru National Park was handed to the Aboriginal people.

If any land is handed over, the responsibility to look after it should go with it, and that is best supervised from Darwin, not Canberra. I take just one example of the maintenance, or rather non-maintenance, of the road at Uluru from Ayers Rock to the Olgas. Since the park was handed over there has been almost zero maintenance on that road and it has now become almost impassable. I believe that the bus and hire companies have banned travel of their vehicles there because of the damage done to those vehicles. The Government has announced that a grader is on the way to do some maintenance on that road, but I do not think that is good enough. It will probably only deepen the road by another six inches which will make the problem worse in the long run. The Northern Territory Government was planning to seal that road just before the park was handed over, but control was taken away from that Government. We have had an increase in the number of tourists arriving at the park by air. In the past 12 months there has been an increase of approximately 60 per cent, which would contain a high proportion of overseas tourists whom we have been trying to get into this country. If these people cannot go out to see one of the great attractions of Australia, the Olgas, they will not be very pleased and will be less inclined to come back here.

The coalition also opposes the Aboriginal land councils being given control over sacred sites on non-Aboriginal land. This proposal is crazy. The Northern Territory Government already has jurisdiction over these sacred sites and has managed this area well. To now also give control to the land councils under Commonwealth law is unnecessary duplication of the worst kind and is a further example of shifting more power to Canberra. The land councils will only frustrate the Northern Territory Government in its satisfactory management of this area. The Minister has also not properly considered the issue of excisions in the Bill. Excisions, for those who do not know, are living areas on pastoral leases that are set aside for resident Aboriginal communities. The Northern Territory has had 134 applications for excisions on its books, of which 124 have some merit. However, when the proposals were put up no substantial detail was submitted with 59 cases which, of course, leaves 65. Of the 65, 14 have had their titles registered, 27 are in various stages of conveyancing, et cetera, and others are under serious negotiation. I mention these figures to demonstrate that the Northern Territory is getting on with the job in this area.

The question of excision is a very difficult area because most Aborigines, not just in the Northern Territory but across Australia, live in towns. I guess the long term future for most Aborigines, as it is for most white people in Australia, is in the towns. To put people permanently on those areas and grant permanent title to these areas I do not think is a long term solution for the Aboriginal people because employment opportunities do not exist in these remote areas, certainly for large numbers of people. Once the excisions are made, the Northern Territory Government is obliged to provide the infrastructure for these areas, which includes access to the areas; fencing in some cases; water, which is very costly and very difficult to provide; and also standard housing. I do think that the Commonwealth should take into account the substantial cost to the Northern Territory Government.

The Minister also wishes to incorporate Aboriginal organisations which receive moneys through royalties under the Commonwealth's Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act. However, the organisations which are presently receiving the greatest proportion of royalty equivalent which are under Northern Territory law are to be excluded. This includes the Gagudju Association, which receives its royalty from the Ranger mine; the Kunwinjku Association from Nabarlek; and the Djabilukju Association from Pancontinental Mining Ltd. I believe all these organisations should be treated equally and should not be split between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory. I believe the jurisdiction of all these organisations should be left under the Northern Territory Government and we should have no further centralisation of power in this area moved to Canberra.

The Aboriginals Benefit Trust Fund-the ABTA-has been paid over $20m a year in recent times in royalties. Since it was instituted in 1978 it has received $95,325,814. I seek leave to incorporate a table in Hansard showing the royalties that have been paid since 1978 until 1985-86. I showed the table to the Minister last night and he has approved it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. As well as these royalties, there are other negotiable royalties too which, because of time pressures, I will not discuss on this occasion. In summary, I believe the Bill is a great disappointment to all Territorians and, in particular, the Aboriginal people in many aspects. It does not deal with many of the main causes for concern. What it does deal with it does so improperly and inadequately. The Government should be condemned for that and honourable members should vote to amend or reject the clauses in the Bill which are unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on this issue has been a very uneven debate because it is quite clear that on the political aspects of the matter the Government speakers have totally annihilated members of the Opposition and their comments. In fact, there is no question about it that what we have seen from the Opposition is a combination of two things. Some speakers who present a front of respectability in relation to this issue, such as the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), are really being manipulated by people such as the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Dr Everingham) and the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) whose speeches yesterday were not broadcast. They should have been broadcast because anyone of Aboriginal descent or Aboriginal background hearing those speeches would have seen what a contemptuous contribution they were. They could be described in a number of ways but, in order that I do not have to withdraw certain terms, I will not go into those descriptions. However, let me say that speakers on my side of the House, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard), the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) and the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), have all taken up the major points in relation to land rights and have debated all the political aspects in a way which I think has presented an overwhelming case in favour of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: For the edification of some honourable members opposite who still do not understand the fundamental reasons why we speak of Aboriginal land rights, Aboriginal self-determination and the importance for services to be provided to the Aboriginal people, let me say something about the history of this situation and the reasons why all Australians, even those recently arrived to this country, have a moral responsibility of the utmost order to the Aboriginal people. Soon we will be celebrating the 200th anniversary of European colonisation of this country. This was the beginning of the destruction of Aboriginal culture which I will demonstrate indisputably here today was one of the great cultures of the world. It was destroyed through the totally insensitive approach taken by the people who first came to this country. People who come to this country look at Aboriginals now and say: `Look at them, they are just drunks, they are just people on drugs, they are just a lost people'. They fail to recognise and accept the responsibility that the people who came to this country have for what happened to the Aboriginal people and for the destruction of their culture. As I have mentioned, they lose sight of the fact that Aboriginal culture was one of the richest of the world.

There is no doubt that, when we get beyond the superficialities of technology-the Aboriginal people did have technology although it was nothing like our modern technology-and we look at the world view, the philosophy and the vision of Aboriginal culture, we see a richness and a wealth which very few cultures have been able to match. It is not insignificant that so many anthropologists around the world still find fascination in the study of Aboriginal culture because of this richness and because of the way in which it represents a complex understanding of the universe and a complex philosophy which we and the average Australian have hardly a clue about. Therefore, we need to ask ourselves: What are the dimensions of the tragedy? What has happened to the Aboriginal people is one of the world tragedies-let us not mince words. Therefore, for us to be insensitive to their need and to their desire to restore some of the culture that has been lost, it is an outrage that we, in this Parliament, should not all be united and immediately push through all forms of legislation which can help and assist those people to restore something of their culture which we have taken away.

As I have mentioned, the Aboriginal culture is not merely a culture based on a materialist's view of the world. It is not a culture that looks merely at material things. It is a culture based essentially on a metaphysical approach which is different from the approach of Western man.

TALK.START.PARA: —Something from which we can learn.

—It is something from which we can learn, as the honourable member for Moore says. We can learn something from the whole Aboriginal concept of spirituality and of the nature of the universe because we have become very narrow in our conceptions of these philosophical issues in the twentieth century. But, instead of that, what do we find? We find that we take a kind of cultural chauvinistic approach, a pretension that we know everything, that our culture is the dominant one, the supreme one, and that the Aborigines have nothing to contribute; that their approach to the mysteries of the universe must be mistaken as our approach is the one which is sound and concrete.

SPEECH.PARA: What sort of approach has been taken by Western man to the fundamental concept in Aboriginal culture of the dreamtime? Our approach has been: `Isn't it quaint? Isn't it cute? These Aborigines believe in this dreamtime-a quaint, cute sort of approach'. That is a totally patronising approach to the fundamentals of their culture. The fact is that the approach of the Aborigines has a lot to commend it because it is an approach that looks at man as a totality, not merely as a material being with selfish desires and nothing more. It is time we recognised that we ought to be doing a great deal to restore Aboriginal culture and the wealth of that culture, and in a multicultural society perhaps even to learn something from it-perhaps even to learn something of the Aboriginal approach to the world and to the universe.

But all of that is a very difficult task because of the great tragedy that has occurred. If honourable members want to know about that great tragedy and about the dimensions of it, I recommend that they read a book entitled The Other Side of the Frontier by Dr Henry Reynolds, which looks at the colonisation of Australia from the Aboriginal point of view and at what really happened. When most of us went to school we heard about the Aboriginal people and about the colonisation of Australia. But what did we hear? We heard the white man's view. We heard a view that was presented entirely from the European perspective. We did not hear about what really happened.

For example, we did not hear about the brave battles fought by the Aborigines in defence of their culture. From some reviews of history, one gets the impression that the Aborigines sold out all of their land immediately. We did not hear about the wars and the battles that they fought, and fought very hard, to defend their land and their culture. It is a disgrace to the academic traditions of this country that only very recently has that side of the story begun to be told. It was a slaughter. Aboriginal people were killed; thousands and thousands of them were killed. Those who were not killed died of diseases brought here by European man. They were virtually wiped out.

Of course, they had no rights. For most of the two centuries they have had no rights of citizenship and no rights as people. Honourable members may be surprised to realise how recent a phenomenon is the Aborigines' gain of citizenship in their own land and their own country. We forget all these things.

The honourable member for the Northern Territory made a contemptuous and disgraceful speech yesterday. He forgets these moral issues. He forgets the fundamental issues that I have addressed today. European man did not merely come in, kill a lot of Aboriginals, take control of the land and say, `Let bygones be bygones, we will now live together'; the Aboriginals were suppressed and their rights were taken away for most of the 200 years. As I mentioned, only as a recent development were they given some rights.

Honourable members may recall the famous Albert Namatjira who, because he became a distinguished artist and person within the context of Western society, was granted honorary citizenship. All Aboriginals could not be given citizenship but one or two, like Albert Namatjira, were given citizenship in the 1950s. That situation was a most extreme form of oppression and paternalism. Albert Namatjira was arrested because he gave some of his relatives liquor to drink. This was against the law because his relatives were not recognised as citizens-they were natives. Namatjira was charged and threatened with imprisonment. Honourable members will be interested to hear the views of the great progressive newspaper, the Northern Territory News, which tries to this day to deny rights to the Aboriginal people. In relation to the Albert Namatjira case in 1958 the Northern Territory News reported:

It is important now not only for Namatjira that there be some acceptance of the lessons glaring from the shamble of the artist's rise and fall and that there be a little public understanding of the massive problem besetting the authorities in the full rights program.

It must be clear that it was a mistake to give Namatjira his citizenship passport despite the fact that he proved he could walk with kings, earn more than most white people and had dignity and ability.
This is what the Northern Territory News said in 1958:

Surely an essential measure of whether a native should get full rights must be his proven ability to bring up his family to the acceptable white standards. This was not the case with Namatjira and this very fact probably contributed more to his downfall than anything else.

That was in 1958. It was only in 1962 that the Northern Territory granted some voting rights to the black people, and it was not until the referendum of 1966 that we finally got recognition by the Australian people that Aboriginals, at least in principle, ought to be given full rights-in principle, I say, because that principle was not implemented until the Whitlam Government came into power and started, with its inquiries, the movement for the granting of land rights. That movement has gained momentum. One of the reasons why it has gained momentum is that the Aboriginal people have increasingly expressed their rights themselves. They have demanded self-determination as a right-not just in some paternalistic way, but as a right. Since that movement began we have started finally to recognise the rights of Aboriginal people, but there is still a long way to go. As I said at the beginning of my speech, the destruction of 200 years is not easy to restore. We cannot immediately and easily restore the Aboriginal cultures which we have annihilated. We must do everything in our power, firstly, to give the Aboriginal people full land rights wherever possible. We should be not merely generous but, if necessary, overgenerous if we are to make up for our historical sins. Secondly, we must consider making self-determination a real principle, a principle that has meaning, so that the Aboriginal people, with dignity, can come together and can determine the courses of action which they should take. Thirdly, we need to provide them with services in a number of fields-in the field of education and in the field of cultural development to help them come back to their cultural roots and to help them restore those cultures which have been destroyed. Finally, we must all recognise that, unless we are prepared to use the resources of the Commonwealth and the State Governments to help the Aboriginal people in this way, we will never be able to get rid of the guilt which we rightfully should feel in relation to the Aboriginal people.

I conclude by saying that we have very little understanding of the richness and the wealth of Aboriginal cultures. Those cultures need to be restored into the whole context of our society, especially if we really mean what we say in relation to being a multicultural nation. As I said at the beginning of my speech, we can learn from those cultures. We can all look forward to a future, provided that we do something to restore those rights for those people. This legislation is a further step in that direction. Not only should it not be opposed but also it should be enthusiastically supported by this Parliament. I conclude by thanking the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), the chairman of the committee and all those involved in doing the hard work, especially the consultations with the Aboriginal communities, in bringing forward this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who was the previous speaker in this debate on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill, had so many finales or conclusions that I suspected for a moment he was trying to outdo Dame Nellie Melba. It is a pity that his performance was nowhere near as good as that of Dame Nellie Melba on the stage. The National Party of Australia believes in equality for all Australians, whether they happen to be Aboriginal or otherwise. One of the most significant aspects of the Federal Aboriginal policy in the last 15 years has been its complete and utter failure. We have seen a handout mentality and attempts by various governments to salve the Australian community's collective conscience with an open cheque-book policy. This is sad. It does not meet the needs of Aboriginal people or, indeed, the wider community.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some examples of this open cheque-book policy. All Aboriginals have access to general health, education and welfare services that are available to all Australians. Nobody would deny that this is proper. Aboriginals are also eligible, subject to normal conditions, to receive social security benefits and are entitled to the same employment conditions and industrial protection which are afforded to the rest of the country. Again, no one would object to this. Aboriginals can claim assistance under government programs to eliminate the disadvantages which they have in common from time to time with other members of the general community. Again, we would have no objection whatsoever to this. That is fair and reasonable. Many Australians are however, concerned about the Government benefits which are earmarked for Aboriginals because they are Aboriginals. A number of benefits, schemes and services are available specifically for Aboriginal people. These should be taken into account, with the current land rights policy, to ascertain whether Labor's handout mentality is a disaster.

In education we have the Aboriginal secondary grants scheme. It assists parents of students of Aboriginal descent who are undertaking secondary schooling. The allowances are not income tested. I seek the leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard a table that sets out benefits under ABSEG.

TALK.START.PARA: -Is leave granted? The honourable member for Fisher might provide the document to the Leader of the House (Mr Young) and, if it meets the Speaker's guidelines for the incorporation of tables, it may be incorporated.
—There is also the Aboriginal study grants scheme which assists people of Aboriginal descent to undertake further study after leaving school. Allowances are not income tested.

—I raise a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, a lot of licence has been given in this debate, but I think education is a bit further away from the Bill than those areas about which most other speakers have spoken. I would suggest that we stick with the legislation. We have all had to do it, and I guess this speaker should do the same.
—The honourable member for Fisher is illustrating his point. I call the honourable member for Fisher.

—Benefits payable or given to Aboriginals are relevant when considering the level of land rights, if any, which are appropriate for Aborigines in the Northern Territory. A higher level of financial assistance, whether through educational help or not, could seriously impact on what land rights should be given. A substantial pecuniary benefit might mean that many people would consider that the level of land rights is outrageous. I was referring to the Aboriginal study grants scheme. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out benefits given under that scheme.
—Is leave granted?
—Leave is not granted.
—I will leave the people of Australia to judge the pathetic effort of the honourable member for Melbourne in obstructing information being given in relation to this scheme in this debate.

—As a point of order, I ask that that be withdrawn. Under the Standing Orders I have the right to object. My point is that education is not relevant to this legislation. If I have to abide by the rules of the Parliament, the honourable member who is speaking also ought to do so. I know that the National Party is separate from everybody else in our society, but at least it ought to follow the rules of the Parliament.

—Order! There is no point of order. What the honourable member for Fisher said was not disorderly or unparliamentary, but the Chair has drawn the honourable member's attention to the fact that the Bill is about Aboriginal land rights. The Chair indicated that he thought the honourable member was illustrating at the beginning of his speech and that he was getting to the subject of Aboriginal land rights. The honourable member had better hurry up and get there.

—That is perfectly correct, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am just outlining some preliminary matters. It has been a wide ranging debate. Extreme latitude had been given to honourable members on the other side of the House, particularly the previous speaker. It is interesting to see the way in which a member of the Government wishes to muzzle a member of the Opposition in trying to bring forward in this House facts that are relevant to this debate.
—Order! Leave has been granted for the incorporation of table 1, and it meets Madam Speaker's guidelines.

—I thank the House. Needless to say, table 2 which the honourable member for Melbourne does not want incorporated in Hansard sets out very substantial payments that are made under the Abstudy scheme. Also under the Abstudy scheme is a special category of 100 awards which are available for Aboriginal mature age students-that is, students aged 25 and over-who wish to take up full time study leading to a formal teaching qualification.

—Order! The honourable member for Fisher shall come to the discussion on the Bill before the House, which is the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill. The Aboriginal study grants scheme is not mentioned in this legislation.

—I mentioned before that the levels of payments in various areas which are made to Aboriginals are relevant when considering the level of land rights which should be given. Many people perceive that land rights are a form of compensation to Aboriginal people. The other benefits, pecuniary or otherwise, which are paid by the Government, and therefore by the taxpayers of Australia, to the Aborigines are relevant when ascertaining the appropriate level of land rights, whether in the Northern Territory or otherwise. I will, however, defer to your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker, by saying briefly that a number of other payments are made specifically to Aboriginal people, and the average Australian does not have access to them. We in the Opposition have no objection to assistance being given to those who are underprivileged--

—Order! The honourable member is standing to debate the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill. He has not touched on it yet and he has been speaking for seven minutes. I ask the honourable member to come to the discussion on the legislation before the House.

—I raise a point of order. I seek your guidance in this matter. It seems to me that the honourable member for Fisher, in discussing this Bill, is indicating that Aboriginal land rights are one way in which to assist the Aboriginal people, and at the same time--
—What is your point of order?
—My point of order is that I ask that latitude be given to the honourable member for Fisher--

—That is not a point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat. The Chair has been providing a fair amount of latitude to the honourable member for Fisher, but it would just help the discussion if he touched on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, in the debate which, as you know, commenced last night, there has been a very--
—Does the honourable member have a point of order?

—Yes. I wish to make an observation, as the Opposition spokesman responsible for this legislation. I just point out to the House that we have had a wide-ranging debate on all sides from all speakers up to now, and I do not think it is reasonable at this stage in the piece, in the last moments of the debate, to determine that one member of the Opposition somehow or other has to limit his response and his comments to the context imposed by others.
—If the honourable member for Fisher would somehow or other get to touch upon the legislation it might be satisfactory.

—In respect of the point of order taken by the shadow Minister, I just make the observation that, going through all of the other speakers, from the shadow Minister himself and the honourable member for the Northern Territory to the speakers on this side, it can be seen that they in fact dealt with the legislation in some detail. The honourable member currently speaking is talking either about another Bill or about some other piece of legislation that he has been researching, because he has not, as yet, touched on the Bill before the House. In trying to help him get to that point, I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to rule that he should talk about the legislation that we are all debating and leave the education section, which he has been researching, to another day, when we will be happy to debate it with him.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for Fisher.
—Unfortunately, I suppose with the previous occupants of the chair there appears to be one rule for the Government and another rule for the Opposition.
—Order! The honourable member for Fisher will withdraw that remark.

—I will withdraw it, Mr Deputy Speaker, but there has been a wide-ranging debate, as was pointed out by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). I am the only person who has been directed not to deal with various other matters.
—Order! The honourable member for Fisher will withdraw the reflection on the Chair unreservedly.
—I withdrew before, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—The honourable member may continue.

—As I mentioned, there are a number of areas where benefits are given to Aboriginals but not to other people. Those benefits include benefits relating to land rights. Many respectable arguments have been brought forward against land rights. I would like to mention some of these. Some people have said that the original Aboriginal inhabitants of this country are dead and that land rights cannot compensate the deceased. The comment has also been made that land rights vest disproportionate power in one section of the community with respect to royalties and the development of mineral resources. Furthermore, it has been said that the principle of Crown title to minerals should apply uniformly throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point which has been made is that land rights legislation discriminates against the majority of Australians. It has been said land rights institutionalise racial and cultural differences that Aborigines may not want institutionalised forever and that land rights cannot be ascertained according to individual title. Also, it has been said that Australia's mineral resources will not be properly developed with the current level of land rights and that Aboriginal lands would not be farmed or used productively. Most important is the allegation that land rights, especially the land rights which the Australian Labor Party is bringing into this Parliament, ensure that we have in Australia an apartheid system-a system which makes South Africa appear very benign by comparison.

We should look at what has happened in the Northern Territory and compare that situation with that of Queensland. Honourable members who have been in this place for some time will recall how the Queensland Parliament and the Queensland Minister were criticised when legislation relating to the deeds of grant in trust was brought in in that State. I might add that some years down the track it is obvious-even those people who have criticised the Queensland Government in the past have admitted this-that the deeds of grant in trust legislation has been an outstanding success in improving the lot of Aborigines in a positive manner. It is a pity that the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill which we are now discussing does not seek to go down the road of the Queensland legislation. The ALP is a party which postures and masquerades as a party of support for the Aboriginal people. Yet in the past, under Queensland Labor Party legislation, we had a situation whereby removal orders could be made to have prominent people taken from their homes at the arbitrary discretion of the local officer in charge. A permit system existed whereby permission had to be obtained before one could enter or leave a reserve area. This permit system presently exists in the Northern Territory. The Government stands condemned because it has not done away with that permit system.

In the bad old days of Labor the reserve manager had the power to gaol any person at his arbitrary discretion. Many people were gaoled without charges having been laid for up to ten days on a regimen of bread and water. The reserve manager could administer corporal punishment, once more at his arbitrary discretion. He could issue work orders as he pleased, directing whoever he liked to perform any task and work any hours, and, shockingly, no person of Aboriginal descent was allowed to receive payment for work performed. His wages were always paid directly to the Director of the Department. It was illegal to sell alcohol to people of Aboriginal descent; only Europeans were allowed to consume alcohol. I wonder what honourable members opposite-there are very few of them in the chamber now-would say at Labor's shocking record for the period that it administered Aboriginal affairs in Queensland. Every one of those laws was swept away when the National Party of Australia came into government.

The most interesting thing about the current situation in Queensland, unlike that in the Northern Territory, is that the people of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander descent have been introduced to free enterprise society. Far from being oppressive and destructive, as the critics of our legislation have suggested, it has improved the lot of the people to the extent that it is now being presented to other States as a preferred alternative-not by the Queensland Government, but by the former critics of that Government. The commune approach of the other States is destructive of the culture of the people whereas individualism, not centralism, was always the rule. The Northern Territory would benefit from similar legislation. But have we seen such legislation brought into the House? We certainly have not. We have a Bill before the House which does not meet the aspirations of those who wanted the previous Act changed. It does not meet the need for alterations to the present situation.

The initial proposals of the Government were infinitely better than those which are before the House today. The Government has ignored the most contentious issues associated with the land rights Act by deferring for discussion and analysis in 1987 such issues as: Exploration and mining on Aboriginal land; the granting of an estate or interest in Aboriginal land to the Northern Territory Government for essential services; the protection of sacred sites; methods for calculating payments of royalty equivalents to the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account; and the removal from claim of pastoral properties owned by Aboriginals, and of public purpose land. The amendments constitute little more than administrative changes-tokenism again. The Bill does not represent the comprehensive package of reforms promised by the Government and demanded by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) when he was the spokesman in opposition. I think the Government should stand condemned for failing to bring to fruition the promise of proper changes which was made. Referring back to the Queensland situation, as opposed to that of the Northern Territory, it is also interesting that Queensland is the only place where the Government can be said to have delivered unfettered ownership in perpetuity. An area of 7.5 million acres of Queensland which has lain dormant and useless for so long has now seen the doors of opportunity thrown open under the Queensland legislation. I would like to quote the words of the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Community Services, who, of course, is the son of the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), an excellent member. The Queensland Minister has said:

For those who claim that the Queensland Government had given a massive handout, I would stress again that these areas have traditionally belonged to people of Aboriginal descent. They are areas that have always been reserved for the use of the local residents who are of Aboriginal descent.

To have remained in a `reserve area' situation would have meant that people of Aboriginal descent would not have been able to use this land effectively because of the lack of ownership. To own a title deed over an area enables the owner to borrow money, which is after all how the growth of every economy commences.

We in the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia support the principle of free enterprise, and the Queensland Government, with its legislation, has brought free enterprise into those areas which were previously reserves. We have found that operations which previously made losses are now making profits. We are finding that Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders are now taking the initiative and reaping the rewards of initiative and hard work. The Queensland Minister, summing up the results of his legislation, said:

This encompasses one of the greatest economic success stories in Australia in recent years, and clearly demonstrates what private ownership and private enterprise can achieve when the fetters of government controls are removed.
It also clearly delivers to the dungeons forever, the prejudices that people of Aboriginal descent don't work hard and cannot achieve when given the same rights and privileges as other people.

We on this side of the House support the principle of the Queensland legislation. The previous critics of the Queensland Government have been saying what a tremendous success this is and, by comparison, the Northern Territory's position is an unmitigated disaster.

In that Territory successful or pending land claims have meant that the ordinary citizens-the ordinary man and woman in the street-will or could lose normal access to at least 51 per cent of the land area of the Northern Territory. The area of land under Aboriginal title in the Northern Territory represents 200 per cent more than the total area given to Canadian Indians. The Northern Territory Government is not happy with this legislation. It has made that unhappiness clear to the Government but unfortunately the Government has not been interested. The attitude of the Minister and the Government is typical of the treatment meted out by the Australian Labor Party to the Territory. On the one hand there is a continual demand for increased financial independence, yet on the other legislative schemes are imposed which hamper the development of major resources and prevent such financial independence. As the Northern Territory Chief Minister has said, it is a situation that no State would tolerate. If it is intended that the Territory should move toward statehood, responsibility for Aboriginal affairs should be handed over to the Northern Territory Government. Then Territorians, like people in other parts of Australia, would be able to decide suitable land rights policies for their part of the country without interference from the central Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In replying to some of the criticisms voiced about the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill, there are a number of points that I need to make. First, I point out that these amendments are merely the first part of a number of amendments which are being examined by the Government. They were brought into the House on the basis that they were largely non-controversial and were based upon recommendations made by Mr Justice Toohey which resulted from quite extensive discussions that had taken place with Aboriginal land councils, the Northern Territory Government and other interest groups in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's approach is interesting because if we look at the formal position of the shadow spokesman, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), we see that he puts on behalf of the Opposition the view that it will not oppose the Bill on the second reading, but it is critical of the legislation because it feels that it does not go far enough. The Opposition spokesperson also foreshadowed a number of amendments which basically duplicated the provisions of a private member's Bill introduced into the Senate by Senator Kilgariff. That was his position and I suppose, as he is the shadow spokesperson, that represents one position of the Opposition. In the course of the debate, however, it became increasingly clear-as it becomes increasingly clear on a day by day basis in other areas in this Parliament-that there are divisions in the Opposition on a whole range of issues. I will not go into the details of that but will simply say that on an issue such as this one would have thought that the shadow spokesperson's view would represent the broad flow of the debate that would then take place. Not a bit of it! The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) all made it perfectly clear, from their utterances and from their general position, that they are opposed in principle to the whole concept and all the concepts that are involved in land rights legislation as it has been passed by this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The honourable member for the Northern Territory says `Hear, hear'; so I am pleased that I am not misstating his position. As far as those honourable members are concerned, this legislation, which was introduced by the Fraser Government and subsequently amended by the Fraser Government, is mistakenly conceived. They are opposed to it in principle and they make that position perfectly clear. That is the first basic division in the Opposition's ranks and it is fairly fundamental because it erodes the general approach that has been taken by the shadow spokesperson on behalf of the Opposition. He puts the Opposition's case, but as fast as he puts it he is subject to vigorous and in some cases heated dissent from his colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we had the interesting contribution of the former Minister, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson). I am not quite sure what position he was putting but most of his speech was directed at regretting the fact that during the period of the Fraser Government amendments which could have been made were not proceeded with. He admitted that a very interesting and detailed report been had produced by Mr Rowlands, QC. He talked about the amendments prepared by the Northern Territory and Federal governments which were opposed by the Australian Labor Party. I do not know to what extent they were opposed by the Labor Party because, although I was in the Parliament at that time, it is a bit difficult for an Opposition to oppose amendments which were never in fact introduced. The problems encountered in those negotiations are endemic in the approaches which still bedevil the Opposition in this matter. It is all very well for the honourable member for the Northern Territory to say that this is not an area in which there should ever have been Commonwealth jurisdiction. The problem that he has with that approach is that there is very clear Commonwealth jurisdiction in this whole area of Aboriginal affairs. There is a very clear constitutional base for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your national Bill then?

—Let me deal with that. At the time this legislation was introduced by a Liberal government and at the time it was subject to some further amendments, also by a Liberal government, the Commonwealth was not merely asserting its position in respect of this, which was constitutionally sound, but also doing so on behalf of an Aboriginal population in the Northern Territory, which was some 25 to 30 per cent of the total population there at that time.
—It was 23 per cent.

—That is the honourable member's figure and he is notoriously wrong with most of his figures. The problem with the honourable member for the Northern Territory is that we can only ever believe half of what he says. The real problem for us is that we can never be quite certain which half.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a fundamental flaw in the general proposals of the Opposition-and this is a problem which continues to exist in the Northern Territory. This is not just a matter for discussion between the Northern Territory and Federal governments. The group that is most vitally involved, apart from the non-Aboriginal population, is the Aboriginal population itself. Given the extent to which the Parliament is involved in legislation which affects the rights and the obligations of Aboriginal people, it seems absolutely essential that there be full discussions with the Aboriginal people and leadership on the nature and the purpose of these amendments. Those discussions have been going on between the Government, Aboriginal people and every other vested interest group in the Territory for well over 2 1/2 years. I pay a compliment to the members of the Aboriginal affairs Caucus committee who have not only spent many hours receiving submissions but journeyed to the Northern Territory as a committee to receive evidence on the ground and to make their own assessments of the proposals put forward by the Government. In approaching that I believe they seriously studied, and continue to study, the arguments that have been put.

I think one of the prevailing problems-and I have pointed it out to both the Chief Minister and the Deputy Chief Minister of the Northern Territory-which this Government has to deal with, and one of the problems which I believe the Northern Territory Government has to seriously address itself to, is that at almost every level there is unfortunately a basic mistrust amongst Aboriginal people of the intention and the purposes of the Northern Territory Government. In respect of even some of the simpler amendments which are being considered and continue to be the subject of discussion, where Aboriginal people are given a choice as to whether these are areas that ought to be subject to control by the Commonwealth or subject to control by the Northern Territory Government, on every occasion they opt for the Commonwealth Government simply because when it comes down to it they say quite bluntly and quite simply that they do not trust the Government of the Northern Territory. I say that because, as I have said privately to both the Chief Minister and the Deputy Chief Minister, if the Northern Territory is serious about endeavouring to obtain statehood it must seriously address the attitude of something over 20 per cent of its community who do not see that Government as representing their hopes and aspirations. It may well be that it is not possible for any government to deal with all the hopes and all the aspirations, but there is a level of tension in that relationship which I believe, unless it is far more seriously addressed by the Northern Territory Administration, will ultimately be the rock upon which its hopes and aspirations for statehood fail.

I want to make another comment in relation to the contribution by the honourable member for the Northern Territory, because it is a very important point to make. He raised in the Parliament the question of the provisions in this legislation which did not make it compulsory for the land councils to keep a register. He waxed long-I would not say eloquently, but certainly at some length-about why this position should not be there: It denies virtually the main function of the land councils. It was an interesting argument and disclosed two things. It disclosed not merely the attitudes and the prejudices of the honourable member for the Northern Territory; it also disclosed the fact that he had not taken any time to read the report of Mr Justice Toohey upon which most of these amendments are predicated. If the honourable member were prepared to take some time to look at the arguments on pages 54 and 55 of a judge who had all the evidence and all the arguments before him he would understand that these amendments are based on the very specific recommendations of His Honour.

If the honourable member for the Northern Territory, during his speech, had directed himself to the arguments of Mr Justice Toohey and then brought forward arguments as to why he disagreed with them, he may have had some credibility. But what we got was the usual ranting, the usual raving, on the basis that the honourable gentleman is not going to waste any time reading the recommendations in the report because, if he did, that might substantially interfere with his long-held and preconceived prejudices.

It is pointless for the Opposition to assert that there is no constitutional foundation for the actions and responsibilities of the Commonwealth in the field of Aboriginal affairs. It is pointless to say that the responsibility ought to be the sole and exclusive responsibility of the Northern Territory Administration. The Northern Territory Administration, like most States, is more than prepared to accept from the Commonwealth very large sums of public funding in order to carry out necessary improvements in areas which are traditional areas of State responsibility. Housing is a State responsibility. Education is a State responsibility. The provision of roads and services is a State responsibility. But when it comes to dealing with Aboriginal people, State after State-and the Northern Territory Government is no exception-says: `We look to the Commonwealth to fund these because this is a Commonwealth responsibility'. They cannot expect the Commonwealth to go on providing funds and then say that we will not have any say in the policy decisions which affect the lives of thousands of Aboriginal people. Again I commend those views not merely to the honourable--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's all baloney.

—That I think is a statement which reflects more on the honourable gentleman than upon me, because, as I pointed out to him, had he been prepared to read the evidence of Mr Justice Toohey, he would not have made some of the thoroughly unsupportable statements that he has made to the Parliament. Quite frankly, the honourable gentleman has developed a method of dealing with many of these issues which does not involve seriously canvassing them in the Parliament or asking questions about them. He develops his positions by a series of Press releases to the Northern Territory News and that is the last we hear about those arguments. We certainly do not hear them being seriously canvassed in the Parliament although I must say that on this occasion the honourable gentleman was prepared to give us the benefit of his thoughts, and of course that displayed his lack of capacity or his unwillingness to look at the arguments that have been brought forward by Mr Justice Toohey in his recommendations. I will not take up the time of the House because we have dealt with the attitudes of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) and those others who simply--
—Take out your left foot and put in your right.

—If the honourable member is going to interject he should raise his standards because the kinds of stupid utterances which characterised his performance in the Northern Territory Parliament simply make him look like a totally inadequate representative of the Northern Territory in this Parliament. He should lift his game.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the other arguments put by members of the Opposition. The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) reiterated his opposition to any kind of Federal legislation and of course was very laudatory of the approach of the Queensland Government. I invite the honourable member for Fisher to look at the level of the contribution made by the Commonwealth Government in encouraging the Queensland Government to proceed with its deeds of grant in trust legislation and to look at the close working co-operation which has emerged between the two governments in getting those programs into place. That illustrates that, despite differences of approach and differences of political philosophy, it is possible for governments to work together for the mutual benefit of Aboriginal citizens by pooling resources. That has occurred in Queensland and the record is there. That record, I do not think, would be seriously denied in any way by the Queensland Minister.

Of course, we had the old argument trotted out-we always get it-that land rights legislation in the Northern Territory is an exercise in apartheid. That is a stupid argument. The view that, because this legislation exists to the benefit of Aboriginal citizens, somehow that creates apartheid similar to what is occurring in South Africa has been dealt with not merely by me but by the High Court of Australia. I commend to the honourable member for Fisher the utterances of Mr Justice Brennan in dealing with that very argument in respect of this legislation when he pointed out that the difference between apartheid and land rights is the difference between having a prison and having a home.

The purpose of this legislation and the amendments which are now prepared and are before the House is to give effect largely to the recommendations of Mr Justice Toohey. I concede that many of the amendments are machinery amendments and are of a non-controversial type. Some of the more difficult problems, for example, questions of mining on Aboriginal land and some of the other matters that have been adverted to, are still being considered by the Government. We hope to introduce further legislation which will deal with those more complex issues by early next year.

The Government has addressed and continues to address the concerns of all interest groups. The first and most obvious interest group is Aboriginal people. The report of Mr Justice Woodward made it perfectly clear that if miners are given an unfettered right to mine Aboriginal land, it would negate the whole purpose of land rights legislation, because of the special relationship which he recognised, which was the whole basis of the legislation enacted by the Fraser Government. There are miners who are aware of the sensitivities of Aboriginal people on this issue, but equally, fairly aggressive attitudes are shown by bodies such as the Australian Mining Industry Council. That Council takes the view of miners as an interest group in the community, which it is perfectly entitled to put to the Government; namely, that if there is a mineral there-it does not matter whether it is on private land or land which might be sacred to the Aboriginal community-it has an intrinsic right to get it up. It does not matter whether there is a mineral under the shrine of St Patrick's Cathedral, or wherever it is; the Australian Mining Industry Council believes its interests transcend every other interest in the community. That is not a new argument; it is a deeply held position. It is a position which was put to the Fraser Government by the Australian Mining Industry Council on no fewer than 18 occasions and rejected on no fewer than 18 occasions. It has been put to us and I equally reject it.

We are endeavouring to find and work towards a balance of what are essentially conflicting attitudes. There is a real difference and it is a problem for a government and a Minister when a group representing mining interests says: `It does not matter where the mineral is; our rights transcend every other right'. On the other hand, we have a situation where I, as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, have a responsibility to traditional people who, for quite legitimate and proper reasons, say that they do not want their lifestyle destroyed or enveloped by mining interests. That is not necessarily a universal position. As the honourable member for the Northern Territory and other honourable members know, a whole range of agreements between land councils and mining interests have been put into place in the Northern Territory, many of which are working well and positively.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: PIG INDUSTRY BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:PIG INDUSTRY (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986PIG SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Pig Industry Bill concurrently with the Pig Industry (Transitional Provisions) Bill and the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2). If there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The growth of the Australian pig and pigmeat industry to over 3,000 producers during the past decade has been one of the more encouraging developments in the rural scene. The gross value of production, which stood at $197m in 1974-75, is now about to break through the $500m barrier. Domestic pigmeat consumption has risen over this period from 12.9 kilograms per capita to an estimated 17.2 kilograms this year. It is important that producers, regardless of the size of their operation, should be able to make a fair living. Smaller scale producers, with perhaps 25 to 50 sows, have shown a very high degree of efficiency and have played a crucial role in the recent expansion of the industry. Their profitability in operations, of course, must not be compromised by the present mix of fiscal, wages and monetary policies. I will say more about that later.

SPEECH.PARA: I just mention the structure of the industry because I think that we will see it change considerably. A number of smaller producers will come into the industry because of their surplus wheat and grain production. I predict that next year will be an absolute disaster year for many of the cereal producers. It will not pay a great number of farmers to deliver their grain to the silos. Many of them would be much wiser to try to consume much of that grain on the farm. Pigs will be one of the big consumers of grain, therefore I hope that we will see a lot of very good and efficient producers coming into the industry.

It is now appropriate that the industry has made representations to the Government seeking to bring its promotional and developmental activities under the umbrella of statutory marketing reforms which have taken place in a range of farm industries. I give the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) some credit for having undertaken a number of reforms in relation to statutory marketing bodies. I am sure that those reforms will facilitate a much more efficient operation of those statutory marketing bodies. Some reforms were under way when we went out of government. The Minister has carried on a number of those initiatives and has even taken the reforms a step or two further.

The Pig Industry Bill and its two associated Bills, the Pig Industry (Transitional Provisions) Bill and the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2), will replace the existing Pork Promotion Committee with a more contemporary Australian Pork Corporation. I want to make it clear that the Bills will not establish a new statutory authority but will replace one which is perhaps not relevant to the demands of today. The promotional activities will be widened to enable pig producers, for example, to participate in such meat industry initiatives as computer aided livestock marketing-CALM-in the new stock language, Ausmeat. The computer aided livestock marketing scheme is very much part of the new technology available to industries generally. It is heartening to see that the meat industry has taken an initiative to try to encourage a greater use of this technology in marketing its products. I give some credit to Mr David Wright of Wollomombi, Armidale, for the amount of time and effort he has put into trying to adapt this technology to the livestock industry. He has done an enormous job in his own time and at his own expense. I am sure that ultimately it will be a great success and it will be widely used by the industry in the next few years. Of course, there are teething problems at present, but I am absolutely positive that they will be overcome.

A new formal statutory basis was considered to be necessary for pig producers to contribute financially to these promotion initiatives if they elect to do so.
