Associated with the legislation is a proposed increase in slaughter levies from 80c to $1 per head for promotion and from 20c to 30c for research. Further increases may occur as the Bills set a maximum promotion levy of $1.50. The new corporation will not be a trading body, nor will it become involved in any form of price setting mechanism which would restrict competition in the market-place. I think this is a very important aspect of this Corporation. It will not adopt any forms of price setting. I think that is a welcome decision by the industry because if it gets into that act ultimately there will be price setting arrangements that probably do not reflect the market-place requirement at all. It will comprise seven members with an independent chairperson, a Commonwealth Government member and, five nominees of a new Selection Committee chosen for its expertise in such matters as pig production, processing, marketing or other appropriate skills. The legislation also establishes an Australian Pig Industry Policy Council, comprising representatives from the producer, processor and selling links along the industry chain. The Council will advise the Minister on topics of importance and will develop pricing recommendations for Federal Government consider- ation.

The Opposition supports passage of these Bills, but as with other similar legislation we will be concerned to ensure that the new body continues adequately to respond to the interests and the wishes of the producers. It would be unacceptable to accede to the industry's request for a new corporation and to wrench control of these levy funds away from the growers at the same time. The industry has endorsed the structure of both the Corporation and its Selection Committee. While there appears to be general satisfaction with the initial arrangements the producers and their executive want to be sure they will retain authority over the expenditure of their funds in the longer term future. This year's slaughter rate is expected to reach 4.7 million head of pigs and so the levies of $1 rising to $1.30 a head are a substantial contribution to research and promotion. The Opposition considers it essential that those who provide the funds should, in turn, have control over expenditure.

This legislation imposes no cost to the taxpayers. I am sure the taxpayers listening will be pleased to hear this. All changes are funded directly by the industry. I think that is very important. In view of its financial independence, there should be no opposition to the Australian Pork Producers Federation's wish to exercise its right to seek an independent statutory body to improve its research and promotion marketing programs. A suggestion was put to the Federation and discussed at length that it consider merging the Pork Promotion Committee into the structure of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. However, the Australian Pork Producers Federation elected to pursue its own course and the Opposition does not oppose its decision to do so. Promotion has been a crucial element in pork, ham and bacon consumption growth over the past decade. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who is at the table, is very closely associated with the meat industry. He will know how important that is.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has made a fortune.

—It is good to have people in this place who have made a fortune out of something or other. I think that they do bring a bit of business expertise into the place. We should not knock him for it. We have not got enough people in this place who have made a fortune out of anything.
—What about Hawke?

—Well, everything he touched went broke-Bourke's store, ACTU-Solo-and, when he left the Australian Council of Trade Unions it was in a hell of a mess. By the time he leaves his job as Prime Minister, I think Australia will be in a mess. Let me return to the Bill.
—He won't be talking to me now.

—I think the Minister will make a better Prime Minister because of his great background. Regular activities of the Committee have included television, radio and Press advertising, magazine cookery supplements and regular contact with the retail trade. Among events on the industry's calendar this year has been the pork and bacon fair at Gunnedah in the electorate of Gwydir.

SPEECH.PARA: My wife, Miriam, and I were delighted to perform the official opening and take part in many of the activities, as well as observing the innovations and technology on display. In fact, my wife-I hope she is listening-was one of the judges of the Miss Pork Princess. I was very impressed with the decision that the judges made. She was a delightful girl actually. The annual conference is really a tremendous occasion. Honourable members will do well if they get an invitation to it. I hope I am there next year.

The promotional activities by the industry have been of an excellent standard. The changes introduced by this legislation should help producers, processors and others to maintain this standard and to make use of the latest technology in marketing. There are two innovations of special note in which the pork industry may participate as a result of this legislation. First, the national meat industries are developing a new market system, which I mentioned earlier, known as CALM. By providing a statutory basis for the collection and distribution of levy funds the industry will be able to become fully involved in CALM if it wishes to do so. Technology is already bringing major changes to some areas of livestock marketing, notably the video livestock auction system, which is enjoying strong support in a growing number of country centres.
It is worth recalling the comment by the President of the Intensive Pig Producers of Australia, Mr Leslie Tonkin, to the 1986 Farm Outlook Conference. He stated:
CALM is moving marketing several steps into the future-but a facility without throughput will be as stationary as a Ferrari without petrol.

I think that is a very good quotation. The move to a statutory corporation will give the industry a sound footing on which to participate in CALM if it elects to do so. Secondly, the new Corporation will have the option of joining Ausmeat, a meat classification monitoring scheme set up by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. I am aware that there has been some opposition by sections of the industry to participation in Ausmeat. In his second reading speech the Minister for Primary Industry said the industry would have a choice to do so-in fact in September the Australian Pork Producers Federation determined it would take part. It is anticipated a levy per head of 6.7c will be earmarked for this purpose. I ask the Minister for Primary Industry to make every effort to smooth the industry's path into Ausmeat, and to ensure that officers of his Department do all in their power to assist the pork producers during this transitional period.

I raise a further matter of specific interest to pork producers with a warning that any laxity of attitude on the part of the Government could spell disaster for the Australian industry. I refer to the threat of premature change to the quarantine regulations governing the importation of uncooked pig meat from Canada.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very important.

—It is very important, as the honourable member for Page has made clear. He has a lot of pig producers in his electorate. On 20 March this year I put a series of questions on the parliamentary Notice Paper to the Minister seeking information on the present regulations and advice as to the precautions being taken by the Government to ensure Australian herds are not exposed to such diseases as transmissible gastro-enteritis or Aujeszky's disease. In his response the Minister assured me that no changes would occur until exhaustive trials had been conducted by Agriculture Canada to prove these imports would not carry TGE. Subsequently we have learned that these trials are not being carried out. In turn, the Minister has now agreed to the industry proposal that trials be conducted by our own experts at the high security Australian National Animal Health Laboratory in Geelong. This is to be commended. It was a very commendable decision by the Minister. The trials, to be carried out over the next 12 months, should provide detailed information upon which the risks to Australian herds may be assessed.

SPEECH.PARA: TGE is a deadly virus with mortality rates of up to 100 per cent for piglets aged to four weeks. Once introduced to a herd it becomes endemic and cannot be slaughtered out. There would be no excuse for risking the importation of this disease without the most thorough trial results being known. One aspect of this issue remains unclear. Why is the Minister risking the entry of uncooked pig meat by changing the import regulations when we have an efficient pig industry of our own? I just wonder where the pressure is coming from. Is it coming from the Canadian Government? We have to be very careful about the introduction of disease into this very important industry. The animals themselves are subject to a number of diseases, this particular disease being one of them. Foot and mouth disease is another about which we have been very concerned for some time. It would be helpful to honourable members on this side of the House and to the industry if the Minister could explain why changes to the quarantine rules are now under active consideration.

Whatever progress is made by the industry with technology and innovation, its potential will be stunted while ever it is saddled with anti-investment, monetary, fiscal and wages policies at a Commonwealth government level. Mr Leslie Tonkin, in his keynote address to the 1986 Outlook Conference, said that, while pork producers had indications of improved profitability, four main negative factors came into place. These factors were named as: Increasing labour costs; monetary performance, including the direction of the dollar and interest rates; the threat of fresh pork imports; and the world agricultural trade scene. The first factor, wages policy, is one of the key flaws of Labor policy. Despite the 40 per cent devaluation against the trade weighted index-we are that much poorer as a nation-this Government has persisted with a 3 per cent across the board productivity deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions; a very bare discounting of wage increases despite an inflation rate, making us totally uncompetitive against our major trading partners; a range of anti-business policies which have further squeezed the capacity of Australian business to make a profit and, therefore, pay higher wages, leaving them little or no funds for essential capital reinvestment; and it has made little more than a few noises over outdated and costly work practices entrenched by certain unions, particularly those on the waterfront.

The wages pause in 1982 showed that all Australians are willing to share our economic burdens so long as governments deal with these problems in an even-handed fashion. Not only do we need wage restraint but also we must have restraints on government spending and a flatter, more equitable tax scale to encourage initiative and to encourage people to produce and to work. Flexibility must be built into the system to cope with changes in the external economy. Nowhere is this more important than in the export industries which are directly tied to world market returns and, of course, this involves the pig industry which is seeking to establish greater export outlets for its products.

Pork is one farm industry with tremendous export potential but that potential will never be realised while governments fail to create the right investment and export climate. The Outlook Conference was also told that pork producers must have relief from the near record interest rates. But, of course, no such action has been taken by the Government. Earlier this week, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) said, during Question Time in another place, that monetary policy would remain as tight as it is now `until a change is deemed appropriate'; in other words, when the Government feels like changing things. The Primary Industry Minister gave the matter a better perspective recently when he said in Narrabri, New South Wales, that interest rates threatened to damage seriously not only our long term economic prospects but also the electoral prospects of the Labor Party.

Nothing will save Labor at the next election, whenever the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wishes to call it. But it should be made clear that interest rates cannot stay at present levels without causing a deep and extended recession. If the Australian prime rate dropped from 18.5 per cent to, say, 11 per cent, which is the highest end of the European scale, the interest bill for Australian farmers would be reduced by $15.4m every week. Net farm incomes would be doubled and the farm crisis would be eased. There is a need for a crisis plan for those Australian farmers carrying high debt loads. According to a survey that I have completed, 30 per cent of farmers are at risk. There is a need for a larger injection of funds into the rural assistance boards for debt reconstruction through interest rate assistance. Certainly, there is a need to try to get the Primary Industry Bank of Australia into some program to see whether it will assist those bigger and larger operators with very heavy debt loads by extending the length of their borrowing. I will be talking to the bank in the near future about some propositions that I think ought to be looked at.

I have had a deputation representing pork producers and a great number of farmers in New South Wales and I just want to quote from a very interesting commentary by them. The first thing that I wish to quote from is a paper that has been prepared by Mr John Chudleigh who is the Head of the School of Rural Management at the Orange Agricultural College. He said:

Australia faces the prospect of losing the expertise and services of a large proportion of competent rural producers and their support services if current commercial developments are allowed to continue.

The number at risk at the start of 1986 as estimated by BAE was 12,000 producers. With high interest rates for all of 1986, this number is now substantially higher and could be in the vicinity of 30,000 producers.
These producers cannot meet their interest and/or lease or hire purchase commitments and consequently are losing equity as well as suffering extreme stress.
The lenders to these producers will face many difficult decisions during the next 12 months if there is little change in interest rates of commodity prices during that period.

That is a very serious summary of the situation by that noted expert. Another paper that was produced on this very real problem, by a group of people representing the Livestock and Grain Producers Association, sets out a view that I think ought to be heard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they the people who were here yesterday?
—I think the honourable member would be interested in this paper.
—Are they the people who were here yesterday?
—Yes, indeed. The paper states:

SPEECH.PARA: The best way for Australia to improve its balance of payments and reduce the current account deficit (currently fluctuating about the $1.5 billion/month mark) is to increase agricultural output-manufacturing industry would take far too long to mobilise and deliver a return!
The paper goes on:
The rural sector needs only an incentive as the infra- structure is already in place for an immediate start.

However, with the millstone of exorbitant interest rates about their necks, most farmers carrying a debt burden, will be flat out surviving without increasing or even carrying on production. e.g. Fertilizer in the grazing industry is all but a thing of the past.
There is no doubt that any saving in interest rates would pass into the general economy immediately, with the usual multiplier effect and subsequent increase in government revenue.

The main benefit of reduced interest rates in the rural sector would be to maintain present farm ownership and therefore, the expertise in the rural sector. If ownership changed dramatically to overseas or corporate ownership-
corporate ownership is a very doubtful prospect because so many of the corporate groups have got out of farming-
Australia's ability to raise the level of agricultural exports may well be permanently disadvantaged.
Finally, the paper states:

By assisting Australian farmers to retain ownership of their farms, we will be ensuring that ownership of our most important export potential is held by Australians for future generations and not sold off wantonly to Japanese or other foreign interests.

So, it is a very serious problem. That problem must be faced up to. I think we will have a major crisis in 1987. On the one hand, we have falling commodity prices. We have an increasing trade deficit. Nothing will overcome the trade deficit problem quickly. Manufacturing probably offers hope if the right policies are implemented down the line, but it will take some time. We also face a massive overseas debt. The burden of interest rates and of inflation on this productive sector of the economy is crippling. A further likely fall in grain prices of 20 to 30 per cent next year-that was the forecast of the Australian Wheat Board yesterday-will undoubtedly aggravate the critical problem facing us even now.

The Government is desperately pursuing policies of propping up the exchange rate, which it is doing by this enormous interest rate burden and by Reserve Bank of Australia intervention; there is no doubt that that is going on. What happens to our foreign exchanges in the ultimate? It is a catch 22 situation for the Government; I realise that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do?

—Clearly, the first thing that one must do is to reduce the deficit or to hold it at least in this year and to try to get more flexibility into the wages system to make it more reflective of our current account difficulties. The unions will not like that; of course they will not like it. But other people in the community have had--
—What does that mean?

—That means that our standard of living will fall. It is falling, and that has to be recognised. We cannot have a debt burden of the extent that we have and we cannot have balance of trade difficulties without people being prepared to recognise that they cannot go on asking for more and more when the system just cannot give it. The only way it can be given is by borrowing more money and putting future generations further into debt. That is something of which we need to be mindful in this country. We will not overcome the problem that we are facing while ever interest rates are as high as they are and while ever the farm sector in Australia, which is fundamental to our standard of living--
—The banks are going crook. They say that they are not making enough profit.

—It is not so much the fault of the banks, surely, in this deregulated financial system that everybody acclaims. We have a market situation determined by Government policy, by economic policy, by the macroeconomic policy that this Government has implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no denial that world commodity prices are depressed. But this should not be the linchpin upon which this Government develops its agricultural policies. It is no good constantly blaming the world market price. We have no alternative but to sell 70 per cent of our agricultural production at the world market price. If the Government cannot bring interest rates down to a more competitive level within a reasonable time, it will have to face the implementation of a Keith Wright plan or some other plan to overcome the great interest rate burden that farmers are carrying at present.

We are facing a crisis of great magnitude and the pork industry is not quarantined from it. Measures such as those contained in this legislation will be of little long term benefit to the people in the industry unless the Government is prepared to implement measures that reduce their cost burden. The Government should take some of the pressure off their transportation costs. It should rely less on fuel as a source of revenue. It should replace those tariff burdens with bounties, as has been done already to some extent, and also make an earnest effort to reduce the interest rate burden which is killing Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latter part of the speech by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) was mainly a filler; I can understand that. It included suggestions as to what the Government should do but not as to how the Government should do it. That is characteristic of all Opposition policies. Opposition members have been unable to tell us how we, or they, could fill their prescriptions. The honourable member for Gwydir talked about this Government propping up the exchange rate. For 7 1/2 years Fraser-Howard Budgets propped up the exchange rate. He talked to us about interest rates. Our interest rates have not reached the heights that interest rates reached in the 7 1/2 years of the Fraser-Howard Governments. He asked us to reduce our deficit. The last Howard deficit was headed for $9.6 billion, but the deficit is now down to $3.5 billion. What is the Government doing? It is doing exactly what the honourable member prescribed. He has not told us how he would reduce the deficit further. He has not suggested any ways in which the various government departments should reduce their expenditure. He has not suggested how cuts should be made. He has not said whether the Government should discontinue its action on rural poverty and other welfare measures. The honourable member for Gwydir talked about a flatter tax scale. To some extent we are doing that. But we are not doing what is suggested by the Opposition. One tax suggestion from the Opposition would mean that a farmer on $10,000 a year would pay the same percentage in tax as a corporate producer executive earning $100,000 a year. Surely the farmer on a family income of $7,500 a year after tax who has to bring up a family, educate the children and buy petrol, and who has done the hard work of production, is worth more than 10 per cent of the income of an executive on $100,000 a year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Pig Industry Bill 1986, the Pig Industry (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1986 and the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 are an important development, following many years of work and consultation between the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), the Department of Primary Industry, the pig meat industry and the Pork Promotion Committee. In 10 years the number of pigs slaughtered has increased by 1.1 million to an estimated 4 1/2 million in 1985-86. The Bills take account of the need for the industry to become heavily involved in computer-aided livestock marketing and in the development of a national livestock language, Ausmeat. They also take account of the unique nature of the pig industry, which wanted to be independent of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation in both computer marketing and Ausmeat development. The legislation provides for a new Australian Pork Corporation which will have wider functions than the existing Pork Promotion Committee. It will have expertise in pig production, pig meat processing and promotion and marketing.

Let us look briefly at the industry. Since 1981 exports have increased by about $9m, from $4m in 1981 to an estimated $13m in 1986. Looking through the history of the industry, we see that there were some very significant events, particularly in 1983 when there was a slide in prices. The cost of feed was high, there were high sales expectations and yet there was a levelling off in demand for pig meat, which was unexpected. In the same year Australia was coming closer to the beginning of corporate ownership of pigs and the pig meat industry. The Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd had control of about 15,000 breeding sows, producing 200,000 piglets. Its firm, Australian Bacon Ltd, with its Dandy range, processed and marketed the pig meat. Naturally, 8,000 independent farmers were worried. They did not want to find themselves in the same situation as the poultry industry had found itself in, wherein growers were locked into the same corporation supplying chicks, supplying feed, supplying medication and then buying the broilers that were produced. This led to a control over the charges for inputs to the farmer as well as a control of the prices paid for the outputs of that farmer. This has led, in the broiler industry, to a squeeze on family incomes and in some cases devastation, especially when there have been untimely events. I recall some 20 years ago a broiler grower having a power failure and the deaths of birds in his sheds devastated his family. It was economically crippling.

In 1983 Elders IXL Ltd was also entering the pig industry. It was called vertical integration, but that really means control right down the line. In the same year a wide range of research grants were made available by the newly elected Hawke Labor Government. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) announced Government funding for 26 continuing and 25 new projects covering breeding, welfare, nutrition, accommodation and disease. Just a few examples include: At the University of Melbourne, a pro- ject on the motivation of pigs to perform behaviour patterns frustrated by an intensive environment; at the University of Sydney, a project on gastric ulceration and digestive function; at the University of Western Australia, a project on reproductive studies in commercial pigs; in the Victorian Department of Agriculture, a project on the influence of intensive housing and stress responsiveness on the welfare status and productivity of breeding sows and a project on the effects of sex and level of feeding on the protein requirements of finisher pigs; and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation undertook a project on the technical appraisal and development of pig accommodation. All these matters are of significance in the breeding, welfare, nutrition, accommodation and disease of pigs and are important to a wide range of people-not just the producers and processors but also those concerned with the welfare of livestock.

With the new Minister for Primary Industry in 1983 a useful and productive period of consultation with the industry began. Discussion centred on electronic auction and the national livestock language. By 1985 imports had become a controversy. The honourable member for Gwydir mentioned that and I do not propose to enlarge on what he said. In that year the industry also rejected bringing the marketing of pigs and pig meat under the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation.

In 1986 we find a quite different scene. The recent Bureau of Agricultural Economics report on the rural economy, issued in November 1986, showed pig saleyard prices up 4 per cent and yet retail prices are up 6.8 per cent. Once again the middle operator soaks up funds at the expense of both the independent producer and the consumer. In 1986 concentration of the industry into fewer businesses has continued. Adsteam now has 30,000 breeding sows, double the 1983 number, and, as well as Dandy, controls Mayfair and Presto. Today around 15 large firms control about 35 per cent of pig numbers. It is nothing like the chicken industry, but it is more structured than before. We find, as is the case with the crisis in the wheat industry, that not the same number of people are diversifying into pigs. Such diversification is not as striking as it was a few years ago.

Under this legislation a new Australian Pork Corporation will have the power to contribute financially to marketing arrangements, for example, computer aided livestock marketing and the development of a national livestock language, called Ausmeat. I hope this means that independent producers will be able to strengthen their position as against that of corporations, through access to these modern marketing techniques. We do not want the agony of the broiler grower industry to be reflected in the pig industry. I support the Bill and wish the industry and the Corporation well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing legislation to replace and improve upon the Pig Industry Research Act 1971. The legislation is at the request of the Australian Pork Producers Federation and is generally in line with the Government's attitude in changing the structure of primary produce marketing authorities. In contrast to a number of other primary industries which are going through times of crisis, the pig industry is providing reasonable returns. A combination of events, such as the industry being based within the domestic market-only 2 per cent of the whole production is exported-a rise in domestic consumption and a collapse in the cost of grain prices have meant that returns have been maintained. The margins, however, are slim, and the profitability is reliant on intensive and efficient production techniques. For the farmer to keep up the pace, high capital costs are involved in setting up the piggery. These farmers would be paying around 18 per cent interest on their borrowed capital; meanwhile their own capital which is tied up in their farms would be returning more in the order of 8 per cent. Interest rates at these levels have the same effect as a tax on the productive sector.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be understood that pig production is mostly carried out in conjunction with other forms of agriculture. In Western Australia, for instance, there are over 350 pig producers with 20 sows or more. Recent Bureau of Agricultural Economics statistics indicate that approximately 6 per cent of farms based on mixed livestock and crops will be at risk this year-that is, they will have difficulty meeting their debt commitments. The main problem is that interest rates have increased by about half since the Labor Government took office, when at the same time interest rates paid by our major trading partners have been steadily falling. Our annual inflation rate is now around 9 per cent, compared to rates for our trading partners of, in the United States, 1.6 per cent; in Japan, 0.5 per cent, and West Germany, which has deflation, of 0.5 per cent. The Government's measures of increasing indirect taxes on basic consumer goods such as wines, fruit juice and flavoured milk, as well as the hike in petrol prices, contribute directly to inflation. Whatever the arguments the Government uses, these policies have resulted in inflation and interest rates way out of line with world trends. The disastrous mix of deregulating our financial markets and maintaining total regulation of our wages and labour market has accelerated our international decline for the 3 1/2 years that this Government has been in control. Containing our labour and wages costs is central to turning around our current account deficit-which incidentally has averaged $1 billion a month for the last 3 1/2 years. That is, the Government has plunged their fellow Australians into a $38 billion loss on our trade results during that time. The high cost of labour for the farmer-which has been further increased through the fringe benefits tax-is another example where government imposed costs have shown no relationship to the market-place.

As I mentioned earlier, the pig industry is based around a $450m domestic market. At the start of this year we saw an attempt by Canadian exporters to gain access to the fresh pork meat market in Australia. The prospect of aujeszky's disease or transmissible gastro-intestinal virus gaining entry to Australia through imported fresh meat products is of grave concern to the pig industry, and one the Government must not take risks on. The current ban must remain in place until water-tight guarantees, backed by trials, which will now apparently take place in the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory in Geelong, are given. These will be concluded around October 1987. The point should be strongly made that access should be based on the matter of safeguarding the Australian industry, not on considerations of trade. Personally, I have little faith in the expertise of our Government negotiators in respect of primary industry. The public servants do not value our industries' worth as highly as a farmer who has his life's work and his family's future tied up in it. They do not drive hard enough deals. Yet, because of various Government regulations and considerations across the broad spectrum of Government involvement, industries can be compromised, as we have seen recently with the Western Australian tuna industry.

There is one way to ensure the moral probity of any decision regarding any industry, and that is to consider only arguments that are directly valid to that particular industry. In considering the establishment of the Australian Pork Corporation, the alternative was the merger of the Pork Promotion Committee and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. I have also taken the view of a number of small pig producers within my electorate. Their view was that statutory marketing authorities can get out of hand and, in terms of the additional bureaucracy that the industry must support by government regulation, the industry probably does not warrant such legislation at this stage. It must be remembered that the industry is not export based, and the new Australian Pork Corporation's role will be one of marketing, production and processing.

If one is primarily concerned with the streamlining or the reduction of the legislative burden, I can see good sense if the Pork Promotion Committee had merged with the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. Many of the AMLC's skills in overseas marketing will be essential to the pig industry, as will the AMLC's initiatives in the area of computer marketing of livestock, CALM, and the development of a national livestock language, Ausmeat. Still, the creation of the separate Australian Pork Corporation was at the industry's request, and the additional costs that growers will incur will be offset by the advantages of autonomy.

The pig industry is a good example of a high level of co-operation among producers, processors, marketing organisations and government. The moderate level of return has meant that the pig producers have been able to take advantage of recently developed technology. One rarely sees a parrot being flung into the swill trough these days. Our pigs are fed on high quality Australian grain. Producers must have good returns to be able to afford the luxury of recent technological improvements. In recent years the Government has believed that one can continue to load up the primary producer with petrol costs, interest rises, restrictions on storage of grain, government run transport monopolies, high cost labour rates and increased taxation, and then tell him to go out and compete in the market-place. Farm costs are the farmers' biggest problem, related to interest rates, and in reality the only thing a government can do about it is to assist farmers with those costs and interest rates. I support the legislation that is before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Pig Industry Bill and cognate Bills, it is worth noting that it has the support of the industry, which is an indication of this Government's willingness to consult the industry and to act on its behalf. It will bestow on the industry a degree of autonomy which means that it will be responsible for its actions and for the consequences of its actions. This is the essence of free enterprise, and I am sure that all honourable members support it. Listening to the debate, I was surprised at how wide ranging it was. Some mention was made of the transmissible gastroenteritis problem which the Government has addressed. It has nothing to do with this Bill, and I do not propose to dwell on it, except to say that I thought it was unnecessary to mention it in relation to this Bill. The Government is aware of the problem, and it is taking a very responsible attitude to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, the Canadians want access to the Australian market. As a country that preaches free trade in agricultural products, we obviously cannot deny that unless it is on very good health grounds. We cannot, as other nations do, simply put forward spurious grounds. I look forward with interest to the results of a study that is taking place at the moment at the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) in his rather wide ranging speech, mentioned quite a lot of things about the industry generally. I think they have to be taken on, to some extent. He told us what should happen but suggested no ways at all in which his views could be implemented. In fact he steered very wide of giving any indication of what the Opposition, as a government, would do. The truth is that it simply does not know.

The honourable member picked on the hoary question of wage deregulation. As I have spent most of my life in primary industry, I can remember when, in the early 1960s, I was taking part in what will be the last great pastoral development in Australia-the opening up of the Nullarbor. At that time we were faced with a de facto wage deregulation. The mining companies, which were then very gung ho about nickel, simply paid double the pastoral award. The result of this was that people left the pastoral industry in droves to work in the nickel exploration industry. That left the pastoral industry with the option of either increasing wages dramatically or employing fools, criminals or pommies. I am very grateful to the pommies who were in Australia at that time because a lot of them were interested in getting experience and seeing Australia and not simply in chasing a quick dollar. I congratulate those people for their effort in the development of the Nullarbor.

It indicates how irrational the economics of the Opposition can be. In a highly competitive situation it is quite clear that if the industries which are depressed offer less they get a lower standard of labour and there is an increased drift to the cities. These things have to be considered. The great problem facing Australia today is not the multitude of little problems that the honourable member for Gwydir addressed but the growing dichotomy between city and country people. There was a time when people in the cities were aware of and sympathetic towards the problems of the people in the country. I am afraid that in the last 30 years this has gone, and it has gone in part because of things such as the immigration policy and the attitude of some people in rural areas.

I was a great supporter of the campaign of the National Farmers Federation, which was designed to bring country and city people together. It probably has not succeeded. I am very sad to say that I think it may even be counterproductive. On reflection, one can see why this has occurred. Because of the need to pay for this costly campaign it obviously had to have sponsorships. So we saw pictures on the television of farmers driving brand new equipment in bright green country, under almost idyllic conditions. It reinforces the view in the cities that everything on the farm is lush, green and lovely. Of course it is not. I do not quite know why that was put over. I say this with all the wisdom of hindsight because at the start I had not realised what was happening either. It is something that has to be addressed. The concept is very good, very valuable and very necessary for Australia, and it has to be addressed if the rural sector is to get value out of that campaign.

In one breath the honourable member for Gwydir talked about devaluation as though it is terrible for the industry, but then he talked about having more devaluation as though this would be good for the industry. In my opinion he showed a complete lack of understanding of how business works. The truth is that the Reserve Bank of Australia undoubtedly has been working to support the value of the Australian dollar. The Australian dollar today is probably undervalued. If its value were to rise rapidly I would be most concerned-certainly for the future of the rural sector. We must realise that the problem is that for many years the value of the dollar was kept artificially high because the parties that were then in power, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, had no policy to deal with wages except to bear down on prices. It kept the value of the Australian dollar high to make imports cheap, to put continual pressure on the Australian manufacturing sector and, of course, to cause unemployment.

The countries in which the rural sector is doing relatively well have a policy of supporting that sector from their manufacturing sector. To do this, a country needs a very large manufacturing base. Australia cannot be in that position, unfortunately, because it export a very large percentage of its agricultural products. But we can move towards that, and there is a great need in Australia today to re-establish manufacturing industry in this country. Indeed, if we are to have a future we have to have a direction whereby we encourage manufacturing industry based on natural advantage or intellectual advantage. By that I mean industries in which we actually invent the product, add value to it in Australia and market it from Australia.

The honourable member for Gwydir also talked about other problems on the land. There is no doubt that the downturn in commodity prices has been a tremendous burden to Australian farmers, particularly in the area of wheat. But there is another problem facing us. It is not only the downturn in prices; it is the shrinking of world markets. Only this morning it was announced that Bahrain would reduce its imports of wheat, presently running at some 32,000 tonnes a year, to a trickle. It will now buy wheat from Saudi Arabia, a country which, with Australian expertise, has learnt to irrigate the desert. It is those factors that we have to look at. We have to realise that the market for wheat will be a contracting one and we have to get into diversification.

We were told about the farm costs. The truth is-in the pig industry, as in other sections of the Australian agricultural industry-that the rate of increase in farm costs has dramatically reduced under this Government. That is generally recognised by farmers. This Government will continue to do what it can in that regard. It is interesting to note that in Western Australia the State owned railway system is in fact carting wheat more cheaply today in real terms than it was five years ago. I think the performances of the then Minister for Transport, Julian Grill, and the present Minister for Transport, Gavan Troy, have been exceptional in this regard. This has not been emulated in New South Wales. The New South Wales system is quite crazy, and there is no doubt that this is an indictment of all State governments in New South Wales over a very long period. It must be remembered that this trouble did not start recently. It certainly was festering away when the Liberals had power in New South Wales. I believe the State Rail Authority of New South Wales really does have to get its act together, and a lot of attention has to be paid to that.

Interest rates are an interesting thing. I believe interest rates are one of the great problems facing the rural sector. There is no doubt that, because of government macroeconomic policy, interest rates have been forced up. I do not run away from that at all; I think there are very good macroeconomic reasons for that. But there is no doubt that it affected in fact a group of farmers who, I think, are vital to the future viability of the pig industry and other industries in the farming sector. In this group generally is the young fellow who went out, probably under-capitalised, full of hope and strength, to substitute his hard work for capital-which meant he had to borrow money. Also affected was the more entrepreneurial type of person, who borrowed money for development at what were realistic interest rates only to have those interest rates double on him.

I believe that some targeting of assistance to those people should have taken place. In consultation with many farmers in Western Australia, I in fact put forward a program for targeting of interest rate reductions. We put forward a couple of proposals which were quite workable. There is no doubt about that. They failed, in fact, because the NFF was incapable of coming to grips with the concept of targeting assistance. For it, interest rate assistance had to be across the board; whether people needed it or not, they all had to have it. The cake is always only so big. If it has to be cut infinitely it means that people get a very small piece; in fact, a piece so small that it does them no real good at all. For those who are doing well it is just a bit of icing on the cake; for those in trouble it is not enough to help them.

The honourable member for Gwydir talked about pumping more money into rural adjustment. The problem is: The rural adjustment bodies do not need any more money; they are brimming with money. Money is coming out at the seams. The problem is that the guidelines are so strict that farmers cannot take advantage of the money that is there. That is the problem that has to be addressed. It is getting access to the money, not the need for more money.

While these problems are very real, it is interesting to note what has happened to the people who are supposed to speak on behalf of the rural sector. The NFF has run a campaign targeted at the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. I can tell the NFF, the National Party and the Liberal Party that the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes are not concerns of genuine farmers. My electorate has the highest farm debt ratios in Australia-and even in those areas farmers are not talking to me about the fringe benefits tax, because the truth is that they do not pay it. There is very little employment of other people in the rural sector and so these farmers are not generally affected by the fringe benefits tax. Where there is any effect it is absolutely minimal.

My mind goes back to a meeting I attended in Salmon Gums in Western Australia. It was convened by the Country Women's Association, an organisation for which I have a very high regard. I congratulate it on the initiative it took. At the meeting I was confronted with a chartered accountant who also happened to be the President of the Liberal Party branch at Esperance. Frankly, I thought I had been set up. Before the meeting he said `I would like to make a short statement' and, since I had no power to stop him, I readily concurred. He said: `I want to tell you people-as many of you are my customers-that you do not have to pay any fringe benefits tax if you do not pay fringe benefits. What you are on about is substantiation. I have been filling in your returns on the basis that what you told me was true, and I certainly hope it was'. He then went on to say that he was ashamed of his own association, which had given an enormous amount of misinformation to people. He concluded by saying: `If the previous Government had had any guts'-the Government of the Party of which he was a member-`it would have introduced legislation like this, because the tax system was a shambles and many farmers know that they were being forced to pay because of the greed and avarice of people who were simply avoiding their responsibility'.

In respect of the pork industry, I must say that I am concerned about the vertical integration that is taking place. I hope that in the measures established by this Bill there is some mechanism whereby a check can be kept on this. The vertical integration will tend to squeeze out the smaller producer unless he is very careful. It will tend to put pressure on his prices unless he is very watchful. It also involves a very high degree of regulation. But while the people opposite talk about deregulation, which in most cases is a misnomer, if we have a high degree of vertical integration we have a totally regulated industry. It is regulated in the interests of a few against the interests of the many. That is so self-evident that I do not think we need talk about it. I think the Government has shown an initiative in facilitating the setting up of this organisation, which will allow farmers to have a large say in their future. I think governments do have the power to take these initiatives.

I was interested to hear my good colleague talk about the tuna industry in Western Australia. What happened with the tuna industry in Western Australia? We regulated that industry. It is now on a very sound basis. But in the process of regulation quotas were made transferable and salable and South Australia stepped in and bought up the quotas in large measure. The Western Australian Government did what it could by putting a floor price on the value of those quotas in an endeavour to retain them in Western Australia. It was unable to attract enough Western Australians to the ideal of selling to them the quota so that it could redistribute them to Western Australian fishermen. What the Western Australian Government has done since is to take a very prominent part in the development of the sashimi business. The present Minister for Agriculture, Julian Grill, has had one of his staff members working full time on this and we now have the situation of fishermen in Esperance looking at great prosperity because of the emerging sashimi industry in which quality and marketing are absolutely essential.

I believe that the Australian pork industry can show the same sorts of initiatives and the same sorts of marketing endeavours to expand the appreciation in the public mind of pork. I congratulate the industry. I think it was wise not to become associated with the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, not because I have any objection to that organisation-in fact, I think it is doing a good job-but there is no doubt that pork will be in competition with some of those other products. I believe that the pork industry should be out there fighting its own battles, reaping its own rewards and of course facing up to any problems that arise from its own bad decisions.

In conclusion, I wish to comment on a couple of the sillier things that are fetishes of the National Party of Australia. National Party members seem to think that there is something magical about the ownership of land. While it is true that interest rates are an enormous burden to farmers, unrealistic prices of land are an even greater burden. These prices keep out young farmers who want to get established and make it harder for people to expand their farms in order to cater for growing families. If the price of land were allowed to fall to a more realistic level, it is self-evident that interest rates would also fall. If the price of land halved the interest rate burden would also halve, regardless of the rate at which it was pitched. When I hear the honourable member for Gwydir talk about the ownership of land, I cannot help feeling that this is a nonsense concept. Does he think that the Japanese who buy a farm, and in doing so put some stability into the market, will then roll it up and take it away and leave a hole in Australia? Of course that will not happen. In my electorate some land has been bought up by European interests. Inevitably this has been leased back to the vendor, who is now working the farm profitably without the burden of actual ownership. This practice has kept people on the land and kept small towns viable. It is not necessarily a bad thing. I am not saying that it should go unobserved, but to look at it in the same way as the honourable member for Gwydir is to adopt a very silly concept. I commend the Bill and I commend the Minister's action in bringing it forward. I certainly wish the industry well and all the best for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 106a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Economy-Christopher Boyce-Tasmania-Taxation-Australian War Memorial-Middle East Conflict-Soviet Union: Jewish Culture-Victorian Land Sale

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than any other single factor, it is uncertainty which is the enemy of economic progress. The heaping of one uncertainty on top of another by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government since they came to office in March 1983 has earned him and it the title of public enemy number one in Australia today. That is undoubtedly true when we reflect on the depressing economic performance in Australia over almost four years of the Hawke Administration. The genesis of government-inspired uncertainties is to be found in countless broken and abandoned election pledges. It is also to be seen in major policy changes foreshadowed, but not immediately-and in some cases never-acted upon, as well as forecasts of economic improvements which have simply not materialised.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian public may not have fully appreciated the portent of the Prime Minister's first broken promise and that is no doubt long forgotten. But it took only three days after his election in March 1983 for this Prime Minister to break his first election promise-just three days. Even today there is a sizable but thankfully ever decreasing number of Australians who hang on to and even believe the solemn undertakings of the Prime Minister. What was the first of these countless broken promises given in 1983? On 10 February of that year the Prime Minister, his eyes disappearing into his forehead and the corners of his mouth pointing to the ground, said: `We will not be devaluing'. He was of course, talking about the value of the then managed Australian dollar. What happened? Just three days after he was elected the Prime Minister devalued our currency by 10 per cent. It took just three days after the elections for the Hawke Government to betray its true intentions! Since then, of course, there has been a veritable avalanche of betrayals. It seems that there is to be no end to them. Back in 1983 broken election promises just became the order of the day. That has been the case ever since. First there was the devaluation. That was followed, with almost indecent haste, by the decision to renege on promised tax cuts. Intermingled with the broken election promises there was in 1983 the foreshadowed and much vaunted economic summit. It came and went without any resolution of the question as to the likely intentions of the then new Government becoming apparent. The uncertainty in the minds of those in other than perhaps big government, big unions and big business was simply not satisfied. Then there was the May 1983 mini-Budget, which did not deliver the promised tax cuts and instead imposed additional taxes and charges. The home loan rebate was scrubbed without prior warning. Retrospective tax legislation was introduced. Calls for expansionary economic policy were rife. Speculation about capital gains tax abounded. That speculation was not put to rest by the Government at that time. We found out why some short 12 months ago. We saw also the Combe affair and the irrational Tasmanian spy flights.

Interspersed with the events of 1983 were the implications and effects of the hastily contrived prices and incomes accord, the application of which no one-not even the Australian Council of Trade Unions-then understood. Mr Deputy Speaker, nothing has changed since in terms of the massive uncertainty that was generated by the so-called accord between big government and big unions, and the successive accords. There were to be good and bad uranium mines, provided the good were limited to one in South Australia. The bad were to be all the others, throughout the remainder of Australia. We saw the Medicare debacle perpetrated and a myriad of accompanying promises of better and cheaper health care fail to materialise. In fact, the opposite happened. The year 1983 was not even over before the Prime Minister, with the help of an ever compliant and fawning Press, started floating the possibility that there would be another general election in 1984. Never mind his pathetically solemn election promise that if Labor were elected in 1983 his Government would serve a full term of three years. That was to become another sacrifice at the altar of truth. Further uncertainty was born out of speculation about the timing of that early election. That particular uncertainty through 1984 was supplemented by the Government's blind support for universal employer-funded superannuation, as well as for anything that the ACTU, in its submissions to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, might want. We saw, without even a warning being given or a mandate being obtained from the electorate, a massive increase made in the number of senators and members of this Parliament.

Then there was the 1984 vote now pay later Budget which, sadly, a majority of voters fell for. With the premature December 1984 general election behind him, the Prime Minister then decided to go for broke. Despite his election campaign, which was notable for the absence of a taxation policy, the Prime Minister set about placing more impediments in the way of certainty and therefore in the way of economic progress. We were to have-may we all eventually forgive him-a tax summit. In the run-up to the misnamed tax summit, over a period of six or seven months, economic uncertainty and instability reigned supreme. There was no improvement as the public came to learn how the Prime Minister had rolled his Treasurer (Mr Keating) in a backroom deal with his masters in the ACTU. Prime ministerial promises that interest rates would fall during 1985 meant simply nothing. Instead they rose, and the Prime Minister's words were once again shown to be less than cheap.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rates are still going up.

—They are still going up. We, in the Opposition, had supported the Government's decision to float the Australian dollar but the Government then, through the agency of the Reserve Bank, set about surreptitiously propping it up to artificially high levels, in the process risking our precious and increasingly scarce international reserves. By mid-1985 there were clear signs, very clear signs indeed, that domestic and international developments meant dire trouble ahead for both our balance of payments and our trading account. Despite the consistent warnings by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and my colleagues and me, the Prime Minister continued to maintain that his policies were just what were needed. We know that the Prime Minister has been advised by his media minders to recultivate his ocker image, but to adopt his `She'll be right' approach to our economic malaise is to plumb new depths of political irresponsibility. Lately he has lauded his Government's monetary policy although one has not even been announced. The Treasurer walked away from announcing money supply goals a couple of years ago when it all became too hard for him. A basic element of any monetary policy surely is knowing what one's goals are for the supply of money, either in terms of M3 or in the broad. As a consequence, the domestic and international markets have been left with no option but to speculate. Mr Deputy Speaker, the actions of people, whether they be consumers, investors or entrepreneurs, will be influenced for better or for worse by their intelligent understanding and certain knowledge of a Commonwealth Government's intentions and its ability to manage its affairs. Bluff, bluster, cant and humbug such as we hear from the Prime Minister are simply no substitute. Consumers, investors and entrepreneurs of all shades have made their judgments and the waffling simply has to stop. The thinking which sees fuel costs escalating widely in Australia while falling throughout the rest of the world has to stop. The mentality that sees vote catching promises broken after elections at the twinkling of an upturned eye, appealing for the approbation of the Press Gallery, has to stop. The fulminating, the backing and filling by the Prime Minister simply has to stop.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 November 1975 we saw the culmination of the most blatant act of external interference in Australia's affairs and its autonomy as a nation and a democracy. The dismissal of the Whitlam Government was orchestrated by a combination of forces inside and outside Australia-namely the United States of America. Now, 11 years later, with the protection of history, this matter has not been properly and exhaustively addressed by either the Australian or the United States governments, present or past. Nor has it been addressed by the Australian media or faced by the Australian people. We have had plenty of opportunities to do so. Much has been said in the media about a former Australian Prime Minister who, in a city in the United States, could not find his trousers. That sort of thing attracts a lot of media attention. Again, we have seen the question of the use of three little words, `my little mate', take the whole of Australia by storm for a year or more and follow a man from the beginning of his career to his grave. We listen day by day, as does the Press, to references to this issue of external interference but the Press has heard it all before and says nothing or very little about it. This issue is not addressed in Australia. The Australian people have held their heads in the sand over it. In fact, they have had their heads held in the sand over it. The Australian Press has virtually ignored the biggest political history event in Australia, the biggest story that they could want in a democracy and an autonomous nation. The public has failed to seek further information. I blame most of that on the Press because it has not sought to pursue the matter further. The blame does not lie there alone. It extends further, to this Parliament, but it is difficult to decide what happened and which way to address this matter first. Should we look at what happened or why it happened? In this event we have a significant amount of evidence which shows the involvement of the United States, through the Central Intelligence Agency, the CIA. It is a concern which virtually every Australian has had at some time or another. I am sure that the extent of the involvement of the CIA, of the United States, in this event, has crossed the minds of honourable members opposite who were perhaps on the fringe of the event. For those in the community who are concerned it is a constant sore and a reminder of the threat that we are placed under. Allegations and information are available in Australia and overseas, and have been for a long time, but we are faced by the iron curtain of American intelligence; we are faced by the Berlin Wall of American intelligence and Australian secrecy, the unavailability of such information to the public.

SPEECH.PARA: One person who did make this information as public as possible, and is now paying the price for having caused quite a furore, was Christopher Boyce, a person convicted in the United States for spying, and serving a 68-year sentence in solitary confinement. He was denied a fair trial because he was prepared to say things that neither the Australian nor the United States governments wanted the public to hear. He was, in 1974, a disillusioned 21-year-old. His faith in the country of his birth had been shaken to the foundations by Vietnam, by Watergate, by racial tension and the mad march towards nuclear destruction. He took a simple job as a postal clerk in an electronics firm, TRW Systems, in California. He stipulated to his employer that his interest in the job was limited to staying only for as long as it took him to save enough money to return to college, but less than two weeks after his commencement a detailed personnel file on Boyce was sent to the CIA. His employer had made the curious decision to recommend this 21-year-old, this restless ex-student who was eager to improve his financial status, to operate and work in a department run by the CIA in this company. Thirteen weeks later Boyce was transferred to the CIA black vault, a communications relay room. He was inexplicably given an exclusive security clearance that allowed him access to America's most secret espionage operations. During the briefing for this new job, that Boyce had not asked for, he was told that much of the communications involved would be coming from Pine Gap in Australia; that although the United States had signed an executive agreement with Australia to share information from Pine Gap, the agreement was not being honoured. It was emphasised that certain information must not be passed to Australia-he was working for the CIA although employed by a private company. He was witnessing at first hand his country's betrayal of allies and had been told that his complicity in deceiving Australia was expected. That was the situation.

Eventually he was brought to trial because he gave information to the Russians and brought out what the United States was doing in its relationship with Australia through Pine Gap. Neither of Boyce's defence lawyers was ever allowed to see any of the documents that he had passed to the Russians, nor were they allowed to examine the file on the CIA's own investigation of Boyce. This despite the fact that both of Boyce's lawyers held the appropriate security clearances. Could it be that the documents were in fact so useless to the Russians that if they had been produced as evidence in court the case would have been dismissed? This matter should certainly be laid to rest but should it be left to rest? As Australian citizens, are we to accept CIA violation of our domestic affairs? Does it matter to us that the United States lied about Pine Gap being a Defence Department project when it was actually a CIA project? Are we unconcerned by America's betrayal of that executive agreement? Does it not strike anyone here as sinister that Gough Whitlam was dismissed from office only hours before he was to expose in Parliament the role of the CIA at Pine Gap? Can Christopher Boyce be condemned for failing to honour his security agreement when a precedent for that had been blatantly set by the United States Government? What are we in this country going to do about Christopher Boyce? What are we going to do about a person who has shown what has been happening in the guise of secrecy, under the protection of an ally, in Australia? This is not a bash against the United States. This is a matter of fighting for Australia, for our own sovereignty, for our democracy. We sit in this House day after day under two Australian flags that hang above. Hour after hour we hear of abuses, of how Australia is not being properly treated, of how we must keep this, our flag, forever and so on. But what is the meaning of the flag if we cannot protect our own autonomy? That is the question that we have to face. The person who could be most incensed over this issue, Gough Whitlam, said in 1977-in this very House:

It is precisely because America is our principal ally that Australia must be satisfied that American agents are not acting in a manner contrary to our interests as a nation. Are we to let an ally get away with something that a rival would not be allowed to get away with? Alliances are not strengthened by covert operations or by condoning and covering up such covert operations.

Our dignity and self-respect as a nation, no less than our national security, demand that the Parliament exercise its supremacy in scrutinising the activities of foreign intelligence services operating in this country.

There is plenty of evidence available, Mr Deputy Speaker. We have seen the attention of the media of Australia and of both Houses of the Parliament focused on the three insignificant words `my little mate'. On the other hand, despite the fact that the evidence of external interference is so much greater, little attention is being paid to it.
Let me return, in the last few minutes left to me, to a description by Gough Whitlam in The Whitlam Government 1972-75 of a meeting held in Sydney. Mr Whitlam says:

I never met President Carter but I had a significant meeting with his Assistant Secretary of State for Asia in the South Pacific, Warren Christopher. On Wednesday, 27 July 1977 at 8 a.m. Alston arranged a breakfast meeting in the Qantas VIP room at Sydney Airport. Those present were Alston, Christopher, his aide, my aide, Richard Butler . . . and I.
He continues, speaking of Christopher:
He made it clear to us that he had made a special detour in his itinerary for the sole purpose of speaking to me. The President had asked him to say:
That he understood the Democrats and the ALP were fraternal parties;
That he respected deeply the democratic rights of the allies of the US;
I ask honourable members to note what he says next:
That the US administration would never again-
I repeat those words:
would never again interfere in the domestic political processes of Australia; and
That he would work with whatever government the people of Australia elected.
If our Bicentenary means anything--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am pleased to enter this debate.
—Order! I have not yet called the honourable member for Franklin. I now do so.

—I am always fast on my feet. Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. You know I can sing and now I am going to swing along with this speech, if you do not mind my saying so. I warned my four fellow Tasmanians when the dams debate was on that we had not heard the last of the people that were so involved-those who came to Tasmania and seemed to stir up all the trouble, those who came to Tasmania and distorted the facts, those who came to Tasmania in the hope that they could make it just a wilderness.
—I was one of them.

—I said that they were a formidable group that needed watching at every opportunity because they would just start there and go further and further and ring the bell, as the Minister at the table is trying to indicate, that they would fight every inch of the way to make Tasmania not just a beautiful island, but a wilderness, a plaything for the conservationists. They have certainly started on that footing again. My four colleagues and I did not have very much of an opportunity to talk about the timber industry, to say quite clearly to the conservationists: `Keep out of that industry'. They have done enough harm with the dams dispute. I would ask them to keep out of this one for goodness sake. In retrospect, we lost the other decision. It is water under the bridge but I am still bitter about the involvement of the Federal Government and particularly the High Court of Australia in it, because they won the day. I thought at the time that we did not fight hard enough but let me ask in retrospect: Where are all the jobs that were promised? I cannot see them. Where are all the jobs in the tourist industry that, according to the Wilderness Society, would be provided? Where are all the jobs that Bob Brown and Norm Sanders promised? They are not there. That is why we have lost so many good Tasmanians to the mainland. The jobs promised down there have not been provided.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, all of a sudden we see that lobby starting up again-very bitterly too, incidentally-to ruin the Tasmanian forest-based industries. They are going to fight hard and will fight dirty if they can, rest assured. They get on television. Let me say that the ABC and other sections of the media in Tasmania seem hell bent on giving Bob Brown and Norm Sanders every opportunity to put their point of view. What is being said is almost laughable, if honourable member do not mind my saying so. I read in the Hobart Mercury-and similar things are being said in every other newspaper in Tasmania, also on the ABC channel and TV6-`Federal grants to the forest group propaganda hit-Sanders says Hawke supports smear campaign'. I know where Mr Hawke stands on this issue and he is equivocating. I know where he stands. He is starting to say: `Look, we cannot win a seat in Tasmania so let us go out and fight in other States in Australia and try to harness the conservation vote because it may be beneficial at the next election'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got that right.

—I have got it absolutely right. But here we have Senator Sanders attacking Mr Hawke for funding a constructive program which indicates to the people of Australia and Tasmania that the forest industry is well organised, well maintained and in the best interests of the people of Tasmania. Let me give a few facts about that industry. The value to the Tasmanian economy in 1985 of all forest-based industries was approximately $230m. Direct employment in all forest-based industries totalled 8,000. Indirect employment totalled 20,000. Sixteen per cent of Tasmania is covered by national parks and State reserves. Only 0.4 per cent of State forest reserves is logged each year. So the position is being exaggerated. Already those people have about 30 per cent of Tasmania tied up, but they want that little bit extra. They want it for their plaything. They want it to be a wilderness. I hope that those who have had to leave Tasmania because of an inability to get jobs-and there are a lot listening today, rest assured-realise that a concerted effort is under way to save that very important industry for Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: The opponents of the industry, with their nice suits, their bright smiles and their ability to get on television at every opportunity, have a sinister thought in mind. They want to bring the Tasmanian forest-based industry to a standstill. They can pretend that they want this and that but, ultimately, what they want is what I have described. The same thing happened over the dams issue. A lot of rot on the part of the Wilderness Society went on down there. I refer to the rot that the wilderness would be harnessed so that people from all over the world could look at it. What a lot of rot! What about the men and women, the ordinary families of Tasmania, who are battling at the moment with high interest rates and petrol costs? They are just living from day to day. When some of those men who have bought trucks and tractors and are living on mortgaged properties, et cetera, find that they are going to be restricted once again, bitterness arises. That is one of my grievances and I know that the people of Tasmania will listen to what I have said. I plead with my four colleagues to consider that this is something that we need to fight on every inch of the way. I plead with them not to get involved in some of the rot that is going on in this Parliament at the moment. Our ultimate aim is to fight for Tasmania, to stay united, to keep away from the intrigue that goes on up here-leadership battles, character assassinations and all the personal stuff that occurs up here-and just fight for Tasmania and for what we believe in. That is one of my grievances.

My second grievance I have mentioned on many occasions. It is regrettable that one has to repeat what one has said so many times. It concerns the petroleum industry. The price of petrol in Hobart at the moment is 64c a litre, about 14c more than is the case in other capital cities of Australia. I know that Robin Gray had to add a 5c a litre impost to the price of petrol in Tasmania. I disagreed with that, but understood his reasons for doing so. I disagreed because the price of petrol at that time was already the highest in Australia. I realise that Mr Gray had to levy the additional 5c in order to make the State function, but even without it the price would have been about 9c higher than elsewhere. It would have been 10c a litre in excess of the Canberra price of about 52c a litre. Even if such a levy were imposed Canberra would still be 5c a litre better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —That impost was forced on Mr Gray by the Federal Government.

—Yes. The Prices Surveillance Authority, which we discussed yesterday-it is an arm of the Federal Government-needs to be looked at. It fixes a maximum wholesale price for petrol in every capital city. That price varies from oil company to oil company. The regrettable part about it is that the oil companies-honourable members know that I have no love for them because of what they have done to Tasmania-have a beautiful ability to drop below that wholesale price, to make it a fic- titious wholesale price. Thus, petrol may be obtained in Queensland, for example, for 32c, 36c or 40c a litre-the price varies from day to day and from State to State. When we see a fixed price of 64c a litre in Hobart it hits hard.
—What does it cost in the mainland States?

—It varies. I mentioned the other day to my colleague that there were people in Hobart, bitter people, who turn on one at the drop of a hat, saying: `Goodluck, you have spoken about petrol on thousands of occasions, but have not been able to get the price down'. That is the stupid rot that one has to contend with in this game. When one tries genuinely to tell people why petrol is so dear, one gets that sort of stuff pushed at one. I would mention to my colleague that in Jackeys Marsh we have a fight on our hands. You have done a good job down there.
—Order! The honourable member will address the Chair.

—I am sorry; he is better looking than you are! When I think about it, although we have the opportunity to get up in this House and speak about the problems of Tasmania we sometimes find that very difficult to do. I have said to my colleagues that we, as a Tasmanian group, need to fight for Tasmania; to get away from all the rot that goes on up here; to get away from character assassinations; to get away from personal recriminations and fight decently for what it is all about-fight hard and fast and get away from all this rot. I hope that the media take heed of what I am saying because I blame them for stirring up the possum at every opportunity. They will not report a decent speech, but if I came in here and threw a bit of mud-which I never do-they would report that in Tasmania. So I hope to God that they listen to this speech and will recognise that what I am saying is right and exact. I hope that the people of Tasmania will know that they have genuine members up here fighting for their causes-not just grandstanding like some that I could name but really thinking about their interests and hoping to make Tasmania a better place in which to live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, all my working life I have been a pay as you earn taxpayer and have paid my fair share of tax. For the last 20 years or so I have been gnashing my teeth with frustrated rage at government unwillingness or inability to establish a fair tax system. There are winners and there are losers in the tax game. The winners are those who are causing tax revenue to be eroded increasingly, to the tune of billions of dollars, through tax avoidance and evasion and the rorts of the corporate sector.
