The losers are the PAYE taxpayer and the poor. The ordinary PAYE taxpayer is a victim of all the tax rorts and rip-offs that certain taxpayer groups practice. While ever some people are allowed to pay less than their fair share of tax, the PAYE taxpayer will have to pay more than his or her fair share. The economic well-being of the poor is powerfully affected by an inequitable tax system that denies the Government money with which to improve their living standards. PAYE taxpayers and the poor must support this Government's attempt to bring justice and equity to the Australian taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, is vulnerable to the accusation that he is not fair dinkum. He opposes virtually everything that the Hawke Government does but offers no real alternatives. He tries to catch votes merely by exploiting discontent. Promises to abolish the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the assets test and the tax on superannuation lump sums might sound great to many people but from where will the money come? What would the Liberals, if they gained office, do to stop the tax avoidance that has occurred through fringe benefits? What would the Liberals do to raise the revenue that would be lost through the abolition of certain taxes? It would be impossible for the Leader of the Opposition to fulfil a commitment to reduce income tax and increase assistance to families if he should have the chance to abolish taxes geared to raising significant sums. It is important that voters realise that the Government will not keep one cent from the fringe benefits tax. Every cent collected will be paid back to taxpayers through lower tax rates which will be introduced on 1 December of this year and 1 July of 1987.

The majority of Australians are offended by taxation evasion and welfare fraud, which has the effect of increasing the taxation burden on honest Australians. The community has shown its overwhelming support for an Australia Card. No honest taxpayer has anything to fear from such a card which is the only effective way to stop taxation evasion and welfare fraud. Mr Howard and other Liberals originally implied support for the Australia Card. They recognised that the Australia Card would not infringe civil liberties. Now the Liberals have done a complete about-face on the issue. The electors of Hunter, as well as all other Australians, have good reason to be puzzled at a party which professes to be opposed to tax avoidance but rejects outright the fringe benefits tax and the Australia Card. The Liberals have no tax plan of their own and in rejecting the fair and equitable measures introduced by the Government are guilty of the most blatant and shameful political opportunism. The honest people of Australia want a tax system that is fair. They want to rid our tax and welfare systems of fraud and know that the best way to achieve this is by having an Australia Card.

The people of Australia are amazed at the remarkable about-face by the Opposition. They know that the Liberals and Nationals have all spoken in favour of an Australia Card. Why have the conservative members now changed their attitude? Honest people are stunned by this inexplicable change. The only people who are cheering the Opposition's about-face are the tax and welfare cheats. The Australian Taxation Office is not. It knows that it cannot do its job properly without an Australia Card. `To oppose the Australia Card is to put a fetter on tax collection' the Taxation Office says. This duplicitous Opposition has sought to exploit the infringement of civil liberties argument but is inconsistent and insincere. The Opposition cynically distorts the language of genuine civil libertarians. What it is claiming is that the citizen has a basic right to defraud the community. It is hollow rhetoric for the Opposition to say that it shares the community concern about tax evasion and social welfare fraud. The honest and innocent have nothing to fear from an Australia Card. The argument advanced about the infringement of civil liberties is a load of codswallop. Private legislation is to be introduced to underwrite the privacy protections that will be provided in the Government's legislation. Citizens need to be protected against the abuse of their privacy by government and that will be done but, equally, citizens need to be protected against others who cynically hide behind the mantle of privacy to create false identities and thus cheat honest citizens. Let us debunk once and for all this infringement of privacy nonsense.

The Australia Card will contain no more than the following: A name, a photograph, a signature, an identifying number and an expiry date; nothing more. Is this an invasion of privacy? Will this terrify honest Australians? The Opposition has once again donned a monster mask in a bid to scare the pants off voters. And who can be heard laughing at their scare tactics? Are all those American Express, Visa and Bankcard holders, and the thousands of other Australians who hold credit or ID cards, scared? They are laughing at the puerile arguments that have been put forward by the Liberals. Many honourable members opposite are feeling a little embarrassed by the stance that they have been forced to adopt. They are wearing sheepish grins. Today, three members of the Opposition showed me plastic ID cards that they carry. It is interesting to note that the Press editorials have condemned the about-face by the Opposition. The Canberra Times had a particularly interesting comment:
The Liberals showed opportunism by opposing the introduction of the Australia Card.
They present a weak case against the Card. Their opposition is hard to fathom.
The Government is well aware that opinion polls indicate that the card has strong public support. The Canberra Times comment continued:
The Liberal case against it is weak, being based on the need to employ more public servants and the assertion that the card assumes that all taxpayers are cheats.
However, the need to employ extra staff does not mean the card is not cost-effective; the staff are essential to get the benefits from the system.

The Canberra Times knows, as does everyone else, that the cost of introducing the Australia Card is a mere fraction of the revenue that it will earn. It will cost the Government $759m in the first 10 years but will raise over the same period $4.7 billion. That figure is worthy of repetition-$4.7 billion. How will that sum be used? The $4.7 billion will be used to reduce tax levels or provide extra services. That is what all honest Australians want. They want lower taxes and better services. The average Australian does not want what the Liberals and Nationals appear to want-the continued protection of welfare and tax cheats.

An extraordinary thing happened in my electoral office on the day that the conservatives made known their opposition to the Australia Card. There were many incoming phone calls, but an oddity was that three callers, two women and one male, refused to give their names. Their reason for adopting the cloak of anonymity was that they were Liberal voters. They had rung merely to express horror and anger that their political party sought to protect tax and welfare cheats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, today I want to raise by way of proper grievance the question of the Australian War Memorial and several outstanding issues relating thereto. On 22 December 1984, a Vietnam veteran was married in the Australian War Memorial. Approval for this was granted directly and indirectly at various levels. I make no comment at this stage on the rightfulness or, more particularly, wrongfulness of a wedding take place at the Australian War Memorial because I want to concentrate on the aspect relating directly to the Minister. On 19 November 1986, yesterday, in the Senate, when the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) was questioned about the wedding, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am absolutely astounded and shocked at any suggestion that a civil wedding has been held at the Australian War Memorial . . .
If the assertions are true, I certainly give Senator Tate an assurance that I will immediately seek an explanation from staff of the Australian War Memorial . . .
Therefore, to suggest that there has been a civil wedding ceremony at the War Memorial defies imagination. I am absolutely appalled at that suggestion.

I can now tell the House that at least 48 hours before the wedding took place the Minister for Veterans' Affairs knew about the wedding. This happened when the Minister attended a Christmas party at the Australian War Memorial in the week leading up to the wedding, during which he was introduced to the bridegroom in his capacity as an employee of the Australian War Memorial. The Director of the Australian War Memorial during the function-I am advised well within ear-shot of the Minister even allowing for difficult acoustics-stated clearly that the Vietnam veteran was being married on the next Saturday, 22 December 1984, at the Australian War Memorial and that everyone would wish him well, or words to that effect. Perhaps I should add that this information has come from a very reliable source, but not from the Director, Air Vice-Marshal Jim Flemming, or the Chairman of the Council of the Australian War Memorial. I should say that I have not spoken to either of these people since the Battle of Britain observance ceremony on Monday, 15 September last, and deliberately so for obvious reasons.

Returning to the issue of the wedding, it is now clear that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is guilty, once again, of grossly misleading the Senate. Should the Minister in Question Time this afternoon plead some excuse in relation to selective memory, he will do so at great risk because a full and open inquiry will bring out a great deal about all aspects of the complex issues relating to the War Memorial. Not only did the Minister know about the wedding at least 48 hours before it took place at the Australian War Memorial. He was in a position to take immediate action to stop the ceremony being held at the Australian War Memorial, an event which he now describes as having defiled the very sacredness of the portion of the Australian War Memorial that was utilised. Indeed the Minister, albeit a new Minister at that time, with responsibility for the War Memorial, is a former soldier who failed to act in the time available on a matter which he now complains about. It is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs who must accept responsibility for the wedding having taken place at the Australian War Memorial and he stands condemned by his own actions and words yesterday.

Mr Deputy Speaker, four issues relating to the Australian War Memorial should be dealt with by the Parliament and the Government before this Parliament rises next week. I wish to continue remarks that I attempted to make at an earlier stage on another motion before the House and to do so by way of further proper grievance. Firstly, there is the issue relating to the Minister and the Australian War Memorial, his politicisation of the War Memorial and the Council.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat for a moment. I remind him that standing order 75 provides:

INTERJECT.PARA: No member may use offensive words against either House of Parliament or any Member thereof, against any member of the Judiciary . . .
I just remind the honourable member so that he will not trangress the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am well aware of that standing order and wish merely to focus the attention of the House on four broad issues associated with the War Memorial. The first is the Minister's role in relation to the War Memorial and the politicisation that is threatening its independence. I could do no better than quote very briefly the remarks of a former Labor South Australian Premier who had been a member of the Council of the War Memorial:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has been constantly interfering in the Council for a long period of time, and I guess that's had its effect in their having overlooked that the Director is entitled to a fair go and natural justice.

The first issue, then, is the Minister's role. The second relates to the Director and the Australian War Memorial, and one should recall that in the Ken Jones report there was a finding of no misbehaviour under the fundamental section of the Act. I make no further comment on that, other than to say that the Director is entitled to natural justice. He is entitled to be present at an inquiry where evidence is given against him. That submission was made by the solicitors for the Council of the Australian War Memorial, but that privilege was not extended to him during the Ken Jones inquiry. The third issue relates to certain other staff at the War Memorial. This was raised by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) and I will not dwell on it. The fourth relates to the modus operandi of the Council of the War Memorial, which is now centre stage in the whole saga which has arisen. I want to say that the Opposition, the Liberal and National parties, has been very patient and careful not to politicise what is a very sacred institution. For example, we waited some five days following the presentation of the Ken Jones report before proposing any motion in either House in relation to the War Memorial issue, then proposed in the Senate a very carefully worded motion which gave the Government a choice of options. It was carried by the Senate.

The War Memorial situation is now out of control. The Government has questions to answer. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has very serious questions to answer in the interests of the veterans' community across Australia, those who served their country in time of war. Those questions should be answered before the Parliament rises for the summer recess. The Government has before it certain options, certain alternatives. We understand that the Cabinet has been looking at those options and alternatives for at least 48 hours; that the matter has now been deferred until next week. So the saga at the other end of Canberra, at the War Memorial, is to continue for at least another three or four days until we see what the Cabinet might do. I appeal to the Government, to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Minister at the table here in the lower House, to consider very carefully all the issues in relation to the Australian War Memorial and, if the fundamental finding of the Ken Jones inquiry is not accepted, to proceed with a further full and open inquiry utilising the proper rules of evidence and cross-examination procedures which would then be available.

May I remind the House of words that were uttered by a great former Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Ben Chifley. When speaking in relation to repatriation matters, veterans and those who had served their country in time of war, he told the House: `Upon this Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done.' I believe they are most relevant words. The ultimate responsibility rests with this Parliament. It is tragic that the situation has reached the stage where unfortunately, due to the inaction and wrong action of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, it has, sadly, become centre stage to some extent in the lower House and certainly centre stage in the Senate. That is very regrettable. I will not resile from my duties as shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs to see that the right thing is done by the Australian War Memorial; that the independence of the Australian War Memorial is retained; that there is accuracy in the comments by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and that he will be forced to own up to misleading the Senate in relation to the wedding ceremony of which he spoke at length yesterday-one that he knew 48 hours beforehand was to take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should withdraw the accusation that the Minister misled the Senate. Such allegations may only be made by way of substantive motion. As I was taking the chair, I believe that I heard the honourable member say that the Minister had misled the Senate. One cannot seek, other than by way of a substantive motion, to accuse a Minister of misleading the Parliament. The honourable member should withdraw.
—I think, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the facts speak for themselves but if you wish me to withdraw I so do.
—The honourable member should withdraw unqualifiedly.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, are you asking me to withdraw?
—Yes.
—I withdraw.
—I thank the honourable member and ask him to resume his seat. His time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish by way of the grievance debate to bring to the attention of the House a visit that I made earlier this year to Iraq and other countries of the Middle East. I visited Iraq in January or February of this year. My major motivation in travelling to Iraq was to investigate the treatment of Iranian prisoners of war. Also, the alleged use of chemical weapons by Iraq in the Gulf war was a matter of public concern at that time. There are many complexities which one could address in the context of a grievance debate but obviously with the very limited time available it is not an appropriate occasion to do that. I would like to make just a few brief general comments and then deal with some specific areas where Australia's interests are certainly intrinsically involved. Obviously, the Gulf war between Iraq and Iran has much greater implications than simply the effect on those two warring nations and the matters that I wish to address are obviously more on the micro level of humanitarian issues insofar as they affect the treatment of prisoners and the use of chemical weapons. But it is worth making the point that because of the Gulf states' oil reserves and their geostrategic location, Australia is not immune to any cataclysmic result from the current dispute between these countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The war has now been ongoing for something like six years. That is unique in Third World countries where one is not looking at wars of national liberation or wars that could be described, if one likes, as civil wars. It has gone on for a very long time at an enormous cost in human and capital terms. Obviously the region because of its oil reserves is particularly sensitive. It has, as I understand it, some 55 per cent of world reserves and in a post-oil glut context the importance of the region will reassert itself. Obviously, the petro-dollars derived from the sale of oil by not only the two protagonists but also the other Gulf states have been intrinsically responsible for the ability of the participants to continue fighting. I refer both to the direct income derived from the sale of their own oil-though that has been severely circumscribed as a result of the war-and, importantly, to that received from other countries in the region. The massive contemporary drop in oil prices will obviously have a severe impact on both protagonists' ability to continue the war. Hence there may be some light at the end of the tunnel in that context.

The Gulf war is almost ignored in the Western media. It is interesting to note that we have people who are prepared to vote with their feet on Sundays and be intrinsically involved in various peace movements but never really give any consideration to this most horrendous of contemporary conflicts. It is important to realise that Iraq has a population similar, if one likes, to that of Australia. Its losses have been absolutely enormous. That situation is reflected even more so-although less as I understand it in percentage terms-by the Iranian losses. I think that when we look at this situation it is worth recalling that in the First World War Australia suffered per capita the highest number of allied casualties in that war.

TALK.START.PARA: —After New Zealand.

—Perhaps I should have said, more accurately, that in World War I the Anzac forces suffered more casualties per capita than did any other allied country involved; that it took us many generations to get over that massive loss of what has accurately been described as the flower of our youth. I simply raise that to try to bring to the attention of the Australian people the fact that we simply cannot ignore the barbaric conflict that is occurring in the Gulf. Apart from the humanitarian aspects, Australia's vital security interests may very well be affected by an unpredictable outcome especially, as I have indicated, in a post-oil glut environment. That may, hopefully, be of import to some.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently there have been a number of moves that tend to belie the stalemate view of the war. I refer, for example, to the slight change in emphasis by Syria towards its long time protagonist Iraq and the highly publicised moves by the United States of America Administration to open a dialogue by way of what is possibly an extra-constitutional and on the surface quite crazy method of supplying arms to the Khomeini regime. I wish simply to place on record my view that whilst I am uncomfortable with that initiative, as I believe most people in Australia would be, it is also important to acknowledge that any conclusion to the Iran-Iraq war will have as a necessary precondition an involvement by the United States Administration and, to the extent that this exercise was allegedly designed to open up a dialogue with moderates within the Iranian regime, it ought not to be cursorily dismissed as necessarily, on all views, a bad initiative.

Australia's role, as has been indicated in this House by my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), is one of strict neutrality. We have sought, by a number of initiatives of our own volition, and by supporting other initiatives, in the United Nations in particular, to bring about a ceasefire without preconditions, which hopefully would lead to a comprehensive settlement. Australia's representative, as President of the United Nations Security Council, pushed through in February 1986 UN initiative 582. Of course, it was opposed by Iran and accordingly was not successful. As recently as October 1986, last month, an Arab-sponsored initiative was again attempted in the United Nations but unfortunately, yet again, Iran refused to co-operate. Our most recent representations in both Baghdad and Tehran, made in May of this year, related to the attempted protection of merchant shipping through the Gulf area. We have, over a long period, taken a very high profile on issues such as the use of chemical weapons and the treatment of prisoners of war. In my experience, the Iraqi Government was prepared to allow the International Committee of the Red Cross people access to its prisoner of war camps. It certainly gave me the opportunity to visit any camps that I was aware of and assured me that they were the only camps that were currently being used. I cannot make a judgment on that but can say that to the extent that there is International Committee of the Red Cross access to Iraqi prisoners of war, unlike the situation transpiring in Iran, to a limited extent at least we ought to acknowledge the Iraqi bona fides in that context. Currently very sensitive negotiations are going on between the International Committee of the Red Cross and the Khomeini regime. It is my fervent hope, one that I am sure would be shared by all honourable members of this House, that in the near future that type of humanitarian access can in fact be provided. There are those in Iraq, for instance, who have been unaware of the situation of their relatives-in fact whether they were dead or alive-over the period of six years. In that way some of the humanitarian issues can be addressed. The Australian Government has, of course, censured again and again Iraq's use of chemical weapons and I certainly do not resile from that. Once again, I think that would receive bipartisan support in this House.

In the short time remaining to me I wish to make the following points: Iraq sought on 2 August of this year a settlement, by way of a five-point plan, to end the war. Once again the initiative was rejected by Iran. Iran has consistently rejected mediation efforts until its basic demands have been met. Of course, those basic demands include large cash war reparations and the dissolution of the Iraqi-Ba'ath Socialist Party regime and its replacement by a popular democratic government. Unless Iran reverses that policy there is, of course, little hope for sufficient common ground being found between the two protagonists and that is a necessary precondition for a negotiated settlement. I conclude by putting the view here, as I have elsewhere, that it is unacceptable in any civilised country not to take every possible step and exert every possible pressure on the protagonists to protect the interests of not only Iraqi but also Iranian youth, who have been lost in their tens or thousands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In one of his columns in the London Times a few weeks ago, Bernard Levin wrote, as he has done before, about the Soviet attempt to destroy, as a deliberate policy, Jewish culture in the Soviet Union. He surveyed the familiar situation: Two million Jews in the Soviet Union but no Jewish schools anywhere; no Jewish education; no teaching of Yiddish except in the fraudulent homeland, Birobidzhan; no teaching of Hebrew except in three academic institutions from which Jews are excluded and the cruel repression of private teaching of Hebrew; no books published in Hebrew and only a handful in Yiddish with small print runs; no Jewish theatre; no Jewish art gallery and so on and on. But Levin goes to to point out in his column that this persecution, this attempt to crush the cultural identity of Soviet Jews out of existence, has had an effect opposite to that intended and there has been a further revival of Jewish culture, despite further persecution and repression.

SPEECH.PARA: Levin ends his column by comparing and contrasting Soviet and nazi anti-semitism. However similar, there is a difference. Hitler wanted to kill Jews but the same motives are not at work in the Soviet leaders. Despite this contrast the Soviet leaders appear to be, Levin thinks, as mad as Hitler. I quote him:

For consider, here is a minority whom they hate who cause them more and more trouble, whose plight attracts opprobrium from abroad and whose only wish is to shake the dust of the Soviet Union of their feet. Then why not let them go?

I think we can attempt an answer to Bernard Levin's anguished and baffled question, `Why not let them go?', and it is an answer that does not encourage easy optimism. It appears that there are two schools of thought, to call them that, on the issue in the Soviet Union. The first says, `Let them go. Get rid of them', as they let 250,000 Jews go in the 1970s. The second says, `Caution. Letting them go will cause all sorts of serious internal problems', and it is this second school of thought which has the upper hand at the moment.

Their fears seem to be these: Firstly, the Kremlin's claim to legitimacy rests on the legend that life in the Soviet Union is better than that in the materialist, racist, immoral and neo-fascist West, real news of which it keeps to a minimum by censorship of publications, jamming of broadcasts and controls of communications. An emigration movement naturally challenges the Soviet legend and if successful would, since emigrants would stay in touch with their families still in the Soviet Union, open another line of real news about the West. It is a threat to the system.

Secondly, the Jewish emigration movement challenges another basic legend of Soviet policy-its nationality policy that ultimately all of the hundred nationalities of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics will abandon their identities and merge together in a uniform Soviet nationality. The refuseniks and Jewish emigrants reject this totally and if they succeed, what effect will this have on other nationalities, the Armenian or Soviet Germans, for example, but not only those who, after all, have friends abroad? Will not these other nationalities be encouraged to assert themselves against the Soviet goal of the suppression of nationality?

Thirdly, a Jewish emigration on the scale of the 1970s would now, unlike then, involve the threat of a Soviet brain drain. The vast bulk of the Jews still in the Soviet Union now live in Moscow, Leningrad, Kiev and Minsk and, despite persecution and increasing exclusion from higher education institutions, are still a disproportionate percentage of the more advanced sectors of Soviet society. While they are only about two-thirds of one per cent of the Soviet population, they are about 14 per cent of all leading scientists; that is, with qualifications above a PhD. Given the demands of Soviet military forces for technology, the threat of the loss of professionals like these is regarded seriously.

Fourthly, there is this consideration: Increasingly the Jews who would emigrate, if they could, would settle or want to settle in the United States; perhaps most of them would. This is a prospect that the Soviet authorities cannot tolerate. The Jewish emigrants of the 1970s were a different matter. Most of them were not, as they are called, `heartland' Jews. When 60 per cent of the Jewish population of Georgia emigrated, usually to Israel, they could be dismissed as the remnants of a reactionary nationalism and a doomed religiosity who deserve their fate in the `racist, militarist, genocidal Israel'.

When half of the Jews in Lithuania and more than one-third of the Jews in Latvia emigrated, they could also be dismissed as a dying breed of unassimilated bourgeois reactionaries. But when tens of thousands of well-educated Russian-speaking `assimilated' Jews from the Slavic republics want to emigrate and opt for the heartland of world capitalism, that is a blow to the lie, to the Soviet legends, which is grave indeed.

So it is for these internal or domestic considerations that the Soviets have maintained their no-exit policy, combined recently with a slight relaxation of anti-Jewish measures and a new apparent willingness to discuss the problem, and to explain how happy and privileged Soviet Jews really are. That is the line we have seen this year coming out of the Soviet Embassy in Canberra.

If this approach is correct, the prospects are not encouraging. The emigration movement is essentially a subversive movement. There will be some concessions by the Soviets, especially in the cases of family reunion. These should not be underestimated. They are thrilling and heart warming to the individuals involved. Madam Speaker, Mrs Child, has won our thanks and congratulations for what she has achieved in this field recently, but unhappily it is a drop in the ocean.

There will be other cases of concessions. Yelena Bonner was permitted to visit the United States. She wisely refused to submit to Soviet surgery and she is now back in exile in Gorky. There is the great example of Anatoly Shcharansky. Clearly, these and others are isolated cases and do not represent a change in basic policy.

What then is to be done? On the sort of view I have taken, there is a limit to what can be achieved by quiet diplomacy, as it is called. Quiet diplomacy does have its successes, of course; sometimes with individual Jews in the Soviet Union, as sometimes with American or French hostages in Lebanon. But if I am anywhere near right, and it would be good if I were wrong, quiet diplomacy alone will not release the hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews who want to emigrate because a no-exit policy is not based on foreign policy considerations which may be completely overcome by trade or technology deals or other foreign policy measures.

It is based on domestic policies, on the basic need to protect the legends or lies on which the Soviet Union is built. If this is right, the only hope must lie in a change in those domestic policies, in some sort of reform in the Soviet Union along the lines advocated by the dissidents. I do not see how the right to emigrate can be accepted by the Soviets without many other changes in Soviet domestic policy; without, that is, undermining the totalitarian structure. In other words, I think those in the nomenklatura who advocate caution and no-exit by emigration are right in their own terms to be cautious about this subversive movement.

Many will quickly say that this is the same as admitting that there is no hope at all, but I believe there is some basis in the hope for change and the question is: What can we do to help it along? I am not talking about revolution in the Soviet Union or the sudden establishment of liberal democracy, but only of the success, even limited success, of those dissident movements which are working for the abandonment of the attempt to merge all the nationalities into one synthetic Soviet nation; for greater scope for private enterprise such as we see in Hungary; for a genuine permanent thaw in cultural life; and for the rule of law and the right to emigrate.

All such moves will be resisted by the nomenklatura and it may succeed again in supressing reform as it has done in the past, but if the Soviet economy continues to fail, as it surely will, and if the various dissident movements-political, cultural, religious, ethnic and economic-persist, and if the West and its allies maintain a strong defence policy that precludes any easy pluckings abroad by the Soviets, then there is that basis for cautious optimism.

It also follows, if this approach is right, that the most promising policy for us outside the Soviet Union to adopt, on the issue of Jewish emigration, is sustained international pressure on the nomenklatura for the recognition of human rights, not only of Jews but of all Soviet citizens, and in support of the dissidents, Jewish and non-Jewish.

At the right moment quiet diplomacy will play its role, but as Shcharansky told us last May, no amount of diplomacy will help unless the key element is there first; that is, strong public pressure from within the Soviet Union and from abroad.
The sub-title, Mr Deputy Speaker, of Martin Gilbert's recent biography of Shcharansky, is Hero of our Time. It is surely a correct sub-title and surely we should listen to this great man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March 1984 I raised in the House a matter concerning a constituent of mine, Ms Maureen Rees, who is an intellectually disabled pensioner and who was supported by the Ferntree Gully and Districts Welfare Association for the Intellectually Handicapped. The matter involved a transfer of title, of land, including a partly completed restaurant from the welfare association to a company, namely, Basilthon Nominees Pty Ltd, for $213,000 on 5 December 1977. Subsequently, in February 1979, just fourteen months later, Basilthon Nominees went into liquidation with the site and premises then being valued at $1,750,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Frank Rees and Mr Trevor Rees, brothers of Maureen Rees, and at that time constituents of mine, alleged that fraud had taken place in relation to the property transfer transactions and related business arrangements which occurred between 1971 and 1979, and asked me in April 1982 to seek information on those transactions on their behalf as they had been unsuccessful in obtaining the necessary information themselves. I, too, was unsuccessful and hence my previous Grievance Debate speech. Since that time more information has come to light which I wish to bring to the attention of the House in the hope that members of the Victorian Government might be persuaded by their Federal ministerial colleagues that there is a case to answer.

However, before I proceed I would like to make it very clear that my investigation of the case is in no way to be seen as a reflection upon the integrity of the present members of the committee of management of the association. I understand that my previous speech was seen as a criticism of the administration of the Ferntree Gully and Districts Welfare Association for the Intellectually Handicapped and I can only say that my speech was regretfully misinterpreted by some people. I have visited the Knoxbrooke training centre on several occasions and have been impressed by the dedicated work provided by all those who are involved with the services provided by the centre.

My sole purpose in pursuing the request for information by the Rees brothers is to seek out the facts behind the sale in 1977 of the property rights to the Swagman restaurant. Since I began my original inquiry in 1982, I am glad to say that the Victorian Labor Government has legislated to ensure that the rights of intellectually handicapped people are fully protected, as had been requested by the Rees brothers when they began their original investigations.

The property transactions which took place between 1971 and 1979 could not have occurred had the current legislation been in force at that time. The Victorian Labor Government must be commended on passing legislation which is protecting the interests of intellectually disadvantaged Victorians. Regretfully, such legislation was not in place for the period 1971 to 1977 when the property transactions in which the Ferntree Gully and Districts Welfare Association was the initial freehold owner took place.

At the conclusion of my previous speech, I drew attention to a number of matters of contention which I considered must be resolved before the case was settled to my satisfaction. For the record, I should point out that on 29 May 1984 I received a reply from the then Victorian Minister for Health, Mr Tom Roper, which concluded:

The sale of land by the association to Basilthon Nominees Pty Ltd has been the subject of litigation and numerous investigations, the most extensive having been conducted by the Victorian Ombudsman. These inquiries have failed to show any irregularity in the sale of the site now occupied by the Swagman restaurant.

In respect of this letter, Madam Speaker, I have to say that apart from the fact that no litigation was involved, I am not convinced that the Ombudsman dealt with all the business transactions involved and subsequently additional information has been uncovered. It has been ascertained that the original leaseholders and proprietors of the Swagman restaurant, the de Jong family, ran a business association with Kevin James O'Brien, a man who was behind a number of tax avoidance schemes in the 1970s. Both Basil de Jong and Kevin James O'Brien were involved in proceedings in the courts as a result of illegal transactions.

Basil de Jong and Kevin O'Brien formed a group of interlocking companies, namely, Basilthon Constructions Pty Ltd, Basilthon Finances Pty Ltd, Basilthon Nominees Pty Ltd, Aquaglen Pty Ltd, PIB Investments, Basilthon Unit Trust and Basilthon Finance Settlement. There were also two additional companies which were involved, namely, Downvale Pty Ltd and Kevin James O'Brien Specialised Computing and Accounting Services Pty Ltd.

The whole purpose of this contrived web of companies was to circumvent the foreign exchange and tax regulations of Australia by establishing an overseas company to act as an intermediary for the receipt of capital profits from Australia. Aquaglen was the overseas company based in London through which the Basilthon companies channelled their profits. Aquaglen then passed the funds back to Basilthon Finance Settlement in Australia, free of exchange controls and taxation liability. Of course, the whole scheme was probably more complicated than I have described, but honourable members will be familiar with the devious and immoral nature of tax avoidance schemes of this type.

At one stage, the Victorian Public Trustee assisted in negotiating a $1m mortgage of the Swagman restaurant, the money being provided by the Metropolitan Fire Brigade Superannuation Board to Downvale Pty Ltd, one of the O'Brien companies. As I mentioned before, some of the people involved in this venture, no doubt unwittingly, have protested to both the Rees brothers and me because we have been pursuing the issue. It has even been suggested that my involvement in the case could do me electoral harm. I want to make it very clear that in my view the Rees brothers have done the community a service in their relentless pursuit of the facts. I have no doubt that this case has assisted in ensuring that the rights of intellectually disabled people are now protected by the legislature.

However, apart from the matters of individual and community trust, there is a need to expose the excessive secretiveness of so much of Australian society. The operations of government, business and our security forces would be vastly improved if there were less secrecy. The whole purpose of the freedom of information legislation, at both Federal and State level, was to encourage a more open society. Yet, in the present case the various authorities concerned have refused to reveal vital information. It has only been the persistence of Frank and Trevor Rees, acting on behalf of their sister Maureen and all intellectually disadvantaged people, which has managed to provide the present background of facts.

There remain a number of facts which have yet to be revealed. I do not have time, unfortunately, to refer to them all. But, first of all, why was the land in question valued at site value only for the purposes of sale by the welfare association and why did it not include the buildings comprising the Swagman restaurant? If the restaurant premises had been included, there would have been far less of a price gulf between the sale proceeds of $213,000 received by the Association and the sale price 14 months later of some $1.75m, which was eventually pocketed by de Jong and O'Brien.

Secondly, in view of apparent conflicting evidence in respect of the dates of all the property transactions relating to the land and premises comprising the Swagman restaurant, the precise dates need to be included and the date of the first transfer of the land from the Knox City Council ascertained and authenticated. In this respect, a copy of the Welfare Association's resolution authorising the sale of the property could help to throw light on the issue.

Thirdly, in view of the strong evidence of criminal intent, why is it not possible for the Federal and State police authorities to collaborate in investigating the web of financial and business dealings behind the Basilthon group of companies?

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health.
—You asked it yesterday.

—Well, it is a tax and identification question, but the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer cannot answer, so I am going to try the Minister for Health now. If, as the Government claims, the major area of tax evasion impacted by the identity card is non-declared interest, how does he justify the introduction of the card when the Government currently does not require the Reserve Bank to provide to the Australian Taxation Office details of those who purchase and earn interest on the $50 billion invested in Commonwealth bonds?

—The Government has never said that the major area in relation to tax evasion is undeclared interest. It is, of course, one of the areas which the card is aimed at. A second point of the whole legislation, as the honourable member knows and as he has often criticised, is that we are trying to improve the reporting processes right across the tax area and in fact to make those reporting practices much more effective by tying them to a real identity. I would have thought that in many ways the basis of the question shows that the honourable member appreciates some of the real problems that government faces. I would have hoped that, recognising and looking at these problems of reporting and of reporting in relation to effective identities, we would get some real and constructive proposals out of the Opposition rather than the kind of negative attitude to these proposals we have had throughout the week.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the effect on a worker on average earnings of the Government's tax cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is increasingly recognised, the sweeping tax reforms that this Government has introduced will produce a fairer and certainly more efficient taxation system and those reforms will generate about $1.5 billion of the $4.5 billion that we will be returning to the taxpayers of this country by way of tax cuts. After two rounds of tax cuts, that is, on 1 December of this year and in the middle of next year, a worker on average earnings will get tax relief of about $12 a week or $10 a week net of the Medicare levy. Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition, in yet another demonstration of his abandonment of principle, sought to suggest that these tax cuts were not real and he boasts that the income tax burden for people on average earnings was lower when he left office in March 1983, but of course any rational analysis of the situation shows that the Leader of the Opposition should be ashamed of his fiscal legacy and certainly not proud of it. There was, of course, nothing in the last Howard Budget of 1982 that would have prevented a worker on average earnings entered the 46c in the dollar bracket.

ANSWER.PARA: As I suggested yesterday, if this Government were as irresponsible as the previous Government under the treasurership of the present Leader of the Opposition it is quite clear that we could provide further huge tax cuts to the people of this country by blowing out the deficit to the same proportions as did the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer. It would be quite simple. In fact, if we wanted to accept the policies of the then Treasurer we could further reduce the marginal rate for a worker on average earnings from 40 per cent to 30 per cent and we could provide further tax cuts of another $20 a week, in addition to the $12 a week we are providing. If we were to do that, if we were to blow the deficit out to the proportions that the Leader of the Opposition did, we would be guilty of the same gross economic irresponsibility as the Leader of the Opposition and we would produce the sorts of interest rates which the Leader of the Opposition delivered. Do honourable members remember what they were? Ninety-day bank bills hit 22 per cent while the dole queues rose by a quarter of a million and inflation hit 11 1/2 per cent. The Leader of the Opposition might have treated the people of Australia like fools in his last Budget and he may be trying to treat them like fools now but he did not get away with it then and he is certainly not getting away with it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his celebrated promise of 20 November 1984 when he assured the Australian people that they would reap the rewards of lower interest rates as a result of the policies of his Government. As today marks the unhappy second anniversary of that promise, will the Prime Minister explain how Australians have been rewarded when home loan interest rates are the highest ever, average home loan repayments have risen by over $150 a month, credit card interest rates such as Bankcard have risen from 18 per cent to as much as 22 1/2 per cent, prime lending rates have risen from 13 1/2 per cent to 18 1/2 per cent, small overdraft rates have risen from 14 1/2 per cent to 20 1/2 per cent and Australia's general interest rate structure has risen substantially? In the light of the Prime Minister's appalling record of keeping his promise on interest rates, what status should any Australian give to the assurances he made in the House yesterday that interest rates would fall in 1987?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated in the answer that I have just given that interest rates in relevant areas rose to their highest levels at the time when the current Leader of the Opposition was in fact Treasurer. It is universally acknowledged, except in the myopic mind of the Leader of the Opposition, that the conditions that were imposed upon Australia by the massive decline in terms of trade, imposed a requirement upon any government concerned with responsible economic management to have a monetary policy and an interest rate regime of the order that operated in this year. That was a requirement, a necessity, imposed upon us by the circumstances of the decline in the terms of trade. We had to do those things. No government likes having a monetary policy or an interest rate regime which has the sorts of interest rate figures which have been referred to, but as distinct from the Leader of the Opposition when in government-he refused to take the basic economic decisions in regard to the exchange rate and in regard to wages policy which were necessary to protect the interests of this country-this Government has consistently refused to take the easy way out. We are concerned with the long haul, with getting the fundamentals right, and in that process a monetary policy and an interest rate regime of the order that has been indicated have been necessary to protect the fundamental interests of this country. Having said that, it is undeniable that Government policy is creating conditions which will allow interest rates in time to decline.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us go to the fundamentals. We have brought in in 1986-87 a Budget deficit of 1.4 per cent as a proportion of gross domestic product. What was it that we inherited from our predecessors? It was 5 per cent. That is what the deficit was as a proportion of GDP and we have consistently brought that down. The fact that we have the courage to do that and to take the hard decisions is one of the necessary conditions for having optimism about the decline in interest rates.

Wages and monetary policies will progressively remove the depreciation-induced acceleration in our inflation rate. As that occurs, it will enable nominal interest rates to decline in line with inflationary expectations. We can already see greater confidence in the financial markets, reflected in a significant rise in the exchange rate and in a decline in professional interest rates, despite substantial sales of the Australian dollar by the Reserve Bank of Australia. In these circumstances, of course, we are not prepared to speculate on when these declines may occur, especially in terms of mortgage rates, because anyone who knows the beginnings of the complexities of this situation will realise that there are a whole host of factors that will impinge on this. Those factors include international financial conditions, shifts in commodity prices, expectations of developments in world monetary and commodity markets and the pace at which the expected progressive improvement in our current account occurs. All those factors will, in their various ways, impact upon the movements in interest rates.

The point I make is that this Government-as distinct from our predecessor, where the responsibility for economic management was with the Treasurer-has been prepared to show the guts and courage to take the tough decisions. Those decisions are concerned with getting the fundamentals right so that the long term future of this country will be secure. We eschew the opportunism which the former Treasurer showed when he was in government and the cynicism and expediency which he consistently demonstrates in opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs been drawn to the death from petrol sniffing of a teenage Aboriginal boy and to the high number of Aboriginal youths from the north-west of South Australia who are presently in hospital as a result of petrol sniffing? What is the Government doing to combat this tragic problem in Aboriginal communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question and for his continuing concern in bringing this problem to the attention of me and my Department. Aboriginal Ministers, both State and Federal, have been concerned to deal with this problem. It has been the subject of communication and discussions between us, as it has been between Ministers for Health. It is not a simple problem, nor does it provide for simple or easy answers. Unfortunately, in a number of Aboriginal communities petrol sniffing is not merely a problem, it is a problem which in the final analysis can be dealt with only by the communities themselves. At some stage someone has to put out his or her hand and take away the can from the petrol sniffer. Unlike problems of drug addiction in the non-Aboriginal community, this problem is a fairly public problem.

ANSWER.PARA: At this stage both my Department and State Ministers are working through a variety of what can only be described as experiments which are designed to tackle and defeat this problem. In conjunction with the Northern Territory Government we have funded a team, known as the Franks team, which comprises two non-Aboriginal people with backgrounds in drug rehabilitation. They are working with traditional Aboriginal people; they go into the communities and involve them in discussion. That discussion provokes movement, concern and a decision, so that the decision to deal with the problem is an Aboriginal-based decision. That is a relatively low cost program and it has shown effective results in the Northern Territory.

In the honourable member's electorate and other areas of South Australia we have no less than four projects operating in conjunction with the South Australian Government under which funding is shared. The problem there is in some ways more acute. The honourable gentleman will be aware of a request by an Aboriginal health structure for funding of $1m to deal with this problem. We have not responded to that request because we do not believe that we can solve this problem simply by putting sums such as $1m into a health service which already has funding of $3m and has the capacity to deal with that problem. Basically, the solution seems to lie in involving the Aboriginal communities themselves and using and reinforcing the authority that exists within communities to deal with this very acute problem. It also involves follow-up programs, particularly when young people are off petrol sniffing, to provide a range of alternative activities, in terms of recreation and other sorts of structures, which will not merely keep the community clean but also enable those young people to lead a normal and balanced life.

This is a very serious problem. It has recently been the subject of discussion by Commonwealth and State Health Ministers and there will be follow-up action by Commonwealth and State Health Ministers and Commonwealth and State Aboriginal Ministers. The matter is certainly receiving a great deal of attention in terms of Commonwealth-State relations. I again use this opportunity to thank the honourable member for his continuing concern on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Treasurer. Is it a fact that the most recent International Monetary Fund and Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development forecasts for economic growth among the industrial economies available prior to the August Budget indicated a 3 per cent growth in 1986 and that the forecasts of those institutions would have largely shaped the international growth assumptions underpinning the Budget forecasts? If so, does the Treasurer's statement in Tokyo yesterday that the world economy is `looking a little fragile at present' and that growth in the industrial economies now seems `likely to fall below 3 per cent' indicate that the Government has revised down its international growth assumptions contained in the Budget? If so, what impact will this have on the Budget forecasts for the current account deficit and the sustained fall in interest rates promised by the Prime Minister in this House only yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that at the annual meeting of the IMF and World Bank in Washington last October an amount of pessimism was expressed by a number of world financial leaders about the extent of growth in the various countries. It is true that the Treasurer led in many of the discussions in pointing out that the need for the United States of America to rein in its large Budget deficit meant that Germany and Japan, in particular, should take a more leading role in the world in easing their monetary situations and in the various policies which would lead to world growth. The Treasurer, as he has announced in this House, came away pessimistic about the attitudes of Japan and Germany at that time. He has gone to Japan for one particular reason, and that is to continue his dialogue with Mr Miyazawa, the new Japanese Finance Minister, in order to seek to persuade Japan in particular to take a role in this matter of easing its policies to lead to more growth. I believe that the Japanese are seeking to respond to those sorts of advices coming from various quarters.

ANSWER.PARA: At the moment the Australian Government sees no reason to change its forecasts in any way. We hope that the various recommendations which have been made from all around the world to the Japanese and Germans will lead them to take more of a lead in this matter, which will mean that the forecasts on which the Australian Budget has been based will be proper forecasts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the effects on the profitability of banks of government economic policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition had occasion yesterday in this place to refer to certain statements attributed to Mr Bob White, the Managing Director of the Westpac Banking Corporation. I have since looked into the profit position of the Westpac group. I agree that Westpac had a flat profit performance last year, in 1985-86. Indeed, group post-tax profits increased by only 3 per cent to $380m in 1985-86. Interestingly, that followed increases of 38 per cent and 20 per cent in the previous two years under the policies of this same Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I have noted comments that the poor performance of the savings bank and the fringe benefits tax were responsible for the relatively poor result last year. I am informed that the savings bank contributes only a small proportion of group profit-12 per cent in 1984-85-and that the fall of $10m in profits from this centre was dwarfed by the $103m increase in its general and specific provisions for bad and doubtful debts, which is attributable in significant part to its exposure to foreign currency loans to Australian resident borrowers. The reduced contributions of Westpac's finance company, which is twice the weight in group profit, is also more significant than the savings bank result.

Those opposite attribute the decline in profit to the impact of the FBT. We have got some very vivid imaginations on the other side of this place, but it requires a remarkably vivid imagination to see how a provision for FBT liability in the last three months of Westpac's fiscal year could have had a major impact on a total profit, post-tax of $380m. Like so many things that are emanating from the other side of this place, it simply does not add up. All this suggests is that Westpac, rather than blame the Government for its performance this year, should, in fact, be looking to its own decisions.

As the Leader of the Opposition sought to invoke a banker on this, let me simply say that not all bankers share the view that the Leader of the Opposition sought to identify with Mr White. Mr Will Bailey, the Managing Director of ANZ Bank, is quoted in Tuesday's Age in these terms:
You can't blame the present Government for the state of the economy, or for changes in the economic environment over the past 20 years . . .

That comment by Will Bailey of the ANZ reflects a very important reality; that is, this Government, as I have said in answer to previous questions today, has set its policies to secure the long term future of this country. We are certainly not going to give up on those responsible policies for the long term to protect the short term profits of bankers or any other sectional interest in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Acting Treasurer aware that many small businesses across Australia have been left holding the baby, stuck with stocks of fringe benefits tax vehicle log books-one small firm in Cowper is left with $3,000 worth of useless log books-following the Treasurer's fiddling with the fringe benefits tax log book requirements? Will he reimburse the businesses concerned for losses sustained because of the Treasurer's inept actions, or will he dismiss this problem as just one more unintended consequence?

—The honourable member for Cowper shows that, whereas at one time he was dead against the log books altogether, now he has changed his tune. The fact is that the log books can be kept and they can be used in future years if there is such a need. As we know from the changes that have been made to the fringe benefits tax in order to accommodate some of the worries from small businesses, which were the subject of the honourable member's question, we allowed 12 weeks of log book entries to determine the percentage of business milage vis-a-vis private milage. But that has to be watched from year to year. I suggest that we have saved those people from having to purchase new log books next year. No adjustments will be made for that.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. What initiatives has the Hawke Government taken to improve the well-being of Australian Defence Force personnel and their families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member will be aware of a number of initiatives which have been discussed previously in this place. The fact is that we ended the pay freeze that had effectively been established on Defence Force salaries by our opponents in their last year of office and effectively gave Defence Force personnel, in addition, a form of anomalies claim which resulted in a 5.9 per cent increase in their wages above the adjustments that they are getting along with the rest of the work force. I think the honourable gentleman will also be aware that we effectively ended a period of freeze on construction of new Defence Force housing. We ended that some time ago. In this Budget we have gone to a record high expenditure of some $66m in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member might not, however, be aware about progress with the implementation of the Hamilton report on supporting service families which was one of the initiatives that we undertook a short time ago to address a problem that I think all honourable members will be aware has been of increasing concern to Defence Force personnel. In this Budget some $1.3m has been made available as a start-up. It will be substantially more than that next year. As a result a national consultative group of service spouses has been established. It met in mid-October for the first time. It is developing and providing a forum for representing defence family matters to the Chief of the Defence Force.

The Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service is also under way. Early in 1987 we will be providing professionally trained community development officers to assist service families in the various installations around Australia. Suitably qualified service spouses will be eligible for appointment and this will be actively encouraged.

I refer now to conditions of service. In light of the Hamilton report, work is proceeding on improvements to, amongst other things, firstly, reunion travel; secondly, child care during removals; and, thirdly, removal for separated spouses. A large number of initiatives are under way.

I was very delighted to see today an initiative established not by this Government but by Government back bench committee members. There was a meeting to which I was invited. The honourable member was a participant. This initiative was for the establishment of a government defence forces action committee on the initiative of those back bench members who represent electorates with a large population of defence personnel and their families.

I am advised that the committee includes the honourable members for Hughes, Herbert, Leichhardt, Grey, Hunter, Greenway, Eden-Monaro, Jagajaga, Bendigo, McEwen, Moore, Brisbane, Brand, Dunkley and Calare. Several others will be joining that committee as well.

That demonstrates the very substantial concern not only on the part of this Government but among the Government back benchers in the interests of service personnel. I assure the members of that committee that we will continue in office to show the care and concern that we have for the conditions both of service personnel and their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment aware of threats by members of the Queensland Graingrowers Association that, unless the Government announces next year's kangaroo cull quota within a few weeks, farmers will go ahead with the proposed one day kangaroo culling shoot? When will the Minister announce the new quota?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report by Mr Houen of the Queensland Graingrowers Association threatening to take the law into his own hands with the proposed shoot out of kangaroos unless I announce the cull quota within a few weeks. Frankly, of all the stupid ideas that I have heard since I became a Minister, this one takes the cake. I want to thank the honourable member because he and his colleague Senator Boswell have been very sensible in their attitude on this matter. As a matter of fact, I might suggest that, if honourable members get invited to the honourable member's electorate for a visit they should accept, as they will have some of the best days they will ever have in their lives. As a matter of fact, I thought the honourable member was Crocodile Dundee.

ANSWER.PARA: Getting back to the subject, I can think of nothing more likely to destroy Australia's reputation abroad as a responsible nation than the action suggested by Mr Houen. I can think of nothing more likely to ensure that our kangaroo management program is destroyed. Mr Houen and some of his colleagues in Queensland seem incapable of understanding that the program not only is dependent upon the work of our State and Federal National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the universities but also, in the final crunch, is dependent upon the European nations and the United States of America which import 90 per cent of the skins culled under the commercial quota. Currently, there is a Bill before the United States Congress calling for an import ban on three species of kangaroo-the western grey, the eastern grey and the red. The European Community is also currently addressing the issue through a motion for a resolution in the Parliament proposing an import ban on kangaroos.

But I and my Department, over the past 3 1/2 years, have painstakingly explained to representatives of these bodies how our management plan works and how commercial industry is a vital component of a program to contain the population of these species and, at the same time, to ensure that the various species are maintained in reasonable populations across their normal habitat. I believe that they understand our program and that it is a responsible, cost effective and humane way of achieving that objective.

Regrettably, a few irresponsible animal welfare liberation groups, using the kangaroo as a means of promoting their own initiatives, have deliberately spread a tissue of lies and disinformation about Australia's program that has been difficult to counteract because we are dealing in the United States and Europe with a largely uninformed community. They have also used the most disgraceful blackmail methods against sporting shoe manufacturers that have resulted in a number of their distributors kowtowing to the blackmail and agreeing not to use kangaroo hide in their products. Let me make it clear that I do not include the majority of responsible conservation groups in Australia, such as the Queensland Conservation Council, the World Wildlife Fund, the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and many others, which understand and support the Government's program in this category.

The last thing we need in Australia is for the international media to relay stories of mass kangaroo slaughters to Europe and the United States. Mr Houen and his friends need not worry about my setting any commercial quotas; there will not be any. The European and the United States Congress will see to it that Mr Houen will shoot not only kangaroos but also himself and his friends in both feet. There will be no quota and there will be no management plan. These liberation groups will have contributed in the same way as Greenpeace, the Fund for Animals and Australians for Animals in destroying the program and kangaroos will be culled but by much less humane methods of poisoning and killing by amateur shooters. The Government recognises that the kangaroo population situation is serious, particularly in the area where the honourable member for Maranoa comes from. The scientific evidence coming to us at the moment shows that there has been a significant increase in the population of kangaroos this year, probably above 15 per cent. We will consider that scientific information carefully and adjust our program accordingly. I will not be bludgeoned or blackmailed by the likes of Mr Houen or anyone else into prematurely making decisions. When we have all the information we will make a decision and not one second before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Aviation inform the House what progress is being made in improving Australia's airports? Further, what private sector proposals, if any, are under consideration to build airport terminals in Australia, particularly with respect to Sydney international airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is as aware as I am that the problems we have with airport services now are really the legacy of the mismanagement and the failure to plan of those who now sit opposite who now come forward with quick-fix propositions that they think will overcome a problem that was many years in the making. I just say to the honourable member that this Government is carrying forward an extensive program of airport works, upgradings and extensions at Sydney, Brisbane, Perth, Canberra, Townsville, Coolangatta and, separately in the country areas, Albury, Broken Hill, Casino, Tamworth, Wagga Wagga, Bundaberg, and Kangaroo Island and work is in progress at Coffs Harbour.

ANSWER.PARA: Coming to the question the honourable member raised of ownership of airport terminals, this brings into focus the irresponsible policy of the Opposition that important public facilities, such as airports and international airport terminals, should be handed over to private individuals. That effectively places the lifeline of the aviation system in the hands of a board of people who can determine what airlines, under what conditions and at what prices, will have access to the airline traffic of this country.

We have seen this kind of proposal put forward in respect of Queensland. I draw the attention of the House to the assertions of some kind of private proposal to build an international terminal at Brisbane. The expressions of interest for a hotel-motel complex were invited in respect of Brisbane early in the year and eight organisations indicated an interest. Those eight organisations were invited to tender and three tendered. Of the three tenders two were clearly non-conforming tenders. The Government took independent legal advice on that matter and that was the recommendation that we were duly bound to uphold.

Let me say in respect of one of the non-conforming tenders that that proposal was being promoted by a Queensland knight, Sir Frank Moore, a well known identity of the National Party of Australia. He was publicly promoting a proposal to build the international terminal at Brisbane, knowing full well that he was the principal of the Roma Street development group that had put forward a non-conforming tender. He knew that and he promoted it publicly without disclosing his own interest. He knew all the time, because he would have had the same legal advice available to him that we had, that it did not conform. Separately from that, another tender did not conform. So no proposal was put forward at all that could have been considered. Certainly, what he put forward was not for a hotel-motel complex, as had been invited by this Government, but for a hotel-motel complex involving a new international terminal. So in Brisbane there is no proposal other than that of the cronies from the Queensland Parliament who thought that they would be dealing in a tendering process in the same way as the Queensland Government deals with tenders. That is the procedure that was under way and that is not the kind of procedure that is acceptable to this Government.

In the case of the international terminal at Sydney a suggestion was put forward by Qantas Airways Ltd towards the end of last year and early this year that it may be interested in erecting a second terminal. It was invited to explain that. When it learnt that the extensions currently under way to Sydney's international terminal would result in an 80 per cent increase in the capacity of that terminal, it quickly withdrew from that proposition and also because it realised that its proposal would involve an outlay of some $70m to $80m, not $20m as had been suggested by certain people. So there is no proposal there.

The only other proposal was a suggestion from certain people in Darwin that they were prepared to finance the extravagance that was suggested in respect of Darwin-a terminal costing in excess of $108m. It is not a matter of who finances the project; it is a matter of what is value for money and what can be afforded. Naturally, under the proposal we would still have to pay the bill anyway and air travellers would still have to pay the bill, so it was rejected.

So I say to the honourable member that there is no proposal for a terminal to be financed from private sources. But, separately from that, it is not the policy of this Government. It is idiotic to suggest that international terminals or airports should be handed over to a bunch of individuals and that they should control public facilities as important and critical as these are to the operation of airline services, particularly to the tourism industry. In conclusion, I say to the honourable member that this Government has done more than any other government in a comparable period to improve the airport systems and services in this country, and we will continue that course of progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Given that the Prime Minister has been willing, over the last couple of days, to predict the future direction for interest rates, will he predict the future course for the Australian dollar and does he still hold the view that the appropriate level for the Australian dollar lies between US72c and US75c?
—The answer is no and no.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. Can the Minister inform the House as to what penalties are contained in the Australia Card Bill in the event of forgeries of Australia Cards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the House that under clause 164 of the Australia Card Bill a person in possession or control of a false Australia Card faces a penalty of $10,000 or imprisonment for five years or both. Once the Bill is passed, I understand, anyone encouraging others to forge an Australia Card will be liable to prosecution under the Crimes Act for conspiracy to commit an offence.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the attention of the House to this matter because the latest juvenile antic of the Opposition is for one of the Opposition members to offer a $100 prize for the first person to forge an Australia Card. It is very difficult to imagine a more kindergarten-like activity in relation to the Australia Card. It shows the depths to which Opposition members have sunk in their effort to debate this very important matter. Throughout the debate they have sought to debase and trivialise the whole debate. Indeed yesterday, after I had commented, somewhat adversely, that Opposition members had paid very little attention to the civil liberties protections provided in the Australia Card Bill, we did a check and found that in almost a whole day's debate only three or four paragraphs from the Opposition referred to the Data Protection Agency. The House, and no doubt the Australian public, may well ask: Why has the Opposition so trivialised and debased the debate on the Australia Card? The answer is that the Opposition has no comprehensive solution to the problems of tax evasion and social welfare fraud in this country. Where there should be policies, there is simply a vacuum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Since the Treasurer gave his warning in May about banana republics, the country has seen worsening balance of payments figures month by month-creating a new record last month; rising inflation, with the latest quarterly consumer price index figures the worst since this Government was elected; and interest rates at their highest for at least 50 years in real terms. Each time the Opposition raises these matters the Prime Minister and the Treasurer seem to believe that pouring scorn on those who dare question their policies will somehow fix everything. Given the fact that the Prime Minister has been Prime Minister for 3 1/2 years now--
—Order! Will you get to the question, please?

—Yes, I will, Madam Speaker. When will the Prime Minister stop pretending that Australians are not entitled to hold his Government responsible, at least in part, for Australian's worsening economic situation?

—One hardly knows where to begin with an effort like that. In answer to this question, I am simply prepared to rest, as I have on a couple of other occasions in this place, not simply on the judgment that I make about myself or on the judgment that the Treasurer makes about the record of this Government. I simply put again what I guess would have to be regarded as at least an objective analysis, and that is by a former colleague of Opposition members in this place, Mr Hyde, who has said publicly that this is a better government and better at economic management than was the previous Government-and he is right.

—I address my question to the Minister for Science.
