It would be a very sad day for this country if it were all thrown out at once, as has been suggested by the Leader of the Opposition.

Most of all, the Australian people under the Hawke Labor Government have been given incentive through taxation reform. There have been tax cuts for all. The 60c rate has been cut to 49c. The poverty traps have been ended so that there is incentive for pensioners to earn a little more. The Liberal and National parties have not cared about these people in their time in government. We have ended the Howard double taxation on dividends. We are cutting the small business tax rate from 78c in the dollar, which was the Howard rate, to no more than 49c. We are introducing a fair and reasonable package of taxes, such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, to make income fashionable again instead of devices which walk around the tax system. These are the real incentives, these will got our economy going. The proof of the pudding is in the eating, the proof is in what we have achieved. All this is a genuine and comprehensive program of incentive, unlike the phoney lot that the Leader of the Opposition gave us today.

The Leader of the Opposition also seeks to shed some crocodile tears about interest rates. The truth is that, as the Prime Minister said, there has been a decline in market interest rates in recent months. For the future, while the Government, through sound fiscal, monetary and wages policies, has established the foundations for reduction in interest rates, we will not seek to engineer that reduction prematurely in a forced way. Let there be no doubt where the prime responsibility for Australia's present interest rate structure lies.

In seven years of rule the Fraser-Howard Government did nothing to address the fundamental imbalances in the Australian economy. Instead it took a massive gamble that resources exports would be our road to riches. All our eggs were placed in one basket. Australia was left reliant on a narrow base of mineral and agricultural exports. We are paying for it now. We are paying for those Fraser-Howard years. Our manufacturing sector was ripped to shreds by cheap imports and this policy was no more than economic vandalism, from which the Hawke Labor Government has had to rescue the Australian economy. The Leader of the Opposition's big play of the roulette wheel did not come off and he will pay for it because we will not let the Australian people forget what was the real record of the present Leader of the Opposition.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON TELECOMMUNICATIONS INTERCEPTION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception, I present the report of the Committee, incorporating a dissenting report, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In presenting the report on behalf of the Committee I would like firstly to remark on the fact that the Committee was unique in the history of the Commonwealth Parliament. This was the first occasion since Federation that a Bill originating in the House of Representatives was referred to a joint select committee for examination and report. I am advised, further, that this was the first time also that a Bill was referred by the House to a select committee prior to the second reading, and today is the first time that a select committee has reported on a Bill referred to it by the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's task was not an easy one. Formed by resolution of the Houses in June of this year, the Committee sat for the first time on 17 July 1986 and for the last time on 18 November 1986. In that time, the Committee was required to examine and report on, firstly, the Telecommunications Interception Amendment Bill 1986 and, secondly, the recommendations contained in Mr Justice Stewart's report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions to the effect that the power of interception be extended to cover serious offences.

The Bill itself is complex, and covers an area in which there is a wide divergence of views within the community and within this Parliament itself. But the Committee took the view that, consistent with the requirement in its resolution of appointment to report as soon as possible, it should report by the end of the parliamentary sittings in 1986. This task has now been achieved. But in doing so it precluded a protracted inquiry into important peripheral issues raised by the Bill and raised in evidence taken by the Committee.

There were many issues of central importance which emerged during the inquiry. These included: The requirement of law enforcement agencies to have rapid access to information which would assist in countering organised and drug-related crime and in solving other serious criminal offences; the protection of individual privacy from unwarranted intrusion; the prevention of abuse of interception powers; the protection of the integrity of the telecommunications system; the need for a thorough and practicable system of safeguards, consistent with administrative efficiency; the requirement for a streamlined system for the lawful implementation of interceptions; the admissibility of evidence gained through legal and illegal interceptions; the communication of information gained through legal interceptions; and the problems created by the free availability of devices capable of effecting illegal interceptions.

The Committee's consideration of these issues generated both heat and light during the inquiry. The Committee was unanimous in its view that there is a need to give law enforcement agencies such assistance as is necessary to combat organised crime, drug trafficking and other serious offences. The Committee was also in broad agreement that there needed to be a balanced structure of safeguards to protect individual privacy and to maintain the integrity of the telecommunications system.

The Committee divided, however, on the best means of achieving these aims. By a majority, in fact by six to three, the report outlines a proposed system which will extend to all necessary law enforcement agencies rapid access to intercepted information sought by them, targeted by them, and in accordance with priorities determined solely by them. The recommendations retain, however, a form of central control in a proposed telecommunications interception agency which itself will provide a significant safeguard against abuse of interception powers and wrongful use of intercepted material. Other safeguards recommended by the Committee in its majority report include a detailed warranting system, strict criteria for the issue of warrants by Federal Court judges and a detailed system of reports culminating in the requirement for the responsible Minister to present to the Parliament an annual report on interceptions conducted in considerable statistical detail. This, in itself, will permit the Parliament to assess the efficacy of the interception process while at the same time protecting information which might either prejudice individual privacy or impede police operations. In addition, the Committee proposes a totally independent audit and scrutiny function over the interception process by a judicial officer.

I should like to refer to the premature release of information purporting to be the Committee's findings in this report and the subsequent reference of this matter to the Privileges Committee. As I have said, throughout the inquiry the Committee as a whole had a broad unity of purpose, differing only in the methodology and mechanisms necessary to achieve that purpose. The Committee maintained its cohesion right throughout the inquiry despite occasional differences, and I was pleased to serve as the Committee Chairman, whilst I recognise the right of the media to follow through reports on committees' views and attempt to predict conclusions. I must express my disappointment that someone on the Committee, or close to the Committee, appears to have unnecessarily assisted the media in fulfilling its role.

On behalf of the Committee, I would particularly like to thank those officers of the Department of the House of Representatives who, although not part of the Committee secretariat, played a major role in enabling this report to be tabled today. I thank Margaret Tie, Pat Arentz and Carol Richardson for their invaluable keyboard assistance in the production of the report since it was approved by the Committee on Tuesday, and Sarah Grey, who worked well into last night, and is still working, to duplicate sufficient copies of the report for those who require it today. At this stage I would also like to thank the Committee secretariat who worked above and beyond normal requirements of secretariat staff. Long hours, copious notes and Committee members who at times argued points of law which would have tested the High Court were all handled by the secretariat with apparent ease. To secretary Peter Gibson and his excellent support staff, Ms Dorothy Miles, Ms Kay Crouch and Mrs Yvonne Huddleston, go my sincere thanks on behalf of the Committee.

Throughout the inquiry, the Committee received unreserved co-operation from two key Commonwealth agencies, the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Telecommunications Commission. State police forces permitted by their governments to make submissions to, and appear before, the Committee made a significant contribution. The Committee is grateful to these organisations, and extends its thanks also to the various law societies, police associations, civil liberties groups, government departments and private individuals who gave evidence to the Committee or made submissions.

The Committee, however, was surprised at the response of State governments to invitations to contribute to the Committee's inquiry. Their responses are detailed in the report, and can best be described as less than enthusiastic, particularly when the main issue before the Committee involved a significant potential devolution of Commonwealth power to the States. The enthusiasm with which these governments embraced the suggestions of the participants at the National Drug Summit, particularly with respect to the need for additional police powers to fight drug trafficking, was clearly not reflected in their communications to the Committee.

Most of the issues raised by the inquiry involved the Committee in `drawing the line' between conflicting, and, occasionally, opposing positions. Balanced judgments were required, and in large measure the Committee achieved agreement. The Committee trusts that the report contributes to public awareness and discussion of the issues involved, and assists in the development of appropriate legislation in this important and sensitive field. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I had the privilege of serving on the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception as the Deputy Chairman to the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), who has just spoken. Before I emphasise some of the areas of disagreement that some of us have with the majority report, I commend the honourable member on his efforts. I commend our colleagues who worked very hard on the preparation of this document and I endorse his comments about the very capable assistance that we received from the secretariat, provided by the House and the Senate, as well as the secretarial staff. To Peter Gibson and Dorothy Miles I say a special thank you for their efforts in ensuring that all views held by Committee members on this subject were able to be made available to the House today.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee's report acknowledges that there are arguments for and against each of its conclusions. It emphasises that in some areas a balanced judgment had to be made. Of course, some of these conclusions would extend significantly the range of circumstances in which telephone and telecommunications interceptions may occur and the information so gained would be made available to a wider range of law enforcement agencies. To the extent that that has occurred in this report and there is agreement on that, I think it is a very important matter and one which, we ought to be pleased, is the concluded position of this Committee. As part of the Committee's package of proposals, the majority has limited seriously the possible range of offences in which telephone interceptions may be used to investigate breaches of the law. The majority report confines the use of telecommunications interceptions directly to the Australian Federal Police or a central agency which may be established within the AFP and implements a range of additional reporting and safeguard provisions, some of which may very well impede the successful use of telephone interceptions.

In the minority report, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), Senator Brian Archer and I came to the view that greater weight should have been placed on arguments advanced by law enforcement agencies for assistance in obtaining evidence which would aid them in obtaining convictions for serious drug trafficking offences and organised criminal activity. In our overview we relied very heavily on the evidence submitted by Mr Justice Stewart. I quote from what he said:
This Commission has not the slightest doubt that organised criminal activity is continuing which has not yet been identified by conventional law enforcement methods.

Mr Justice Stewart came to that view whilst conducting his Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. It is our view that, if this situation is to be reversed, law enforcement agencies must be given every possible means to counteract serious crime. We were of the view, following the Special Premiers Conference on Drugs, that the Government was adopting an approach which was likely to meet that need expressed by Mr Justice Stewart.

The Special Premiers Conference on Drugs, held in April 1985, endorsed the importance of achieving full co-operation between law enforcement authorities, both within jurisdictions and between jurisdictions. The Conference called on all relevant authorities to ensure that they work together in a co-operative way. The Conference further agreed that telephone interception powers can be a valuable aid in the investigation of drug trafficking and that the Commonwealth would extend such powers in relation to drug trafficking to the States, subject to stringent controls being exercised over their use. The controls were to include a requirement for judicial warrants.

The fact is that we believe the report is flawed because it does not go as far as Mr Justice Stewart thought was desirable in certain areas, which I will identify in a moment. It does not envisage the co-operative arrangements that we thought were likely to be put in place after the Special Premiers Conference. It was our view that the extension of telephone and telecommunications interceptions powers to the National Crime Authority, State police forces, including the Northern Territory Police Force and the New South Wales Drug Crime Commission, if those organisations were desirous of it, was a very desirable matter. That was the view of the Committee. The extension would proceed, if requested by the agencies, in accordance with the guidelines proposed by the Government in its amending Bill, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1986.

The minority members were not in favour of the introduction of a further interventionist statutory authority as proposed in the report. As a consequence of that view, we believe that if the law enforcement agencies mentioned request a capacity to utilise telecommunications interceptions, they should make all the decisions in relation to that matter themselves. They should be able to approach a court for information, and the issue of a warrant should be accessible and convenient to them. The warrants should be obtained through State Supreme Court judges in addition to judges of the Federal Court of Australia. The interceptions would be facilitated by Telecom Australia. We saw that as the most desirable and direct method and one which would limit the possibility of serious delay which can occur in relation to these matters. The dissenting report identifies some of those issues further.

While we broadly accept the majority view on the range of serious offences for which telecommunications interceptions might be used, we recognise, like the majority, that circumstances might arise, which we have not envisaged, where it may be appropriate that the interceptions power be extended beyond the list of specified offences that the Committee has identified in its report. We believe that it should be possible to obtain an extension to that list expeditiously. We were concerned that, if an amendment is required to an Act of parliament, the system proposed would be a significant impediment to the use of telecommunications interceptions in appropriate cases. Therefore, we came to the view that whilst the extension of the list should be scrutinised by parliament, a more appropriate mechanism for achieving such extensions is the regulation-making power.

In the area of safeguards, we accept, like the majority, that the use of telecommunications interceptions carries significant risks, particularly to privacy. Therefore, the use of this power should be balanced with carefully structured safeguards. However, the safeguards should not be so stringent as to seriously impede the appropriate use of the power to make telecommunications interceptions.

We are of the view that the use of information obtained from interceptions carried out in accordance with the law ought to be used in all but the most minor of offences. It is our view that the Committee's recommendation to limit the use of such information to a range of offences punishable only by imprisonment for three years or longer would provide a formal and technical defence to charges which ought quite properly lead to a conviction on available interception evidence. Coupled with this, the majority view that information obtained in some technical contravention of the interception legislation should be inadmissible in a court, except solely for the purposes of establishing a contravention, is in itself an unreasonable requirement. That requirement would merely establish another form of technical defence to offences that could otherwise be properly established by relevant agencies and lead to a conviction before a court.

The Committee's report envisages a rewriting of the legislation and suggests that the Bill and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act be withdrawn and redrafted. From our experience we conclude that this would be a very time-consuming procedure. The adoption of this approach might well delay, by possibly a year or more, the introduction of appropriate legislation. It is our view that the Government should amend the Bill immediately in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee, taking into account the views of the dissentients, and proceed to put in place new arrangements as quickly as possible. The Government could proceed to introduce an amending Bill consolidating the amendments and the existing legislation at a later date. In order to satisfy the desire of those who would like such legislation to come into the Parliament quickly, a sunset clause in the amending Bill could be utilised.

Finally, it is the judgment of the dissentients that the requirement for detailed and comprehensive reports to Parliament, as well as the intervention of a judicial auditor, is unnecessary and an excessive intervention that may well hinder the effectiveness and use of interceptions. It is our view that only one of the proposals in the Committee report ought to be accepted by the Government. We believe that a judicial auditor as proposed would limit the public release of information, which may have an unintended consequence of alerting criminals, to some extent, of the methods of operation of law enforcement agencies. Therefore, our preferred view for safeguard and protection is that the judicial auditor report mechanism should be adopted by the Government and put in place.
I mention those dissents most strongly. I commend them to the Government. I believe that, in adopting the proposals in the report, the Government should qualify them in the way we have suggested.

It is ironic that Robert Kennedy at the 1964 Democratic convention was the subject of a considerable degree of telephone interceptions and the use of listening devices allegedly planted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the United States to provide certain political information to President Johnson. The first thing that has to be said about this report and the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception is, as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has pointed out, that we have all found agreement on a large number of points. There was unanimous agreement that telephone intercepts, if they are approved by a judge, should be extended beyond drug trafficking. There was unanimous agreement that that should include murder, kidnapping and organised crime. Despite Mr Justice Stewart's recommendation that the State police forces and the National Crime Authority should have the power to install their own telephone intercept devices, the committee unanimously agreed that the current practice whereby Telecom Australia implements telephone intercepts should continue.

As the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), pointed out, the Committee divided six, three on what, on balance, was the most efficient and secure way to give the State police forces and the NCA the information that they need to catch those who are dealing in drugs and involved in organised crime. It should be remembered that if the original recommendations of Mr Justice Stewart's report had been accepted, it would have allowed not only the six State police forces to intercept telephone conversations, but also the Northern Territory police force, the National Crime Authority and the New South Wales Drug Crime Commission.

Many on the Committee were disappointed with the response from the State governments. We wrote to them on more than one occasion asking them to give evidence to our committee. With the exception of the New South Wales Government and the Northern Territory Government, none of the State governments came out in complete support of Mr Justice Stewart's report. TALK.START.PARA: —The table indicates the view of the various State governments on this issue. No State government was prepared to come before the Committee to give evidence and to answer any questions which the Committee wished to ask. The Committee was, therefore, totally unable to reach a conclusion as to whether the safeguards which the various State governments proposed to introduce were satisfactory. In fact, the South Australian Government advised the Committee that whilst it endorsed Mr Justice Stewart's recommendations that power should be extended to the States, it preferred the Australian Federal Police to carry out any telephone interceptions which the South Australian police needed. I wish to make several comments on the minority report which has been brought down by three members of the Opposition. Paragraph 6 states:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that a greater weight should have been placed on the arguments advanced by law enforcement agencies . . .

This is on the question of whether the State should be allowed to intercept telephone conversations or whether the Federal Police, as a central agency, should carry out interceptions for everyone. I believe the minority report has not given enough weight to some comments made by people who represented the State police forces. Chief Superintendent Parrington, gave evidence, along with others, on behalf of the New South Wales Police. He made the following remarks at our hearings in Sydney:

That means the actual tapes and everything would be in Sydney. Yes, that would overcome that major objection. It is very costly having it in Canberra where the lines have to run backwards and forwards from wherever the tap is on.
Secondly, I quote from Assistant Commissioner Delianis, who is from the Victoria Police. He made the following remarks in answer to the following questions from the Chairman:
CHAIRMAN-How would you react to a suggestion . . . that there be established some central organisation to handle all telecommunication interceptions for all levels of crime investigation . . .
Mr Delianis-Yes, that would have appeal.
CHAIRMAN-The Victorian Police would have no objection to something like that?
Mr Delianis-There would be no objections, providing security were not thrown down the drain . . .

In my view we did not have very strong evidence from the State police forces to say that they needed to implement the intercepts. I believe that, by allowing the Australian Federal Police to apply all of the intercepts that are needed, we can have an efficient and tightly run organisation. It is important to remember that the Committee report recommends that the State police forces be allowed to determine the targets and priorities and be allowed to go to a Federal Court judge to seek approval of the warrant. I believe the State police forces will be able to make effective use of these procedures. We will not have the complaints coming forward that perhaps the Federal Police are not co-operating sufficiently with the various State police forces.

Before I wind up, I will comment on another point which did have the unanimous support of all members of the committee; that is a recommendation contained in chapter 2, namely, that the law should be amended to allow the Australian Federal Police to introduce evidence from their monitors by using evidentiary certificates. At the moment whenever the Federal Police produce evidence in court which has been obtained by legal interceptions, a large number of the Federal Police staff are required to go to the trial and give evidence which is largely technical and quite time-consuming for the police and courts. The Committee unanimously recommended that that evidence be allowed to be given by way of certificate on the very important condition that the defence retain the right to challenge that evidence and have all the monitors brought to court.

I wish to add my thanks to Peter Gibson, the Secretary of the Committee, and all the support staff. I say to my colleagues who served on the Committee that it was one of the most rewarding experiences I have had since I have been in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Although it is coincidental, it is nonetheless important that the presenting of this report occurs at the very same time when jury convictions against three of the United States of America's five Mafia families have been brought down. When in America during July I engaged in a number of discussions with Federal prosecutors and district attorneys in different parts of America on the strategy employed against the Mafia and other criminal organisations. The fundamental plank of that strategy was the use of telephone interceptions.

SPEECH.PARA: I say, with respect, that the Americans found it hard to believe that we have waited so long to be in a position to pass legislation allowing for telephone interceptions beyond the narrow grounds that previously existed, that being phone tapping only by the Australian Federal Police in regard to drug trafficking. Of the Mafia convictions, we find that the primary evidence is largely arrived at by way of telephone interceptions, if not against the three heads of the families then of their lieutenants, so that certain convictions are envisaged making those lieutenants more susceptible to turning prosecution evidence. Coupled with the efforts of the authorities in Sicily and Italy, the Americans are very confident that the Mafia in a short while will be reduced to another large, although often successful criminal organisation. After giving the Mafia and organised crime offshoots some 40 or 50 years head start, the Americans have finally brought them back to the field. The problem for them now, of course, is the upsurge and growth in a whole new area of organised crime-the Chinese Triads, the Colombians involved in the South American smuggling, a number of prison gang organised crime rackets as well as bikies. I make those introductory comments to stress the importance of telephone interceptions whilst at the same time acknowledging, as did the Deputy Chairman of this inquiry, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), the need to have stringent controls on the issuing of warrants allowing telephone interceptions.

The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) qouted from what Robert F. Kennedy had to say in the early 1960s about the need to limit the extension of crimes upon which telephone interceptions could be placed. The first comment I make to that is that a lot of water has flowed under the bridge since 1962 when Mr Kennedy made those comments and the extent and growth of organised crime, without talking about its menace, is so much more apparent to us. If anything, Australia lost its innocence and became aware of the dangers of organised crime only this decade. The second point I make to the honourable member for Dobell is that Federal Bureau of Investigation telephone interceptions and listening devices were all illegal applications. We must stress that the legal interceptions will be strictly controlled by the conditions laid down by the issuing judge.

Let me quickly summarise the differences in emphasis in this report between the majority and the minority. In essence, the minority believes that the report does not go far enough. We acknowledge the dedication and the honesty of approach by Government members but, at the end of the day, this falls short of what I believe to be the necessary tools in the war against organised crime. Firstly, the minority believes that the power to apply for telephone interceptions should be given to the National Crime Authority, all State and Northern Territory police forces and the New South Wales Drug Crime Commission. Secondly, we do not believe that there should be a central interception agency. Instead, each of these law enforcement agencies should be able to carry out their own interceptions. We do not agree with the report of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception in regard to the centralised operation.

Interestingly, in relation to the question of resources, it was never fully investigated whether the Australian Federal Police could or would be involved in any enlarged scheme. Again, in reply to the honourable member for Dobell's statement that Assistant Commissioner Paul Delianis of the Victoria Police Force has no objection to a central agency, my recollection, with respect, of that evidence is that it was never explained to Assistant Commissioner Delianis what was meant by a central agency, and I do not know whether he understood properly what was being put to him. I only raise that as a doubt, for the benefit of the honourable member for Dobell, rather than as any conclusive reading of Mr Delianis's mind.

The next point of difference is that we in the minority believe that there should be a wider extension of the offences upon which telephone interceptions can be placed. I do not believe that the offences should be limited to murder, kidnapping and organised crime activity arising out of, or centred upon, murder and kidnapping. What about white collar and other financial fraud, taxation fraud, union racketeering, illegal gambling, prostitution, hard core pornography, video piracy, extortion and standover tactics? As I read the majority report, unless those other crimes are connected in one way or another with murder, kidnapping or financial dealings, there will be a very real doubt as to whether a telephone interception can be granted. I believe that the offences upon which interception can be placed are too narrow. I note that the majority Committee report wishes all present legislation to be amended. But, as the honourable member for Dundas has said in the report which he so clearly influenced, that will take far too long. What we really need now is legislation to empower the law enforcement agencies to apply interceptions. The wholesale redrafting proposed by the majority will take far too long where speed is of the essence.

In drawing to a conclusion, I wish to acknowledge the work done by the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin). It is a trite observation that organised crime poses a major threat to Australian society. It also poses major problems of law enforcement to this Federal Government and, indeed, any Federal government. All in all, I do not despair in relation to this report, although I am a member of the minority report. It is far better to have our foot in the door and, after a period when the system works well, when perhaps there is a greater awareness of the evil we face, there will be an extension of powers and offences for telephone interceptions.

Finally, I associate myself with the comments of previous speakers concerning the quite outstanding assistance provided by Peter Gibson, Secretary to the Committee, Dorothy Miles's research officers and their administrative assistants. It was an immensely difficult task and it seemed as though the clock was always running against us. Therefore, they had to work with not only complex issues but also great speed and efficiency, and I wish to add my congratulations to them.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF HMAS ALBATROSS, NOWRA, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Development of HMAS Albatross, Nowra, NSW, stage 1.

The proposed work now before the House is for the construction of new facilities to support a squadron of Sikorsky Seahawk helicopters at HMAS Albatross Nowra. It was first referred to the Joint Committee on Public Works on 22 September 1986. Part of the proposal includes the development and upgrading of existing facilities at the base. In order to locate a squadron of Seahawk helicopters at Albatross, new facilities to service and maintain the helicopters will be required.

The work will involve the construction of a new building to house a flight simulator and an aircraft weapons system support centre. As well, an avionics workshop building will be extended and maintenance facilities, including a squadron maintenance support building and flight line operation and aircraft washdown facilities, will be built. Associated services to upgrade the base, such as a new supply centre and a building to house the Royal Australian Navy's tactical electronic warfare support section facility, will be provided. Fire protection to three hangars and a new pump house and substation will also be upgraded.

The estimated cost of all the work is $19.7m at November 1986 prices. This cost represents the indexed equivalent of the $19.2m at August 1986 prices which was originally referred to the Public Works Committee. This includes an additional $70,000 for a larger computer room for the flight simulator. Further consultations have taken place between officers of the Department of Housing and Construction and both the Shoalhaven Shire Council and the State Pollution Control Commission. These consultations will continue during progress on the work. In addition, Department of Defence officers will hold further discussions with the Shoalhaven Shire Council in respect of urban development and a cycleway.

When the House first referred the proposal to the Public Works Committee, the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), misunderstood some aspects in my speech. The proposal consists of two parts. The first element is for helicopter facilities estimated to cost $6.65m at August 1986 prices. This work has been included in the capital works program for 1986-87. Four hundred thousand dollars has been set aside in the capital works program this financial year for the helicopter facilities. This is considered a reasonable amount, given that the bulk of contracts will not be let until February 1987.

A contract for the installation of the flight simulator computer will be awarded as soon as possible. Apart from the flight simulator, it is intended that construction of the helicopter facilities will commence in February 1987, and will be completed by September 1988. The remaining element of the proposal is for the upgrading of the base. This is estimated to cost $12.55m at August 1986 prices and is likely to be included in the capital works program next financial year.

If the upgrading work required for the base is included in the 1987-88 capital works program, it is anticipated that construction will commence in August 1987, and be completed by the end of 1988. So there are two stages to this work-one which already has government approval, and stage 2 which will, after today, have Public Works Committee approval and will go forward hopefully into the next capital works program.

Consultants have been used to design and develop the proposed work and it is intended that they will continue to be used for project documentation. Actual construction is to be contracted to private enterprise in accordance with normal Department of Housing and Construction practice. The project will employ a work force which will peak at 100 on site plus 25 off site administrative staff. Up to an additional 30 positions could be generated in local support and services industries. I would like to thank the Committee for its quick examination and support of this proposal. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) I shall respond on behalf of the coalition to the motion moved by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West). There is no doubt that the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has dealt with the report now before us effectively, and expeditiously. Like the Minister, I commend it for the way in which it has undertaken its responsibilities. The extension of these facilities at HMAS Albatross is essential if the Royal Australian Navy is to bring into service on schedule the Seahawk helicopters. These are an essential adjunct to the fleet which will be able to give to the FFG frigates the eyes and ears necessary for them to undertake their proper function. Without the Seahawks the FFG is not adequately able to undertake its task. The Squirrel is a much smaller helicopter than is necessary, and of course it does not have anti-submarine warfare capability. The Seahawk will correct that deficiency and, while it is true that there are other helicopters in service in the Royal Australian Navy which might to some degree pick up the shortfall, they cannot land with safety at least on marks 1 to 3 of the FFGs presently in service. For that reason the introduction of the Seahawks into service as soon as possible is essential. For that reason I was a little disappointed to see that the Seahawk helicopters are apparently still not coming into operation until, at the earliest, some time later next year.

SPEECH.PARA: The facilities themselves-this report relates specifically to the on-shore facilities-are essential if the fleet is to operate the Seahawks. It is necessary for the Navy to have shore based facilities at which the helicopters can be repaired and maintained, and particularly where major refits can be carried out. The other adjunct facilities relate not just to the Seahawks but to the Navy's tactical electronic warfare support section, to the flight simulator that is to be incorporated there and also to other facilities at HMAS Albatross.

The coalition has not at this stage taken any final stance with respect to a fixed wing aviation component for the Royal Australian Navy. It is of great concern to us, however, that the fleet should not go unprotected and we are therefore concerned that HMAS Albatross should be maintained and developed so that, should a future coalition government decide it necessary to acquire fixed wing aviation for the Royal Australian Navy, the facilities will be there and the naval base will be able to handle those aircraft and facilitate their operation and maintenance. Of course this is quite possible under the program envisaged in the motion before the House.

HMAS Albatross is an excellent facility. It is well served in the Nowra community, which is in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), and I believe the Navy and the community have established a very happy working relationship which is a very good illustration of how the community and the Services can work together to each other's mutual advantage. I notice as part of the reference there is a suggestion that there will be consultations with the Shoalhaven Shire Council and the State Pollution Control Commission, and also that there will be some urban development and a cycleway. These are necessary facilities to try to maintain the quality of the environment around HMAS Albatross, and again they have the full support of the coalition.

One area of concern to us is that in government we would wish to ensure to the maximum that work and responsibilities be undertaken by the private sector. I know that there is reference in the Minister's statement to actual construction by private enterprise in accordance with normal Department of Housing and Construction practice. It is our view that that construction must be undertaken by the ordinary community, and we believe that, subject to that being the case, the reference by the Minister would fit within our belief as to how the whole project should be undertaken. Private enterprise involvement and in particular the delegation to those within HMAS Albatross, who will have responsibility for operating these facilities, of greater financial management than is now the case are elements of our policy which differ from those now pursued by the present Government. The coalition supports the move by the Minister and believes that these additional facilities are necessary and will facilitate the early and adequate introduction into the Royal Australian Navy of the Seahawk generation of helicopters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the member of parliament representing HMAS Albatross I feel it important today to say a few words about the motion before the House. I state first that I, as the local member, welcome this motion. I urge the Government if there is at any stage in the future some means by which it can put a roof over these wonderful and valuable aircraft, to do so as quickly as possible because in so doing it will be maintaining a valuable piece of our history.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PIG INDUSTRY BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:PIG INDUSTRY (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986PIG SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the speeches of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Opposition spokesman on primary industry they gave details of the way in which the industry is growing and the reasons that that is so. I would like to repeat them for the information of people who may be listening to the debate on the Pig Industry Bill and cognate Bills and who did not hear those details. The reasons are several. It is a very efficient industry. The fact that consumption is increasing reflects, it seems to me, changing eating habits of Australian people, possibly reflecting the huge number of people who have come here from overseas since the Second World War. This is an efficient industry partly because at present the grain prices are lower. Farmers, in association with research companies, have gained world wide recognition for their ability to handle pigs. There is an improved feedback conversion ratio and, as other speakers in the debate have indicated and as has been mentioned in the debates on all manufacturing industries, the rapid devaluation of the Australian dollar has certainly been of benefit to Australian exporters as far as their exports are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is appropriate in a debate such as this to pay tribute to the aggressive marketing and research activities of people who are associated with the manufacture of pork goods. It is true that they have sought out markets overseas as well as locally. They have done this basically through their own expertise, at their own cost, and they have always been proud to put their brand names on their exports. Of course, it is understood that those products also bear the Australian mark. The success has been the fact that individual exporters, private enterprise people, have taken a great pride in the quality of their product and a determination to ensure that the quality of the product is sufficient to attract purchasers from all over the world, irrespective of the competition.

In some of the markets that they have opened up there has been a realisation that it is difficult for Australian companies and exporters to compete against such producers as the European Economic Community and Canada. It is often stated in the House and in other debates that such producers dump their products. Australian pork producers have endeavoured to open up new markets such as the air export of fresh, unfrozen pork to the rapidly growing markets of Japan, Korea and New Zealand. Occasionally in debates all of us should adopt the view of what is good for Australia and forget about playing politics. The Minister saw that maybe there would be a threat to Australia from the dumping of Canadian products. Because of his concern that some of these products from Canada could contain diseases which are not prevalent in Australia, he has agreed to ensure that any such products that come in are examined and, as I understand it, the Government will pay the costs.

It is interesting to note that the suggestions for the rearrangement of this authority have more or less fallen in line with the blueprint that the Minister indicated to the House some months ago would be the format that he would like all statutory and primary industry marketing authorities to adopt. It appears to me that sometimes in pursuing an objective we may not fully meet with the agreement of all sections of the industry. The information that comes to me from Queensland-

TALK.START.PARA: —A great State.

—As the honourable member for Dawson quite rightly and fittingly observed, it is a great State, a State where democracy continues, where a party that gets 56 per cent of the vote can quite rightly govern the State. The Queensland industry believed it was not necessary to have this type of legislation. It was in agreement that the original Pork Promotion Committee had been very successful; it operated with a minimum of costs. It is a concern that, under the arrangements as indicated by the Minister in this legislation, the cost factor could be prohibitive. I am informed that the Tasmanian organisation plus the Queensland organisation and the intensive pig producers were basically against this type of statutory authority. I assure the Minister that the industry in those States will be keeping a very close watch on the cost factor and the operations of the statutory authority.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Minister's attention to a view that has been expressed to me by pig producers from all over Australia, and that is the composition of the Pig Industry Policy Council. I make particular reference to the fact that on that Council one position has been reserved for the President of the National Meat Processors Association. It is my understanding that the National Meat Processors Association is not representative of pork processors. It grew out of the Australian Meat Canners Association which canned beef, pork and sheep products. I know that the Minister, given his background, will be interested to note that the criticism that I get of this organisation is that in industry circles it is called the Melbourne Club. Not having any association with the Melbourne Club, I am not really sure what the inference is, but I understand that it does not represent the real producers of Australia; it just represents the big producers. Many small producers of pork products do not belong to that Association which, as I have said, does not specifically represent pork producers but which represents also beef and sheep product processors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big is not always best.

—The honourable member for Dawson has come in with quite a legitimate observation that big is not always best. It is quite right that government always has a responsibility to look after the smaller producer. It is all very well to bring in legislation which purports to meet with the approval of an industry because a few producers are producing an enormous quantity, but the wishes of a lot of producers who are producing a small percentage are disregarded.

SPEECH.PARA: It is necessary for the Minister to have another look at the composition of his Pig Industry Policy Council. If he is attracted to the logic and the fairness of my comments, he might see fit to replace that person who, I am advised, is not representative of the industry by someone representing the Australian Consumers Association. It appears to me that too often we tend to forget that the consumer has rights and that it is necessary in the development of policy to ensure that the consumer is in a position to express a point of view adequately and, if necessary, with force. In the final analysis there is not much sense in producing a whole heap of goods if no one wants to buy them.

I will quote from a newspaper article of Friday, 11 April this year. It quotes a great Queenslander, a product of that beautiful part of Australia called the Darling Downs, Sir Leslie Price. He is a man who has had the confidence of governments of both political colours. I think it is pertinent to quote the views attributed to Sir Leslie Price by Peter Robinson in an article in the Australian Financial Review, as I said, of 11 April 1986. The article states:

As Sir Leslie Price, former boss of the Wheat Board and as tough an old cocky as you are ever likely to find, pointed out the other day, the overproduction of wheat in the world `is such that any relief for the Australian industry is likely to be only temporary'.
Between 4,000 and 5,000 farmers might be forced out of the industry . . .

So it appears to me that, consistent with the view expressed by Sir Leslie Price, it is necessary to ensure that the consumer is represented on these various policy councils, because the consumer knows what the people want. I pay tribute to the Pork Promotion Committee for what it has developed. It has developed smaller cuts of pork, pork with leaner meat, and pork which is more readily prepared-something that is very important in this modern day, particularly when both husband and wife work. I thought the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), voiced a great concern--

TALK.START.PARA: —How much longer, Tom?

—I will, just like the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), take 20 minutes. I understand that he took 20 minutes and, unless there is an arrangement, so will I. I understand that that was the norm. The shadow Minister expressed the concern that unless we watch it we could have a pork industry in Australia controlled by very few producers and we could have enormously sized intensive piggeries located in a few strategic areas. It was suggested that, in effect, they could establish a cartel and capture the market. So it is necessary to ensure that we have an industry which widely reflects the Australian method of access to grain et cetera and market requirements. Otherwise, the industry could very well go to the wall. So we will watch with interest all these initiatives which the Minister has brought up in the legislation that we are now debating.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the previous speakers touched on the need to have an industry which is export oriented. Of course, one can understand the logic of that approach, given the fact that last month we had the worst ever trading deficit-a record in Australia. Surely, Mr Deputy Speaker, it does not give you any great pride, as a member of the Australian Labor Party, to know that a government to whose policy, platform and philosophy you subscribe had an Australian record for a trading deficit. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in an excellent speech in this Parliament this afternoon, really detailed to the Australian people this severe problem of Australian farmers, brought on by the macroeconomic policies of the Hawke-Keating Administration. I think the views he expressed need to be emphasised. He cited the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates for 1985-86. The average farmer will have an income of $3,800. Surely, Mr Deputy Speaker, you must agree that that is well below the poverty line. Seventy-five per cent of farmers will be in debt. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would not allow 75 per cent of your trade union supporters to be in debt. Yet the Government sits idly by and allows this type of situation to occur. As the Leader of the Opposition states, in 1985-86 the interest repayments on capital borrowed for farm initiatives increased by 28 per cent over the year. He also detailed the problem of spiralling interest rates as they affect the home owner and he informed the Parliament and the nation that home loan interest rates increased by 4 per cent, from 11 1/2 per cent to 15 1/2 per cent, in two years, necessitating extra repayments of $152 per month.

Quite obviously we need to ensure that the farmers are in a position to remain competitive. I do not know how they will do that, because, in addition to those figures given to the Parliament by the Leader of the Opposition, the BAE indicated that there will be an increase in farm cash costs from $69,200 in 1983-84 to $79,300 in 1985-86. The rate of return to capital and management, excluding capital appreciation, will drop close to zero in 1985-86, against 2 per cent the previous year, while the real rate of return, this time including capital appreciation, was estimated at minus 6 per cent as a result of declining land values in some regions.

So in all these restructurings we need to be aware that the Government's macroeconomic policies are contributing to declining farm income, forcing farmers on to the verge of bankruptcy and making it impossible for them to stay internationally competitive. We want to increase the export of primary industry products. We want to ensure that pork products are exported in increasing amounts. I am just saying these things to indicate the tough competition that Australian primary producers have to face in the world market-places which they cannot meet unless they have sympathetic treatment from the Government.

I am concerned that the European Community's Commissioner for External Relations, Mr Willy De Clercq, during his recent visit here, proposed a freeze on agricultural export subsidies pending agreement with the United States of America to do likewise. Yet in his address to the National Press Club he maintained that the EC would retaliate if the United States or any other country decided to increase its agricultural export subsidies. At the same time it has been reported that the European Commissioners are seeking an additional $4 billion war chest to use for their dairy and beef subsidies. Before any progress can be made on freezing subsidies the countries involved have to reach agreement on the definition and measurement of subsidies. This will not be easy and the issue is as contentious as the subsidies themselves. If we are to reach some degree of balance with this whole mess some sort of meaningful dialogue must be established. To achieve this there must be a willingness of all parties to reach a conclusion. Now that there is a Democrat controlled House and Senate in the United States, a new wild card has been thrown into the deck.

Australia is in a difficult position because, on the one hand, products such as pig meat may be coming into the country from Canada with a subsidised price tag but at the same time we are encouraging our producers to become more efficient and export oriented. The argument about exotic diseases from other parts of the world being introduced to Australia via pork is reasonable because of the serious result which would occur. As I said earlier in my few words, I thank the Minister for the positive contribution that he has made. Nevertheless, the real solution to the subsidy problem is to address the fundamental and structural problems associated with both the EC and United States farm industries. At the same time, we must take heed of the problems they are faced with and endeavour to make sure we do not fall into the same traps with the same expensive results. This is a difficult problem and there are no easy solutions.

In conclusion, I just want to say, as a primary producer myself, that it is interesting to note the changing emphasis in the attitude of rural producers in the last decade. They are only too willing now to contribute out of their own funds-although in many instances they may be close to bankruptcy-for research and promotion. That is absolutely essential. This, of course, is to ensure that we have a great conversion of grain and supplements into pork, that we have the quickest possible growth rates, and that the product is promoted. Other countries, such as New Zealand, spend far greater amounts of money on promotion, are more expert at it and have a capacity to seek out markets and to target on to those markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak to the Pig Industry Bill 1986, the Pig Industry (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1986 and the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1986. We in the Opposition support these Bills. I believe that the industry itself is more or less in favour of the measures. It is not 100 per cent in support; there are some things that it is still not happy about, but overall it seems to be reasonably supportive of the changes that are taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: Before coming to the guts of the Bills, I wish to congratulate Denis Hinton, a past president of the Queensland Pork Producers Association, on being part of that fantastic election in the State of Queensland a few weeks ago. He has been elected as a back bench member for the seat of Broadsound and I do not doubt that he will do a fantastic job in the Queensland House representing pork producers, primary producers and all the other people in his electorate. As well, I wish to congratulate my local member for Balonne, Mr Don Neal, who has been elevated to the Queensland Ministry. He has also been involved in the pork industry and he represents a number of pork producers in his State electorate. I am sure that he will do an excellent job as a new Minister. In passing, I wish to inform the House, as other members have, that the National Party in Queensland is now governing in its own right with 53 per cent of the second preference vote and 55 per cent of the seats. It is time that we buried forever the sort of Press reports that were put around about the election result. People such as Mr Denis Hinton and Mr Don Neal will continue to do that for our National Party in Queensland--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is appropriate to the pig debate, is it?

—Yes, it is, because the National Party has been very supportive of the pig industry in Australia. Many of the pork producers of Australia live in inland Queensland. Many producers have moved into the pork industry from the grain industry. I do not doubt that that move will be accelerated with the downturn of the grain industry. Many producers have been converting grain into pork and they have been very successful. Some of the bigger grain growers have now established huge piggeries in this country and have done so very successfully. That includes the past Leader of our Party, Mr Doug Anthony, who has been in the pig producing industry for many years. We in the National Party pride ourselves on the fact that we have a knowledge of the industry and many members of our Party are in that industry. It is important for us to see that the changes continue and to ensure that they are the sorts of changes that the producers want.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to mention the wild pig program which the Government has introduced. I congratulate the Government on attempting to get this program under way. Unfortunately it has not allocated very much money to the program, but I hope that some more funds will be available and I look forward to the day when some of these funds are spent in my electorate of Maranoa. Not only do we have an enormous kangaroo problem in that part of Australia, but we also have an enormous population of wild pigs. The wild pig problem is tied in with foot and mouth disease control. We dread the day when foot and mouth disease might break out in Australia and we have to attempt to eradicate all the wild pigs in the country. It will be a tremendous task.

We have had a matter of public importance today highlighting Australia's debt position and the high interest rates for primary producers, including pork producers, in this country. At lunch time members of the Livestock and Grain Producers Association spoke to us and put their case on behalf of pork producers of this country and other farmers. The continuing alarmingly high interest rates are affecting the efficient production of these foodstuffs and making it terribly difficult for many of these businesses to continue. For pork production particularly, high-tech, disease-free piggeries are needed. It costs millions of dollars to build and operate them and to supply the consumers with a quality and disease-free product. This industry, as much as any, is affected by the horrendous interest rates and the problems of meeting interest bills and at the same time remaining in business.

I wish to quote quickly some of the figures that were given today by the LGPA. Only 28 per cent of farmers have no debt-that is a very small number. The rest of Australia's primary producers carry some sort of debt. Of those, 10 per cent carry 37 per cent of the total farm debt; 20 per cent have 58 per cent; 30 per cent have 73 per cent of that debt; and 40 per cent have 85 per cent of the total debt. One can see from those figures that unfortunately for us, with a downturn of markets throughout the world and the fact that we must continue to compete under ever increasing costs, primary producers and in particular pork producers are finding it very difficult to remaining in business.

These Bills establish the Australian Pork Corporation and the Pig Industry Policy Council. The new Corporation has a wider range of functions than the Pork Promotion Committee which it replaces. It will become involved with price setting and will give advice to the Minister about the sorts of levies and so on that should be imposed and the marketing arrangements, such as computer aided livestock marketing. The pork industry has been at the forefront of computerised marketing. It was one of the first industries to introduce classification of its product and to sell under the present electronic marketing arrangements. The industry has reached a stage where it is no longer necessary to have buyers physically in attendance; it is all being done on a television screen and people do not have to go out into the field in order to buy. These great advances are taking place, not only in the pork industry, but also in the beef and sheep meat industries. The pork industry has been one of the pioneers of these changes. I am sure that all honourable members who have had a chance to look at these aspects will realise that the pork industry is more technically advanced than most manufacturing industries.

I have also had the privilege of speaking to Mr Fred Hillier, who is the Chairman of the Queensland Pork Producers Association. He is concerned about the fact that producers have lost control of the levy. The Minister will still have control of that. As a producer, Mr Hillier feels that the Minister should not have the final say. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) shakes his head but perhaps his public relations is not the best. I can assure the Minister that Mr Hillier told me that the producers are concerned about some of the control being taken away from them. They are no longer in a position to have the absolute control that they once had over setting the levy.

The new Australian Pork Corporation will consist of seven members-an independent Chairman, a government representative and five members with expertise in pig production, pig meat processing, et cetera. The five expert members will be selected by the Australian Pork Corporation's selection committee. The Australian Pig Industry Policy Council will also be set up under this legislation. It will have eight members including an independent Chairman. Under this Council there will be a meeting of a number of special interest groups to decide on the future policy of the industry. The levies will be collected on the pigs slaughtered in Australia for human consumption. The Australian Pork Corporation will be responsible for recommendations to the Minister. I believe that it is important to note that it will make only recommendations, not final decisions. Unfortunately under these Bills the industry always gives away some of its independence. It must now make recommendations and the Minister will have the final say on the levy. The slaughter levy that was paid to the Pork Promotions Committee will now be paid to the Corporation and the maximum levy will be increased from $1 to $1.50.

The pig industry is well organised, as I said. It is experiencing a rapid increase in production. Average consumption now is 16.5 kilograms per person per year. An amount of $15m has been spent on promotion since 1975 and $4m has been allocated for 1986-87. Of every $1 of the slaughter levy, 80c is spent on promotion. In not only the pork industry but also other meat industries we are having a great debate at present as to how much money we should be spending on promotion. I believe that in the present day and age, because we have ever increasing competition in our markets, we must continue to expend as much money on it as we can physically afford. It is difficult for us sometimes even to pay these levies, particularly in slump times. In the cattle industry the slaughter levy is often as high as the price of cattle. It is now up to $8 a head. In the real crunch period of the beef industry we are not able to get that sort of money for our cattle.

That is one of the dangers in introducing these compulsory levies. They are all right when times are good, but when times are tough and we are not getting very good prices for our stock it is often difficult to pay the levy. It becomes due before the producer sees a cheque, and there are many instances of producers having to forward a cheque to their agents to cover the costs of selling their stock, be they in the pork, beef or sheep meat industries. The pork industry is spending much more of its funds on promoting its product, including recipe promotion and new cuts of pork. It has done an excellent job in that area. Consumption of pork is up by 40 per cent since 1982-83 and I think that is an excellent performance in anybody's book. I do not wish to add any more to the debate. There is in front of me a much more competent person, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), who wishes to speak. I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) for his obvious confidence in me. I rise to speak on the Pig Industry Bill and cognate Bills because I feel that they are important. I am one of the few people actively involved in the pig industry who are also members of this Parliament.
—Very successfully involved.

—I thank the honourable member. I notice that former members of parliament have also been involved in the pig industry. I refer to people such as the Rt Hon. Doug Anthony, the former leader of the National Party, who is a very large pig producer as well as being a dairy operator. I also note that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has had some interest in the pig industry over the last few years at the other end of the industry to the one I have been involved in. I have been involved in the production end; he has been involved in the slaughtering end. I suppose that it is fair to say that, since becoming a member of this Government, his activities have been much the same in that he and his colleagues have been busily slaughtering the economy. It is the economy, of course, which is affecting the pig industry at present.

SPEECH.PARA: As other speakers have said in this debate, interest rates are severely affecting the pig industry at present. I can speak with some personal experience on this. When money was borrowed to make extensions to piggeries to increase productivity and efficiency it was done at a rate of about 12 per cent. Today the interest rate on those moneys borrowed only a couple of years ago is in the order of 20 per cent. Unfortunately the industry is not sufficiently profitable to carry such huge increases in the cost of interest. One of the great bugbears of the industry is that it is so capital intensive. In order to be an efficient producer of pig meats today one has to have very extensive capital expenditure. One has to have an intensive piggery to be able to operate profitably and efficiently today. Unless one is prepared to borrow funds, I am afraid to say, one will not be an efficient pig producer in the future. So the cost of interest has been the great burden that this Government has placed upon the pig producers of Australia.

Whilst we cannot really do much about the world prices of our agricultural commodities, because Australia is not a big producer except in areas such as wool, we really can do something about some of these internally created costs such as interest rates. I strongly urge the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), if there is one thing he can do in this Government to really help not just pig producers but all farmers, to do something to reduce the cost of interest to the figure it was two or three years ago-10 to 12 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —For all Australians.

—As my colleague says, if he could do that for farmers, it would be of great benefit to all Australians. I am pleased that this legislation has been introduced into the House because the Bill creating the Australian Pork Corporation has broad support from within the industry. This Corporation will replace the existing body, the Pork Promotion Committee. Of course, the Pork Promotion Committee has served the industry very well over the years but, because the pig industry is a very dynamic industry, times change and, with them, the various aspects of the industry have to be upgraded to keep up. The Pork Promotion Committee will be replaced by this Australian Pork Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is important for me to correct in the House a few of the misconceptions that exist in our society and indeed within this Parliament. Many of these corporations involved in agricultural industries are totally self-funded by the industries. There are no Commonwealth funds or State funds going into the establishment or maintenance of this organisation. I am afraid to say that many people in the community believe that, when an organisation such as this is set up, it will be a burden on the taxpayer. This is not so. The pig industry will pay the entire cost of running and establishing this Corporation. I think that point has to be made clear, because the misconception is popularly held both in this House and outside it.

The pig industry is one of the great success stories of agriculture. I cannot recall an industry which has been more successful. The gross value of production in the pig industry has risen in the last 10 years from $197m to $450m. That is more than a doubling in the value of the production of pork in 10 years, a huge increase in anybody's book. It is to the great credit of people involved in the industry. The reason the pig industry has expanded so much is that it has been prepared to promote itself properly. As a result of promoting itself properly, consumption has increased quite substantially. Previous speakers have pointed out that in the last 10 years or so consumption of pork meat has increased from 12 kilograms per head per year to in excess of 16 kilograms per head per year. The reason this has taken place is that the pork industry is made up of people who are management, promotion and marketing oriented. They have gone about promoting their product in a most aggressive and imaginative way. I will give an example of the sort of promotion that they engage in. I come from a town called Young, which is quite a significant pig producing area. Each year at the Young show the pork industry has a stand in the main pavilion with a chef who displays the latest cuts of pork meat. He cooks the pork in various styles and, through a microphone, talks to all the people who go by to try to promote new ways of cutting pork meat and of cooking it. This is an ongoing promotional campaign which has resulted in increased consumption of pig meats and which has added to the general viability of the industry.

I mentioned earlier that the pork industry has grown rapidly. It has grown not only because of promotion and marketing but also because there has been a great deal of improvement in the actual management that people in the industry are prepared to undergo. One of the great benefits of the pig industry is that pig gradings are now such that producers are really forced to produce a product that the market demands. One of the unfortunate aspects of other meat producing industries such as the beef or sheep industries is that they are unable to quickly meet the ever-changing eating habits of our society. The pig industry is able to do that because it is a much more disciplined industry. What has happened over the years is that the pig industry has recognised that the eating habits of people have changed. People are now more health conscious and require less fat in their meat, therefore the pig industry has been able to change the way it markets its product so that the pigs do not have as much fat in them to meet the changing needs of our consumer society.

There have been some major improvements in techniques of management, but there is still a long way to go before Australian pork producers will match the performance of some other countries. I have met English pig producers who brag of getting in the order of 30 to 32 pigs per sow per year as an average, whereas if an Australian pig producer can brag that he has averaged 20 pigs per sow per year, he is doing very well. There is a long way to go before Australian pig managers will be able to match the performances of overseas pig producers, but we have increased our production figures over the years through increased genetics and management techniques.

Every pig manager in this country is aware of the fact that it is vitally important to have a proper environment in which to raise pigs. One of the unfortunate things that has occurred in our society over the past few years is the way in which the animal liberation movement has given a false impression of what goes on inside intensive piggeries. We are led to believe by the animal liberationists that piggeries are the Australian version of concentration camps. This is not so at all. Every producer understands that a healthy, happy pig is a productive pig and therefore a profitable pig, and profit is the name of the game in the pig business. People who do not have a healthy, happy pig will not have a profitable piggery, therefore they will be out of business very quickly and the piggery will close down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you sign them up in the National Party if they are happy, healthy pigs?

—All good pig managers are members of the National Party of Australia because they are good businessmen and understand that the policies of our Party are the best policies for those people who are prepared to go into business to make a profit, to create wealth, jobs and so forth.

SPEECH.PARA: The animal liberation movement has not done justice to the pig industry. Anybody who is prepared to take a little bit of time and trouble to go through an intensive piggery will understand the care and concerns that every pig manager has for the well-being of the animals under his control. I say to honourable members and all the people who are listening today: Do not believe what the animal liberationists tell you because they try to play on your emotions. They make false statements and try to create a false impression. By attacking the pig industry in a concerted way, they may well put at risk an industry which is very important to this economy-an industry which is growing rapidly, producing $450m of wealth and employing a lot of people. It would be a very sad day if the animal liberationists affected the long term viability of our industry.

The new Australian Pork Corporation will further enhance the management and promotion aspects of the pig industry. It will help the establishment of computer aided livestock marketing-CALM-and it will add further to the development of the national livestock language, commonly called Ausmeat. It will add to the necessary tools of a dynamic, growing and profitable industry. I know that the Corporation will be well received by the industry. It will not be involved in price setting schemes, nor will it be a trading body, but it will be involved in marketing issues which affect the pig industry. I hope that the whole scheme will be happily financed by the industry. Most of the pork producers I speak to are happy to pay the levy on each pig slaughtered for domestic human consumption. I reiterate that the Corporation will be funded totally by the industry; no taxpayers' funds will go into it. The body will be fully accountable to the Parliament, the people of Australia and the industry. I commend this Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this legislation and offers it clear passage through the Parliament.
