The introduction of proprietorial ownership of commercially bred plant varieties has fuelled many emotions both for and against the concept over many years. However, when these arguments are weighed one against the other I am left in no doubt that the net benefits of plant variety rights well outweigh any drawbacks. Plant variety rights will encourage new private sector research to complement existing public research for a wide range of cropping and vegetable industries. Among those to benefit most will be cereal growers, who are among the hardest hit by the rural recession and many of whom will suffer a net income loss again in 1986-87. I remind the House again of the figures brought forward by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics earlier this year, that farm incomes are likely to drop by $4,000 per farm over this coming period, so if there is to be a benefit let us hope that it will be in the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only can we expect intensified research in Australia, but also plant and seed users will enjoy access to new plant species from overseas through the introduction of reciprocal agreements with our trading partners. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has correctly pointed to PVR giving a significant boost to our farm industries, allowing farmers and nurserymen to compete more effectively on world markets. It would be appropriate for us to view Australia's situation in this world market in the current crisis facing the exporters of Australia.

We see from the trading results of the past four months not only that the projection of $14.7 billion deficit in the current account this year will be met, but it will be exceeded. Again, it is within the trading sector that it is of particular relevance. If we look at the balance of trade figures on the goods side alone, the last year in which Australia had a real trade surplus was 1979-80. From 1980-81 to the current year in only one year, 1983-84, did we have a small surplus. Australia is a nation that has to trade to survive. I believe the deficit is of major interest and concern to us all.

Let me turn to the current account figures. The last occasion of a credit in this regard was 1972. Since then the deficit has progressed downwards to what was, last year, $13.7 billion. This year it is $14.7 billion. It has been estimated that the deficit, to keep in track with the October deficit of $1.7 billion, will have run at an average of $1.1 billion for the next 8 months. This crisis is a major concern to primary industry and to everybody in Australia. I have just mentioned Australia's trading results. Let us turn now to accumulated foreign debt. It has been estimated by an economist that while the Hawke Labor Government was in office from March 1983 to June 1986 our net foreign debt tripled. It has gone from $22 billion to $66 billion. The analogy is often made that whereas it took Australia 81 years to reach $22 billion, it took Labor only three years to triple it to $66 billion. The figures that we have heard suggest that our foreign debt is exploding. It is in the vicinity of $100 billion. Any boost to our export performance in the trade sector will be very good news not only for the exporters but for all Australians. It has to be repeated that trade deficits will affect every Australian. No Australian can feel that he is quarantined against the effects of our overall trading position. The standard of living of every Australian can only deteriorate with the figures I have mentioned. This will be an indication to the person in the street that his own standard of living will decrease. Interest rates are at a high level. These are features of a deteriorating trade situation.

Unfortunately we could have had plant variety rights four years ago. The Liberal-National Party Government then recognised a need to bring Australia into line with statutory rights which have been available for several years in most developed countries. The Fraser Government brought legislation into this Parliament in 1981, but the present Minister, by his own admission in his second reading speech, was responsible for delaying the Plant Variety Rights Bill which ultimately led to it lapsing. His reasoning was to seek further public consideration of the concept of PVR. This was in spite of the fact that interest in plant variety right first emerged in Australia in the 1960s. One wonders why extra public consideration was necessary in 1980. This was followed by several inquiries in the 1970s-notably the Industries Assistance Commission report on rural research in 1976 which strongly recommended introduction of plant variety rights. Draft versions of the 1981 Bills were circulated up to two years before they were introduced into this House. Then they lay on the table for another 12 months. Despite all the opportunity given for public debate, parliamentary debate and formulation of an opinion, the Australian Labor Party allowed the Bill to lapse and has dragged its feet until now. Australia has waited an additional four years for PVR legislation to come back into this Parliament. It is unfortunate that while the Minister for Primary Industry has now stressed the benefit of PVR, Australian agriculture has not had the benefit of this boost since 1982 to help it overcome one of the worst economic crises on record.

I want to give evidence of that economic crisis, as is evidenced within the primary production area. I speak on behalf of any primary producer who is listening. They have faced difficulties, compared with three, four, ten or 20 years ago, in making ends meet and trying to make a profit. Today they are facing record interest rates. Earlier today in this House on the debate on interest rates an indication was given that prime rates of interest that would be available in the most favourable circumstances to our primary producers were now at 18.5 per cent-5 per cent higher than they were when Labor took office in 1983.

Let us look at inflation. The recent quarter was a record for this Government and shows that the inflation rate for the 12 months will be greatly in excess of what was predicted. On top of that, primary producers, above anybody else, know the on-costs they face because of government charges and taxes. Do I have to remind this House of the effects of the fringe benefits tax for work related benefits being taxed to the employer? This can lead only to a deterioration in the work situation. I also indicate the reduced development incentives through taxation and the capital gains tax that has been introduced in this House.

I want to compare this Government's economic record with the rest of the world. I stress that the interest rate of 18.5 per cent is the prime rate and is about three times higher than that available to our competitors overseas. Examples which have been given in this House show that while our interest has been increasing by 5 per cent in the last three years, the prime interest rate available to producers throughout other countries, our competitors, has been at a lesser rate and has been decreasing. Let us look at the inflation rate. Some of our competitors are now benefiting from a negative inflation compared to our own inflation which we believe will probably go back into double digit figures this year. Australia's inflation rate, which represents a cost to our producers, will be about three or four times higher than our competitors. When the Government talks about the wonderful benefits of devaluation, it does not add in the additional costs that have been brought about in interest through inflation and the price of imports. We should never let the Labor Government forget that a lot of the problems facing primary industry today were deliberately created and put as an impediment in the way of the primary producers by this same Government.

There are some flaws in the plant variety rights to which I will refer in a moment. The central principle of plant variety rights is to allow plant breeders to apply for proprietary rights over any new variety of plant which they develop. Endorsement of the concept has come from the IAC reports on rural research in 1976, apple and pear industries in 1985 and the vegetable product industries this year. Support has also come from the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, the Lazenby inquiry into Australia's plant breeding needs and the 1985 Committee of Inquiry into Grape and Wine Industries, known as the McKay report.

Among the most vocal supporters of PVR, and one to whom we should pay credit, is Senator Robert Hill who has fought a frustrating battle in Opposition to gain support for his private member's Bill. I have no doubt that the action of Senator Hill has helped catalyse events leading to the introduction of this Bill. The plant breeders and plant industries of Australia owe him a great vote of thanks for helping to keep the issue of PVR on the boil in this Parliament.

The benefits of this Bill now before the House may be summarised under three main categories. We are likely to see, firstly, a stimulus to private sector research; secondly, a faster and wider-ranging development of new varieties; and, thirdly, improved access for Australians to overseas varieties. While there is likely to be some shift in research emphasis from the public to the private sector, there should be a substantial improvement in the overall research level in Australia. The scheme is voluntary. Once granted, rights will attract an annual fee over the 20 years for which they will apply. As the scheme will be open to overseas as well as Australian breeders, I would expect to see an improvement in our access to international genetic varieties.

I just want to emphasise again the part that primary industry plays in our trade balance and the part that it must play in the future. Some people would suggest, and I would agree with them, that the way out of our present trade imbalance lies with our services and manufacturing industries. But the difficulty is that, by the time the risk is calculated and they have the stability to make an investment and bring that investment to the point of production, even with the best of good will and the best of intentions of a government that is helpful and not negative towards the manufacturing sector, it could take months and years to come to fruition. It will take some years to flatten that playing field so that everybody can relate to a consistent and practical government economic policy. In the meantime, no Australian and no exporter, whether he be in primary industry, in minerals or in the manufacturing industry, should underestimate the need for Australian primary industry to maintain and try to increase its portion of world trade. Immediate relief could be given by Bills such as this to that balance of trade figure.

In addition, Australia will seek membership of an international convention extending benefits of domestic rights to overseas markets. Any plant breeder or public or private gardener will be able to obtain rights, as will overseas breeders. Rights may be transferred, surrendered or revoked if the grantee does not meet conditions of the grant or pay the annual licence fees. Complementary amendments will be required to the Trade Practices Act to grant an exclusive proprietary right over a variety.

The Bill includes an appeal mechanism, and any legal action to protect rights may be pursued by breeders through the Federal Court of Australia. A major review of the scheme will be conducted after its first five years of operation. Rights will not restrict the sale of plants for use as food or any other purpose that does not involve the growing of the plants. Importantly, to be eligible for PVR the variety must be new and distinguishable from other known varieties. It must be bred by the applicant and not drawn from a natural or wild environment.

While these provisions overcome many of the initial fears held over plant variety rights, especially by the farm community, some doubts remain. We should remember that, despite all the deliberations, discussions, soul searching and inquiries, this Bill still does not convey rights to any particular species or genus. A committee will be established to advise the Minister on which genus or species will be granted protection under the legislation. I do not disagree with the idea of an advisory panel, but I do draw a note of caution concerning that panel and I suggest that it is a caution that the Minister should take on board and understand.

The Minister's instructions to the new committee that it consult widely before making recommendations should not be used as a delaying tactic which might effectively defer action on PVR for some years. Using the New Zealand experience as a guide we will be well into the 1990s before most species are covered and it may be a couple of years before any species or genus is included.

As I have said before, after four years of delay, the Opposition is heartily sick and tired of these delays and what could be further delays in this regard. This Parliament has waited for too long for the PVR legislation. To induce further delays in its implementation would be nothing short of scandal. The Government's performance will be closely watched in this regard by the Opposition and there will be no excuses for delays.

The Australian Labor Party, having been dragged kicking to this point where we have the legislation, must now accept the legislation as a positive contribution to the overall plant development effort in Australia and must facilitate the operation of the Act.

I turn to some matters of specific interest to particular industries and community groups. One concern raised frequently has been that farmers may not be permitted to save patented seed for a new season's crop. The Opposition's understanding of the legislation is that farmers and home gardeners will be able to keep seed or other propagating material for their own use. It is unclear in the legislation whether this extends to commercial crops. So I call upon the Minister to answer this concern before the legislation passes this House. It is unfortunate that the Minister responsible is not in the House at the moment. But I hope that, in his response to the second reading debate, he will indicate whether he can answer the concern we have.

The grains industry has flagged to the Opposition some concern over possible exclusion of growers from important varieties should the recipient of rights be selective in the allocation of the new variety. Naturally PVR incorporates commercial risks in developing species, so there will be commercial considerations which will govern the distribution of such seed or other propagation material. There will, of course, be a continuing industry and public research effort as well as the expected new private research. The network of plant genetic resource centres established by the Federal and State governments will be one open source of raw material for plant research. It might be helpful to the industry, though, if the Minister for Primary Industry could give wheat growers, in particular, an assurance that he will carefully monitor progress on this issue. Should major grievances arise on the part of the industry, there may be a case for a careful and exhaustive review of the PVR scheme's operation as it affects wheat growers, if necessary prior to the five-year review which is already planned.

I know that the concerns over possible denials of access to crucial new varieties are shared by growers in all of the wheat, barley, sorghum, rye, triticale, millet, maize, oats, grain legumes and oilseeds industries. This body of opinion must not be ignored by the Minister, and he will have a responsibility to maintain close contact on the operation of PVR with the grains councils of Australia. It is not sufficient for the Minister to bring this legislation into the House and have it passed. He has a continuing responsibility to monitor the effects of the legislation in the future.

A Sydney lady has raised the fear that voluntary charitable causes may be disadvantaged by this legislation. She has pointed out to the Opposition that her own work has raised several hundred dollars through the sale of plants at school fetes and other such functions. Further, these activities tend to encourage children to take an interest in gardening and the broader subject of botany. She has said that it would be an outrage if this were to be denied through unexpected restrictions flowing from this Bill. I doubt that such restrictions would be an intended consequence of the legislation, but I call on the Minister to allay these fears. Beyond these matters, some claims have been made which I consider to be of a rather wild nature.

Many criticisms of PVR concerning genetic resources, market structure and the impact on the Third World are issues quite independent of PVR. It should be noted that Australia has established an aid program for agricultural research in developing countries. Further, under the auspices of the consultative group for international agricultural research Australia contributes to the operation of 13 research institutes in the developing world.

This legislation is long overdue but it carries the support of the Liberal and National parties. The costs to taxpayers are minimal compared with the likely benefits in terms of improved production across many plant industries, and, as I have said, the effects of our trade situation with the rest of the world. Administrative costs of $700,000 in the start-up three-year period will be partially offset by expected revenue of $150,000. Further, revenue is likely to increase in future years as PVR is spread across a wider range of industries to a point where the scheme should be self-funding. The Opposition, although concerned over delays which I have mentioned, commends the Minister for Primary Industry for adopting plant variety rights and will give this legislation passage through the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1986. However, I do so with some concerns. First, I want to outline briefly the concept of the Bill, which is to grant a proprietary right to the breeder of new varieties of certain plants that will give the owner of the right the ability to sell the new varieties in a restricted market. Such a right can most easily be compared with the principle underlying patent and copyright legislation to give protection to the invention. Normally, inventions are made and designed by man. What we are doing here is altering something that was not made by man and enabling the right to that product to be owned mainly by a very exclusive number of people, mainly large multinational companies.

SPEECH.PARA: The system of plant variety rights exists in many countries, including the United Kingdom, Japan, West Germany, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the United States of America and New Zealand. Plant variety rights were first introduced in the United Kingdom in 1964. The first rights were issued in 1965. Under the system, rights can exist for between 15 and 25 years and can apply to agricultural crops, field crops, vegetables, fruits and ornamentals. There are a number of arguments both for and against PVR. The major arguments in favour of the system are that it will encourage increased plant breeding in Australia as breeders will be able to recoup the funds necessary to create new varieties; that it will facilitate access to new varieties bred in other countries with a PVR system; and that it will assist the development of an export industry.

The major arguments against PVR concern their effects on the lesser developed countries and the genetic stock, which is what interests me. It is argued that the system of PVR adversely affects the lesser developed countries as they will become more reliant on seed stock that has to be imported from the more developed countries. If they refuse to pay, they will be deprived of the more productive crops. The concern over genetic stock is that the range available for future use will be drastically reduced and will get into fewer and fewer hands, and that much of the genetic stock that has been developed by nature will cease to be available.

As mentioned in the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), India had approximately 30,000 varieties of rice at the turn of the century but only 30 varieties are now in use. However, much of the genetic stock is preserved for future use by national and international bodies such as the International Board for Plant Genetic Resources. That is what begins to worry me. If our seeds that were created by nature are stored by various governmental bodies, who has access to these seeds?

Recently, my sister, who lives at Kongwak, which is a fairly good farming area, tried to get some seeds from a State government organisation in Victoria-the Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands. They were seeds for native trees and plants. However, when she rang there, she found that the seeds were not available. They could not be sold to her because they were out of stock. I rang recently and asked why they were out of stock. I was told that it was because there had been some changes within the State government department and it was temporarily not collecting seed or distributing it. It did not have any for any State government departments in Victoria which may want to seed some trees anywhere in Victoria. It just did not have the seed. Will these State instrumentalities run out in the future and not have any seed? Will it be available to people such as me? These are the sorts of worries that I have.

I would like to give a perfect example of plant variety rights already practised here in Australia. I am talking about the humble cabbage. I am a bit of an amateur gardener. I went to my local seed store to buy some cabbage seeds. I have here six packets of different cabbage seeds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to table them?

—I cannot table them. Only one of them is not a hybrid seed. Hybrid means that the seeds cannot be kept; that is, if I grow these cabbages in my back yard and I want to keep the seeds to be able to grow these particular cabbages again, that will not work, because they will not grow again. What this means is that every year I have to buy new seeds. After a while, there will not be any original seed stock left in Australia; there will be only hybrid seeds or seeds held under PVR. What will happen in 20 years time when, say the Liberal Party of Australia of the National Party of Australia gets into power and there is some sort of depression and I want to grow my own food? I will have to buy the seed every year. I will not be able to collect the seed and keep it until the next year because the seed will not work. Those are the problems that come with PVR.

SPEECH.PARA: I have noted that some National Party members are speaking in this debate. They should be speaking in this debate because they should be very concerned about what will happen to their farmers. I am not talking about the immediate future; I am talking about the long term future. What will happen in 20 years time if, say, there is one type of wheat seed which has proved to be better than all the others in the world? Let us say that it gives a better crop, a better head, and that one gets so many more bags per acre from this seed. Let us say that the only way one can grow this seed is to have a particular type of chemical. This happens now with many crops where one has to have certain chemicals to make them grow. Let us say that all of these chemicals are controlled by big multinational companies. The Shell company has moved into the agricultural business in a big way in developing seeds. What if it controlled this particular type of seed and this particular type of chemical? It could hold countries to ransom.

Food is a most important thing. We would not be here without it. We would not be here without the efforts of our farmers who grow it. In many years time we may not be able to exist without a particular type of seed and chemical fertiliser. Let us say, once again, that the whole of the Mallee had been planted with this type of wheat and that for some unknown reason some pest or virus had attacked and wiped out the whole crop. Where would the diversity of seed come from to make certain that this did not happen? Would everybody have access to it? As I have already illustrated, even today, through one government body, the average person does not have access to a particular native tree seed. What will happen in 20 years time? This is the problem that I am concerned about.

The Plant Variety Rights Bill contains a clause which provides for a limited life or a limited amount of time for the patents. But we will not be around in the distant future. This Bill has far-reaching consequences. It should be looked at very closely. We should make certain that seed stock is kept not just by government agencies but also by private agencies. I am pleased to know that there is one in Tasmania which has been acting very responsibly by building up seed stock and making it available to people throughout Australia.

I have put some arguments against this Bill. The arguments for it are that it will give some people, who have put a lot of work into developing new seeds and new strains of plants and fruit, some sort of protection. But we should look closely at this Bill. Perhaps there should even be a sunset clause in the whole Bill so that in 20 or 30 years time we can look at it and, if it is not working correctly, take steps to correct it. I hope there is a large seed stock that can be distributed freely throughout the country and we will not have to rely on one particular company or its products to enable us to survive. Our Government has decided that we will put this legislation through. It has been on the books for a long time; I know that.

In 1986 the European Parliament passed a strong resolution of concern regarding transnational concentration in the European seed trade, of which they have had experience for some years, the elimination of small scale producers and the serious loss of local plant varieties. Many years ago I read a science fiction novel called The Death of Grass. It showed what could happen if some disease wiped out all our grass and the problems it would cause. One has only to think of that sort of thing happening to a particular strain of wheat, rice or barely to realise how it could affect many people throughout the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) shows unnecessary concern about the Plant Variety Rights Bill. He is concerned about hybrids, multinational fertiliser companies et cetera. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) went to great lengths in his second reading speech to allay those concerns, and I suggest that world experience has not indicated that those sorts of concerns should be of paramount importance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is delighted that the Government has finally seen the need for plant variety rights legislation in Australia. The Bill is substantially similar to the Plant Variety Rights Bill of 1981, which was tabled by the then Minister for Primary Industry, Peter Nixon. The legislation we are discussing today has some slight though not substantial changes to the previous Bill. That we did not have this legislation in place in the early 1970s showed a lack of foresight by government, but it is quite another matter that this legislation was ready to go when the Hawke Government came to power and it has been delayed for over 3 1/2 years. It has been critical for Australian agricultural industries to have this legislation for over 15 years, and I cannot help believing that we have caused a permanent stunting of the development of our agricultural export industries because of this lack of care by successive governments. In fact, the delay of this legislation is an example of how pseudo-intellectuals of the greeny-type can confuse the arguments, and deny legislation which would benefit everyone in Australia. It is about vocal minorities, which have had no commercial interest in an industry, holding sway.

The Minister in his second reading speech was obviously very sensitive to these groups, who are only experts on the red herring and the white elephant. Obviously he has been listening to the honourable member for Dunkley.

TALK.START.PARA: —Other members, too.

—Others too? Will we have a division on the Bill? So sensitive in fact was the Minister to these groups that he delayed the legislation for 3 1/2 years, having waited through all the debate and reporting from various groups that occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: It would have been a difficult time to ignore the pleas from the industry. During August and September last year I received over 65 different letters from horticulturalists, farmers, plant breeders, dairymen, crop growers and home gardeners requesting my support to have this legislation introduced. We had a private members Bill introduced in the Senate on PVR by Senator Robert Hill. Nothing seemed to move the Government, until now, from its concentration on taxation reform-a deep regret which by now is shared by all Australians.

It is against this background that I would like to mention a few industries within my electorate. The wine industry in particular will benefit from access to varieties and genetic material from Europe and the United States of America. Some overseas programs have evolved disease resistant grape vine hybrids, which significantly reduce the need for chemical sprays. Australia up until now has relied upon the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation breeding station at Merbein, the State agricultural departments and the work undertaken by private wine companies. Even so these programs simply cannot compete with overseas vine breeding programs, some of which have been in operation for over 100 years. Through reciprocal agreements allowed under PVR legislation this breeding stock will now become available in Australia.

But this is little consolation at a time when the Australian wine industry has been forced into crisis by capricious acts of this Government-acts of pure irresponsibility such as lifting the customs duty on imported wines by 10 per cent, and in the same year introducing a wine sales tax of 10 per cent. The Government was lucky that the devaluation coincided with this decision to lift the customs duty, otherwise our producers would have been in a bigger mess. Despite the downturn this caused our wine industry, the Government imposed a further 10 per cent sales tax this year, totally against the advice of the McKay report on the grape and wine industry. It introduced a $2.61 per litre excise on alcohol used for fortification of wine, and then found that it had to be withdrawn before it precipitated a collapse in the industry, and unsettled the whole industry by trying to limit the amount of off-farm income which could be used as a write-off against farm losses. Everyone knows that wine producers have had negative incomes in four out of the last five years.

All these items are over and above the problems this Government has saddled all rural producers with, such as record interest rates, between double and treble those of our major trading partners; rises in fuel costs when the price of oil has fallen on world markets; the accord, mark 1 and 2, with its nonsensical wage indexation, and massive on costs in employing staff; and a tax reform package which had nothing to do with reform as it was all about increased taxation to the tune of $26.7 billion in just four Budgets. I hope this places the PVR legislation back into perspective. It is important, but the Government must not stop here, with just one good turn to an industry to make up for the litany of bad turns. If we do not have a healthy and viable domestic wine industry, grape growers will simply not be able to afford the new breeding stock which will now become available. Unless each grower can see a future for his product down the track, the price of investment-the Government must understand that many grape varieties take five to 10 years to reach a decent yield-will simply be far too high.

Australia has many areas which are better climatically than Europe for growing grapes. Australia should represent strong competition in the world wine markets. Yet our growers have been denied some excellent varieties used in making full-flavoured white table wine and there certainly has been increased demand for these wines. In the past 10 years wine imports into Australia have virtually doubled. In 1975-76 we imported 6,925 kilolitres, in 1985-86 that increased to 12,794 kilolitres. On the export side, in 1975-76 we exported 6,132 kilolitres and in 1985-86 that had increased only to 10,828 kilolitres. Something is seriously wrong, and that problem must be addressed by increased wine exports. To this end, certain improvements must be made to the export market development grants scheme. PVR legislation is one less impediment the wine industry will now face in setting the stage for Australia to return to the days of being a net wine exporter. Western Australian table grape growers will benefit significantly from access to European varieties, and I believe we shall see the commencement of a plant breeding industry with significant export potential in Western Australia now that they will be guaranteed reward and protection for their efforts.

The apple and pear industry will also benefit from PVR. Western Australia leads the States in apple export and my electorate leads the State by producing 72.4 per cent of the State's total product. Last year exports amounted to 558,320 boxes, and by far the majority went to South East Asian markets. Maintaining and developing these markets depends on maintaining our edge on price, quality of product, visual appeal and consistency. It is not just a matter of staying with varieties such as granny smith, delicious and jonathans and hoping all other varieties will go away. The concern is that new varieties, such as the United States of America bred prime gold, redchief or the oregan red sour, have gained strong acceptance on world markets, while Australian growers have been denied stock, simply because countries are unwilling to provide patented stock to Australia where there is no mechanism by which the material is afforded protection or royalties returned to the owner.

In the past private and public breeding organisations have simply been denied stock, although I believe in the absence of PVR legislation there have been a number of signed agreements between Australian purchasers and overseas breeders allowing for royalty payments to be made, while the purchaser has agreed not to repropagate the material. However this is no substitute for PVR legislation. This legislation will now give all parties who have agreed to the International Convention for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants confidence to deal with Australia. This current legislation is fairly precise and protective of the rights of all Australians regarding access to patented varieties of plants. It also protects the existing range of stock being patented. In case anyone is listening to the debate and cannot wait to lodge an application for his unique variety of garden rose or strange looking shrub that may be in the garden he may be disappointed.

Under this Bill the powers of the Parliament derive from paragraph 51 (xviii) of the Constitution which authorises laws, among other things, in respect of patents of inventions. A new variety amounts to an invention only if it is purposely bred. Rights will not be granted for simple discoveries where there is no element of invention. My reading of the Bill is that genuine native flora or chance seedlings would therefore not be patentable.

The third industry I would like also to make reference to is citrus fruits, which is facing its worst crisis in 10 years. The main problem is from Brazilian competition on the Australian market, and it will mean that citrus grower incomes from the processing sector will be reduced by 50 per cent or around $25m this season. One contributory factor is that there is a certain market preference for the low priced Brazilian orange juice concentrate which also has a lower sugar; acid ratio 14:1 and 17:1 than the Australian orange juice concentrate, which is 12:1 and 14:1. Further government legislation will exacerbate the problem. Mr Kemp said the citrus industry had experienced increased government activity over the past year, with the soon to be introduced model food standards regulation for orange juice, which amongst other things states that not more than 1.5 per cent sugar may be added without declaring it on the label; this was previously 4 per cent. This means that our juices, with lower sugar acid ratios of about 12:1 to 14:1, are at a disadvantage to imported juices which may be up to about 20:1 ratio but which normally are about 16.1. The converters require a juice of 15:1 sugar; acid ratio. Previously up to 4 per cent sugar could be added to bring most of our juices up to the required level, but now high ratio imported juice must be added to achieve this, so reducing local content in juices.

He said the recent legislation governing marketing boards and the introduction of new export and domestic market fresh fruit standards had all increased the work load of the industry and must be carefully considered to ensure it is beneficial to our industry. To my knowledge, it is the variety and, to a lesser degree, the horticultural practices which determine the sugar: acid ratio, and these factors are within the control of the industry. The crisis over the Brazilian imports has meant that growers are realising that the fresh fruit market will once again become the main income earner, with the juicing sector using the second grade fruit.

Again PVR is only one item among many issues which the industry would like the Government to resolve, such as the entry of products in overseas markets, food irradiation rationalising complex legislation and the streamlining of procedures relating to the importation of nursery stock material which has helped to retard the dynamism of the citrus industry in the past. Without doubt the immediate benefits of PVR will be seen in the whole range of fruit such as cherries, avocados, peaches, apricots, strawberries, nuts, gooseberries, the berry fruits, nectarines, plums and prunes. It will enable many of our growers to pick up on the specialised fruit export markets which have not developed as aggressively as some of our export competitors. I am very pleased to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Plant Variety Rights Bill provides for the granting of proprietary rights to persons originating new plant varieties, and for other purposes. In other words, it will allow a plant breeder to own a plant variety which has been created by selective breeding and to control its distribution, propagation, export and import for up to 20 years. I rise to speak on this Bill with reluctance and some regret. Indeed, it is my personal, preferred position that such legislation not be introduced at this time because I believe that many questions relating to plant variety rights remain unanswered. I say this despite the findings of the 1984 report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources plant variety rights inquiry and the more recent report of the Lazenby inquiry into Australia's plant breeding needs. I also recognise that my position on this legislation runs counter to the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission following inquiries into rural research in 1976, the apple and pear industries in 1985, and the vegetable and vegetable product industries in 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, I am mindful of the fact that the prospect of plant variety rights legislation was raised at the national conference of the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania earlier this year, and I appreciate the Government's objective of stimulating plant breeding in Australia. However, I am also aware that a large group of people in the community share my concerns on this issue. Contrary to the claims of the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond), it is not a small minority. These people genuinely believe that plant variety rights will have a detrimental effect on seed stocks and varieties world wide to the point at which the future of humanity may be under threat. People opposed to plant variety rights on these grounds come from all walks of life and represent a significant range of interest groups, including the religious, environmental and consumer communities.

Like some others on this side of the House, I have been studying the possible impact of PVR for a number of years. My misgivings arise from a long-standing concern over matters involving genetic engineering. They include a genuine fear that the worst effects of plant variety rights will be felt in the countries of the underdeveloped and/or developing world which are already inextricably dependent on the developed world for so much of their food and seed requirements. If people in Australia have concerns about new technologies, such as in vitro fertilisation and other new reproductive technologies, because they may be deemed to be forms of genetic engineering, how much more concerned would these same people be if they recognised the possible effects of plant variety rights?

The people who have approached me regarding this Bill have expressed a definite and dedicated opposition to the concept of patenting life forms. Furthermore, they believe that PVR will reduce genetic diversity and variability while enabling corporate plant breeders to gain monopoly rights over germ plasm, seeds and plants. I am inclined to agree with them.

In connection with the many expressed misgivings about this legislation, I would like to draw the attention of the House to a report which was endorsed by the European Parliament on 20 February 1986 and which specifically refers to the adverse consequences of multinational control of the seed industry. In passing, I note that the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) also referred to this report briefly. It is extremely pertinent to the debate on this Bill because most European countries have had plant variety rights-type legislation for more than 20 years. In the context of that experience the criticisms voiced by the European Parliament are even more alarming. They relate to the dramatic narrowing in the availability of plant genetic diversity, both species and varieties, which has led to more pesticide use and, accordingly, more pollution. It has also led to loss of plant breeding material, higher farm costs, fewer farmers, less consumer choice and a lower quality food.

The report implicitly acknowledges that plant breeders' rights have played a contributory role to these deleterious structural trends by specifically calling on those member states that have plant breeders' rights to ensure that `obstacles to the development of new varieties are removed' and that `information concerning new discoveries is circulated'. It further demands that germ plasm of all varieties of plant not be regarded and treated as private property. It calls on the member states to adopt the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation international undertaking on plant genetic resources. The report goes on to highlight the fact that plant patenting is significantly increasing the plight of the starving and malnourished in developing countries. European member nations have been requested to provide the following information by 1 January 1987: Statistics on the extent and effects of genetic erosion over the last three decades; analysis of the reasons for the drop in the number of plant varieties and species; suggestions on how member states and institutions could exert a positive influence in the matter of genetic diversity in the Third World countries; proposals for indirect economic measures to reduce genetic erosion; and, finally, emergency measures to safeguard genetic diversity.

It disturbs me that the Lazenby inquiry did not appear to have considered the report of the European Parliament on PVR. Australia should be heeding the experience of countries which have a negative view on plant variety rights, as well as those that have a positive view, especially on a matter with the complexity of imponderables that plant variety rights has. While I understand that there are primary producers who claim that this legislation is required to enable access to overseas seed sources and to new improved high yield plant varieties, I believe that they are seriously mistaken. My information leads me to believe that they are seriously mistaken. My information leads me to believe that there is currently no barrier to obtaining patented seed varieties from overseas for use in Australia. On the contrary, people have ordered patented material from seed catalogues and they have arrived in this country without any difficulty whatsoever bar our own protection mechanisms, which honourable members opposite, I am sure, would all support. I refer to the Australian Customs Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would all be hybrids, wouldn't they?

—They may be hybrids, but I am not sure that that will change. There is another reason why plant variety rights cause me concern, that is, its basic restriction on information. The scientific community has always maintained a protocol of information sharing for the benefit of human kind. How does plant variety rights with its obvious consequences of hoarding and secrecy fit into this protocol? Suffice it to say that plant variety rights makes exclusively held plant breeding material extremely valuable. Like my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley and, obviously the honourable member for Forrest, I have a continuing concern with the proliferation of mule or hybrid varieties of plants. While I am pleased that the Bill provides some protection for farmers and home gardeners by allowing them to retain seed from purchased PVR varieties for their own use, this provision cannot apply to hybrid plants. Although I know that the Minister has heard these arguments before and has given them consideration prior to introducing this legislation, I do not think they bear repeating today. I thank the Minister for his undertaking to review the effects of this legislation five years hence, at which time the information relating to plant variety rights may be even more categoric. Like the honourable member for Dunkley again, I would prefer that a sunset clause be inserted in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I urge the Minister to ensure that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation continues to experiment in plant productivity and disease resistance in its own right. Ironically, the resultant varieties may themselves need to be patented for protection of their integrity. (Quorum formed) Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker and honourable members. I had better repeat the last piece. I urge the Minister to ensure that the CSIRO continues to experiment in plant productivity and disease resistance in its own right. Ironically, the resultant varieties may themselves need to be patented for protection of their integrity. The distinction between the activities of the CSIRO and the activities of other plant breeders is that profit will not be the motivating force. Rather, I would expect that the CSIRO, as a government funded scientific institution, will have an obligation to the people of Australia, its producers and consumers, and will therefore create only those varieties which have no in-built dependence on fertilisers and pesticides. Should such pressures arise, its duty to resist is clear and unequivocal. No nation can afford to be trapped into a food production cycle which is entirely dependent on such factors for its yield and/or its survival. That road is the road of monopoly and domination, and it is certainly not one down which Australia should be walking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before outlining why we in the Opposition are very keen to support the Plant Variety Rights Bill, I thought I might just take up a couple of points mentioned by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) and the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen). The honourable member for Dunkley highlighted the problems with hybrids, but I think he makes an assumption that somewhere down the track all seeds will be hybrids, and I would have to suggest to him that, in all practicality, that is very unlikely. If one looks at other aspects of the agricultural scene, one sees that there are many varieties of sheep, cattle, horses and even pigs. In all those genetic areas there are those types or breeds that would be considered inferior in terms of productivity. However, in the eyes of those who are breeding them there is some reason for them to continue with those breeds. The same would be true in areas of horticulture and other crops. In any case, the fear the honourable member expressed of a particular variety dominating the market and dominating our crops is extremely unlikely to occur because of the wide range of climate in Australia. We must also not forget that there are many other types of climate throughout the world and, if one particular variety of plant became susceptible to a new disease, I do not believe it would be catastrophic. I believe that the situation could quite easily be remedied because other varieties would still be available.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Cowan made an assumption which is basically wrong. Following on from the comments of the honourable member for Dunkley and my reply, she is assuming that a small amount of genetic material will dominate all the breeding and all the crops in Australia. That is wrong; it will not happen. After all the existing varieties will still be around. Some of those available in Australia have been available for 50 years or more. They will not just disappear. Some people will continue to use them and at present most plant breeding stations in Australia hold stores of older varieties that are no longer in use. Again, the fear that is being put forward is based on a wrong assumption. The honourable member for Cowan is looking at an extreme example which, in reality, is never likely to happen. The honourable member for Cowan also made a couple of extraordinary statements when she said that plant variety rights will lead to fewer farmers. I find it a little difficult to understand how she reached that conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that; the European Parliament said that.

—She said that on the basis of the report of the European Parliament. The point is that plant variety rights will not lead to fewer farmers. There may be other reasons for there being fewer farmers, such as the record of this Government. One only has to look at the level of interest rates, the level of inflation and the lack of competitiveness faced by farmers in Australia when compared with farmers in the rest of the world to see why there might be fewer of them. The honourable member went on to make another extraordinary statement that by patenting plant varieties we would add to the malnutrition in less developed countries.
—The European Parliament said that too.

—The European Parliament has got it wrong. How on earth can the patenting of plant varieties lead to malnutrition? Is the honourable member assuming that countries that have a certain variety will be deprived of that variety? Obviously they will not. They will continue to have those varieties and it is more likely than not that through aid programs they will have access to better varieties. Therefore I would have thought that the opposite would be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: On this side of the House we strongly support this Bill. I am sure that most honourable members on the Government side will support it also. There are a number of reasons why this measure will be of great benefit to Australia and particularly to Australian farmers. It will certainly boost private plant breeding-it is the shot in the arm that we have been looking for for a long time. It will also open up export opportunities which do not exist at present and this will be of particular benefit because Australia happens to be located in the Southern Hemisphere. I will come to that matter again in a moment. It will also give Australian farmers access to new varieties that are presently available overseas, to our competitors. That is something we tend to forget. Our competitors are going ahead, using better varieties, getting better and cheaper production and this is making it more difficult for Australian farmers. Of course Australian consumers will also benefit. With a greater range of plants there will be a great opportunity to get better quality food and probably cheaper food as well. In this way plant variety rights will benefit all consumers. So, overall plant variety rights will be of considerable benefit to Australians and particularly to Australian farmers.

The matter of plant variety rights or the right to patent new varieties of plants has been on the political agenda in Australia for 15 years. It was first raised at the Commonwealth Plant Breeding Conference in Perth in 1971. PVR was recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission in 1976-so 10 years ago the IAC recommended that Australia should introduce PVR. We have not exactly rushed into this. In fact, the Australian Agricultural Council endorsed PVR as long ago as 1977, so even that august body got moving. In fact, the first Bill was introduced into the Parliament late in 1979. It was later redrafted and reintroduced into the House of Representatives by the previous Government in 1981. So there has been a lot of time and opportunity for the debate on PVR to proceed and there is no doubt that through this process of distillation the Bill before us today must have had the longest gestation period we have seen for some time. When the then Minister for Primary Industry introduced the Bill he let it lie on the table and in 1982 he introduced some amendments. It was most unfortunate and most untimely that the previous Government lost power before that Bill could be passed. In the light of these efforts I found it a bit galling that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said in his second reading speech:
Research and development in the private sector have been of particular concern to this Government.

If this has been a matter of such concern to the Government why has it taken the Minister 3 1/2 years to reintroduce a Bill that was already in the Parliament when the Government was elected? Despite this, the Government proceeded to refer the matter to a Senate select committee. Following that, Senator Hill's Bill was introduced last year and I would have thought that the Government could have been big enough to proceed with that measure. Nonetheless we had yet another report-after having reports from the IAC and the Senate select committee-and this time it was made by Professor Lazenby. Again, this report fully recommended that Australia should introduce plant variety rights. Now at long last, after all this time, we are seeing the introduction of plant variety rights into Australia. It is interesting to note that every one of these inquiries supported the introduction of plant variety rights. Honourable members opposite, who seem to have some doubts about the whole idea, should look closely at those reports because it is not often that one finds such a string of reports all supporting the same thing. To give honourable members an idea of some of the things that were said, I quote the report of the IAC inquiry into apples and pears in 1985, which also endorsed PVR:

. . . the absence of PVR for the Australian apple and pear industries has been a significant factor in denying growers access to those varieties of fruit . . . which are better yielding, more disease resistant and in greater demand in world markets. Australian growers have been, and remain, disadvantaged as a result.
That makes the point very clearly. I also quote from the McKay report on the grape and wine industries:
Australia is missing out on productivity and efficiency gains, quality gains and disease resistance.

It is very significant that in both cases disease resistance should be mentioned. Some honourable members opposite are rather concerned about the increased use of chemicals in farming nowadays. Here is evidence to show that plant variety rights will in fact facilitate the use of fewer chemicals in farming and I would have thought that all honourable members would welcome that. Professor Lazenby said in his most recent report, entitled `Australia's Plant Breeding Needs':

Overall therefore, the evidence leaves me in no doubt that the total resources presently invested in plant breeding in Australia are insufficient to enable rapid and effective improvement of our agricultural and horticultural plants.
I seek leave to continue my speech later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I present the report of the Committee entitled `Australia and the Philippines: The situation in the Philippines and its implications for Australia', together with extracts from the minutes of proceedings and transcripts of evidence, and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of my remarks I would like to pass on my best wishes to the Chairman of the Sub-committee on the Philippines, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), who unfortunately cannot be with us this evening because of an accident. I know I speak on behalf of all members of the House when I wish him a speedy recovery. We will greatly miss his wit and the contribution that he makes.

SPEECH.PARA: The report entitled `Australia and the Philippines' of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence presents a timely and valuable contribution to Australia-Philippines bilateral relations by the Australian Parliament. The decision to conduct such an inquiry was based on several considerations, including the Philippines location in a region of primary strategic, political and economic interest to Australia, its membership of the Association of South East Asian Nations and alliances with the United States of America. A further consideration was the growing public concern in Australia about Australia's policies towards the Philippines in general and the Marcos regime in particular.

Soon after the Committee commenced its program of public hearings in February 1986, the political landscape in the Philippines changed dramatically. After being declared winner of the presidential elections held on 7 February, Marcos's position was rapidly eroded by widespread reports of vote buying, multiple voting, mass disenfranchisement and other forms of fraud. The election was condemned both in the Philippines and the international community. I would note here that Senator Hill, the Deputy Chairman of the Sub-committee, participated as an international observer at those elections. In an extraordinary sequence of events, Defence Minister Enrile and General Ramos announced that they had broken with Marcos and would no longer accept his authority as President. This defection quickly attracted the support of the armed forces. Simultaneously, the church and opposition groups acted swiftly to mobilise `people power' in the streets of Manila to support the cause of the rebels. Within a few days Marcos left for exile in the United States once it was clear that he had lost control of the armed forces and that the United States Administration would no longer support his presidency. That same day, Corazon Aquino was sworn in as President and established a new government. I now turn to the major findings of the report.
The Aquino Government-Challenges and Prospects

The prospects facing the Aquino Government are daunting in their number, scale and complexity. After 20 years in office, Marcos left the Philippines a legacy of decay and corrupt political institutions, an economy in crisis, an active communist insurgency and a society marked by sharp inequalities and widespread poverty. Despite these problems, the Aquino Government has moved quickly to begin the task of rebuilding the political system and restoring individual freedom and respect for human rights.

There have been some major political developments since the Committee concluded its inquiry in September. Regrettably, political instability has persisted. Serious differences between Defence Minister Enrile and other members of the Cabinet, which were explored in detail in the report, have intensified in the last two months. The handling of the communist insurgency remains the major bone of contention between Enrile and other Ministers. The draft constitution to be presented to the people in a plebiscite in early February is also emerging as a source of instability and friction within the Aquino Government. The murder in recent days of a prominent left wing political and trade union leader, Rolando Olalia, and the kidnapping of a senior Japanese executive provide further evidence of the difficulties which now exist. Even within the last 48 hours, the assassination of David Puzon, a confidant of Enrile, has further inflamed this situation.

Despite the current instability, it should not be concluded that the Aquino Government is about to fall. What is more likely to happen is a continuation of the present circumstances, in which personal ambitions and policy differences are being fought out within the Aquino Government. Despite persistent rumours, a military takeover does not appear likely in the short term. As noted in the Committee's report, President Aquino enjoys the support of the Reagan Administration and the US Congress. Anyone contemplating the illegal seizure of power would have to take account of strong US disapproval and probably withdrawal of US economic and military aid. We should also bear in mind that there is a very broad constituency supporting the Government's emphasis on national reconciliation and moderate reform. If Aquino can hold together the broad middle ground, there is a fair prospect that her Government will lay the foundations for political stability and economic recovery in the Philippines.
The Economy

President Aquino's government is facing severe economic problems after three years of contraction in the economy as a result of mismanagement by the Marcos Government and the drop in world commodity prices. The most pressing needs are to reschedule foreign debt, to improve economic policy formulation, to revive business and investor confidence and to alleviate poverty throughout the country. The Committee's report concluded that even with sound economic management, economic recovery would be slow and difficult. Recent developments confirm this unfortunate outlook with the economy contracting by about 2.2 per cent in the first half of 1986. The persistence of political instability is a major reason for the reluctance of domestic and foreign business to invest in the Philippines.
The Communist Insurgency

One of the most serious challenges to the Aquino Government is the communist insurgency. The Committee's report concluded that the communist insurgency, which remains at a high level, would continue to burden the Aquino Government at a time when its energies and resources are already stretched to meet political and economic problems. Regrettably, recent developments appear to bear out that pessimistic assessment. The Committee's report concluded that a lasting nationwide ceasefire was not likely. Though negotiations between representatives of the Government and the insurgency have continued, the chances for success look very remote indeed. The recent murder of Rolando Olalia, the prominent political leader, will set back even further the prospects of a lasting ceasefire.
Australian Policy

The Committee's report strongly endorses the Australian Government's decision to extend political support and to increase development assistance to the Aquino Government. The emergence this year by peaceful means of a new Philippines government, committed to democracy and reform, was a better outcome than was widely expected in the closing stages of the Marcos regime. The Aquino Government deserved support and assistance in February this year. It continues to deserve that support and assistance now.
Defence Co-operation Program

Australia's defence relations with the Philippines have been the subject of controversy within the Australian community mainly because such relations have been perceived as providing support and assistance to the previous Marcos regime, and because of concern that they associated Australia with human rights abuses. The nature and extent of the defence co-operation program is not always clearly understood. No weapons or armaments are provided under the DCP. Funding for the program has remained at the very modest level of about $1.5m since 1979-80. The major element of the DCP in recent years has been training in Australia of personnel from the Armed Forces of the Philippines. The Committee does not consider that training of Armed Forces of the Philippines personnel in Australia contributes to human rights abuses in the Philippines or that it represented endorsement of the policies and practices of the Marcos Government. The conduct of Armed Forces of the Philippines personnel is a matter for the Philippines to resolve. If Australian training imparts useful skills and knowledge and encourages a professional and disciplined approach, it will have served a worthy purpose.

I point out that Amnesty International told the Committee that it was unaware of any individual of the Armed Forces of the Philippines who trained in Australia and later became implicated in human rights abuses. The Committee believes that training in Australia of Armed Forces of the Philippines personnel may serve to instil in the recipients values that tend to discourage human rights abuses. The Committee believes that the time to make the Armed Forces of the Philippines more proficient and professional is now, and Australia's DCP can make a modest but useful contribution to this process.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government consult with the Government of the Philippines on the most appropriate form and orientation of the defence co-operation program, and give careful consideration to any proposals from the Philippines Government for reorientation of the DCP including any relating to human rights issues, such as the provision of special training courses.
Development Assistance

Although there was no disputing that the Philippines was a deserving recipient of aid, the forms and effectiveness of its delivery by Australia were questioned in many submissions received by the Committee. The Samar and Zamboanga projects have been criticised for an excessive emphasis on infrastructure on the basis that roads and bridges are of limited value to the poorest groups in the community and may also benefit the military. The Committee considers that this criticism misses the point that sustained economic growth, without which lasting poverty alleviation is unlikely to occur, requires the removal of major obstacles to development, one of which is poor infrastructure in the Philippines.

The Committee has concluded, on balance, that large scale integrated development projects, such as those at Zamboanga del Sur and Northern Samar are a suitable vehicle for aid delivery and that these projects in the Philippines have increasingly met their objectives. In its current form, the Samar project represents a well-balanced combination of infrastructure and agriculture components with an appropriate emphasis on fostering community organisations and local decision making. The Committee is keen to see the benefits of this project sustained and improved. The Committee understands the Australian Government's decision to withdraw Australian personnel from Samar in 1985 on security grounds. It would be a pity, however, if project implementation were to lose momentum now. For this reason the Committee recommends that the Australian Government, in consultation with the Philippines Government, should arrange the return of Australian personnel to Northern Samar as soon as security conditions allow.

Earlier this year, shortly after the Australian Government announced an increase in development assistance to the Philippines, the Australian Development Assistance Bureau outlined a series of proposals on how best to structure and implement an expanded aid program. The Committee agrees in general with ADAB's proposals and considers that they offer an imaginative and constructive approach to the problems confronting the Philippines. The Committee commends the proposed sectoral inputs program as an appropriate response to the Philippines' pressing budgetary and balance of payments difficulties. This proposal will require careful design to ensure that Australian exports to the Philippines will not be adversely affected.

The Committee commends also the proposal for an Australian community assistance program which focuses on the pressing need to create jobs and generate income in rural areas, and which recognises the important and effective role which Philippines non-government organisations, and the Catholic Church can play in pursuing these objectives. This scheme should go some way towards addressing the criticism, raised by Australian non-government organisations, that Australian aid to the Philippines is inadequately focused on community needs and is excessively implemented through bilateral rather than community channels.
Economic Relations

Although Australia and the Philippines are not major trading partners, economic relations are an important aspect of the bilateral relationship. Domestic economic circumstances in both countries, and the state of the international economic environment, do not favour a rapid or substantial increase in bilateral trade or investment. The Committee believes, nonetheless, that several opportunities exist for an increase in Australian trade with the Philippines particularly in the sale of agricultural and mining equipment and technology.

The Committee heard claims from a number of witnesses concerning the alleged abuses of Filipino workers by Australian companies operating in the Philippines. The Aquino Government has announced its intention drastically to overhaul industrial practices and improve labour conditions in the Philippines which currently leave much to be desired. Evidence submitted to the Committee would not appear to support claims of repeated abuses by Australian companies of Filipino workers. The Committee does not consider that the establishment of a code of conduct for Australian companies in the Philippines would be a useful or effective measure. Australian companies operating in the Philippines are subject to the laws of that land and it is ultimately the responsibility of the Philippines Government to enforce those laws.
Social Concerns

During the course of the inquiry the Committee also encountered a level of concern with the community about issues affecting Filipino women. These included the problems faced by Filipino brides in Australia, the organisation of so-called sex tours to the Philippines and prostitution. Whilst these matters go beyond the scope of this inquiry, the Committee believes that they require further investigation, particularly by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford).
Conclusion

Before concluding my remarks, I would like to express my appreciation to all who assisted with this inquiry. I would like to thank all members of the Sub-Committee who attended the series of meetings and public hearings and all organisations and individuals who placed submissions before the inquiry and assisted the Sub-Committee with its work. I thank the Hansard staff for their assistance during the formal proceedings. I would also like to thank Mr Peter Stephens, Secretary to the Sub-Committee; Mr Marcel Dimo, foreign affairs adviser; Ms Kelly Edwards who was responsible for typing of the report; and Ms Margaret Ray and Mr Jack Cassells for their valuable assistance with this inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) for his presentation of this report tonight. He will understand when I say-indeed his words pointed to the same sort of view that I am about to express-that members of the Opposition regret that, through his injury, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), in his capacity as Chairman of the Sub-Committee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, could not present the report to the Parliament. He did an outstanding job as Chairman, bringing to bear his background as a diplomat and a former officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs. But I congratulate the honourable member for Rankin on his presentation and introduction of the report tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: My remarks will be more limited than those of the honourable member for Rankin. The tabling of the report on the Philippines is a timely reminder to us all of how swiftly political tides can change and of the volatility of international relations. This inquiry was born out of concern at the direction of Australian policy towards the Marcos regime and the growing instability in the Philippines resulting from the authoritarian nature of his regime and his refusal to implement meaningful reforms. Within months of the start of the inquiry, the political complexion had changed dramatically and the report was written with Cory Aquino as President of the Philippines. Now, nine months on, we table our findings during a period of renewed tension and uncertainty within the Philippines and concerns regarding the durability of the Aquino Government.

As the polarisation within President Aquino's Administration becomes greater her immediate problem is to hold her Government together. The dangers at the moment are only too apparent. While the political wrangling and instability persists the Government will be increasingly distracted from the difficult tasks it has before it. In any revolution, particularly that which overthrows a stale, corrupt regime, there is a strong temptation to believe that the very act of overthrowing the regime is, in itself, the answer to all problems. Clearly, it is a major prerequisite and catalyst to change but the problems that still confront the Philippines cannot be minimised.

Members of the Committee will know that, throughout this year, I have been perhaps a little more pessimistic as to the future and stability of the Aquino Government than many other members. I respect their views, but one has been issuing warnings about the instability that one has perceived, quite apart from the structural problems of the economy in the Philippines itself. That instability is very evident and before one and all who follow international affairs at present. That is not said in any way to put down the regime. I wish President Aquino well. She represents the will and the desire of the people and she deserves to continue in office. It is not for us to determine who should rule in given nations-that is a determinant that can only be indicated by those who reside and have jurisdiction or citizenship within a given country. I trust that matters there will settle. However, the Marcos legacy for the Aquino Administration is a formidable array of challenges, daunting in their number, scale and complexity.

We believe the major priorities of the Government in the Philippines must now be to restore a stable political order, to regenerate the economy, to alleviate poverty and to deal with the threat of the communist insurgency. The political twists and turns now going on in Manila have the potential, of course, to benefit only one interest group in the Philippines, namely, the communist insurgency. In recent years the insurgency has grown to alarming proportions and has deeply penetrated Philippine society. Philippine Government estimates place the number of insurgents at around 23,000. The New People's Army is active in at least 59 of the nation's 73 provinces. The number of its armed regulars and irregulars is increasing. Its supply of weapons is growing and it is provoking more frequent and more violent incidents.

In recent weeks it appears that the New People's Army has established itself in Manila. The NPA may well include within its support base disaffected individuals driven by poverty or unemployment and disillusioned by the corrupt political and judicial system under Marcos or by the poor discipline and related human rights abuses on the part of the armed forces. It is these very people the Government of President Aquino is attempting to woo away from the insurgency through negotiations, and economic and political reform. But we ought not be deluded, indeed we must not be deluded, about the leaders of the NPA, about its hardcore supporters, its philosophy, and its ultimate aim. Its members are not agrarian reformers. The Robin Hood image which is often argued by their sympathisers in Australia is far from the truth. They are ruthless and they are opportunistic.

The recent establishment of extreme left wing political parties in the Philippines by members of the Communist Party is nothing more than a cynical abuse of the democratic process. Their professed allegiance to the Aquino Government is very hollow indeed. We have seen these people peddling their vision for the Philippines in Australia, in recent months-courtesy dare I say-of the Australian trade union movement. They do no represent democracy, they do not represent freedom any more than their comrades in Vietnam and Nicaragua. The emergence of a communist regime in the Philippines would have profound consequences for the region. It would be a major setback to Western interests, a major setback for Australia, and it would create significant instability in South East Asia, particularly among other members of the Association of South East Asian Nations.

I turn briefly to these strategic concerns. A regime hostile to Western interests in such a strategic location would allow the Soviet Union unprecedented influence in the Pacific Basin. In my view the Philippines is a country of substantial strategic influence to our nation. For this reason, Australia cannot afford to remain indifferent to strategic developments in and around the Philippines. Without dwelling on the point, its strategic importance is derived from its alliance with the United States and is most evident when considering the role of the United States military facilities at Subic Bay naval base and Clark air force base. Clark air base is the major American tactical installation in the Western Pacific along with others in Japan and Korea. Subic Bay provides logistics support for naval operations throughout the Western Pacific and Indian oceans.
