The bases also contribute to the security of sea and air routes connecting the Indian and Pacific oceans and would play a major role in facilitating a United States response to a crisis in the Persian Gulf.

Japan and South Korea, two of our major trading partners, rely on secure sea lanes for the supply of energy and raw materials for their industry as well as for United States strategic support. These facilities play a fundamentally important role in maintaining the predominance of current United States military influence in the Western Pacific. Without their facilities at Clark and Subic, even allowing for the possible development of alternative facilities elsewhere, the United States would find it considerably more difficult to sustain operations in those areas of greatest strategic significance to Australia. It would be hard-pressed to keep open vital lines of communication including sea and air routes, and to operate effectively in the Pacific and Indian oceans. In a time of conflict the objectives of United States naval and air forces would be to deter and to suppress the activities of Soviet aircraft and submarines and to be able to cut the Soviet supply lines to their bases in Vietnam from Siberia and the Indian Ocean. This would effectively neutralise the Soviet presence in Cam Ranh Bay. An American presence at Clark Field and Subic Bay, therefore, means that the Soviets cannot count on the long term use of their Vietnamese bases in a time of war.

My comments have sought to identify major areas of concern to Australian interests. To be very frank, this is the analysis that I have sought to bring to bear in the few remarks that I make tonight. Of course, as the honourable member for Rankin indicated in his purview of elements of the report, the report is much broader and discusses important aspects of the bilateral relationship between Australia and the Philippines, covering, as he said, development assistance, defence co-operation, economic relations and community issues. I have indicated my pessimism. I trust I am wrong. I trust I am wrong because the Philippines is important not only to us. It is a nation of proud people. It is a country I have visited frequently. It has now been freed from the shackles of a corrupt and brutal regime and I trust that, beyond the February date for the ratification of the Constitution, it will be able to mirror the aspirations of Filipinos. After all, at root in the Philippines must be the interests of its people and that is for them, not for us, to determine.

In conclusion, I would like to reiterate my appreciation, as an ex officio member of the Committee, of the work done by the honourable member for Kingston. I join with the honourable member for Rankin in wishing him a speedy recovery. I also thank Senator Robert Hill, who joined a multinational observer team for the Philippines election, at my request, and contributed much to the Committee's deliberations. I also thank the other members and senators of the Sub-Committee who, at times when they may have had many other pressing engagements, gave much of their time and energy to analyse the many submissions that were put to the Committee. That is appreciated greatly by honourable members on this side of the House. I would particularly like to thank all the officials who work for the Committee. I think of Peter Stephens, the Secretary to the Committee, Marcel Dimo, who is here and who is the Committee's foreign affairs adviser, as well as all the other staff who were involved in the preparation of what I believe was, although it was not perceived to be at the very outset of the inquiry, a most timely report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I also was a member of the Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I also begin by congratulating the Chairman, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), for the work he did and I wish him a speedy recovery from his accident. I appreciated many of the comments of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). I hope that there is a bipartisan approach as far as possible to the problems of the Philippines. It is true to say that both sides of this House were very uncomfortable with the Marcos regime, the actions it carried out, and the suppression of the Filipino people. It is true that the Australian Government took a number of actions to try to change things in the Philippines, without appearing to be too interventionist in the internal affairs of that country.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, it is more a fortune of history than anything else that we have seen the fall of Marcos. It was a conjunction of events which might not have been predictable. They came together in quick succession. At the time the Sub-Committee was beginning its report, it looked as though Marcos would be there for many years. We are very pleased to see that there have been substantial changes and that the Aquino Administration has taken over.

Having said that, I indicate that I take a slightly different approach to the problems of the Aquino Administration from that of the honourable member for Kooyong. In my view the problems of the Administration should be squarely put on the shoulders of Mr Enrile, the Minister for Defence. There is no question that Mr Enrile, who is a suspect individual at the best of times, is the person who has been encouraging dissension within the Government and has created many of the problems facing President Aquino. Mr Enrile attended a rally in support of the previous President, Mr Marcos-and he is a member of the current Administration. I think it showed extraordinary tolerance on the part of the President that she allowed him to remain in the ministry when he went to such a rally and was clearly seen putting his thumb down against the Aquino Administration, an administration of which he is a member.

The situation in the Philippines is quite incredible in relation to the role of Mr Enrile as the Defence Minister. As honourable members will remember, this gentleman had a particular role to play in that he was a great friend of Mr Marcos. He was close to Mr Marcos. It was only at the key turning point in events that he turned against Mr Marcos and brought many of the armed forces with him. Nevertheless, he is playing an extremely dangerous and destabilising role in the Philippines.

The Government of Mrs Aquino-I remind the honourable member for Kooyong of this-was embarking on a constructive dialogue with the New People's Army and with other forces in the Philippines in an attempt to reach a resolution of the conflict and an accommodation. I believe that resolution and accommodation would have been achieved if it had not been for the destabilising role of Mr Enrile. The brutal assassination of the left wing trade union leader, which has polarised the Philippines and brought the situation to crisis point, has been sheeted home to the supporters of Mr Enrile. One has to ask: What game is Mr Enrile playing? Is it his intention to try to destroy the democratic Aquino Government, or is it his intention to continue a destabilisation campaign because he disagrees with an agreement being reached which would bring peace to that nation and allow for much greater democratic participation in the forthcoming election? This is the issue that needs to be raised and faced.

As the honourable member for Kooyong mentioned, many of the problems Marcos created through his oppressive administration, such as the problems of poverty and inequality, remain in the Philippines. Notwithstanding the best will in the world, the Aquino Administration has not been able to transform the situation in economic terms and in terms of social justice. But in the Aquino Administration there are Ministers who are concerned to try to achieve greater social justice and a better deal for the poor of the Philippines. If people like Mr Enrile have their way, the process of increasing democratisation, of moving towards greater social justice, will be stifled. The very things that the honourable member for Kooyong fears might be brought about by the destabilising activities by people like Mr Enrile. I believe that Australia should take a great interest in recent developments in the Philippines and make it perfectly clear that we oppose any attempt to overthrow the Government of Mrs Aquino or to destabilise the situation, especially in favour of someone such as the Defence Minister, Mr Enrile, with his short-sighted approach.

Having made that general point, I want to say something about another aspect of the report which is of interest to Australia, and is particularly of interest to me as chairman of the Caucus immigration committee. It concerns relations between Australia and the Philippines especially in the context of Filipino brides. We received a lot of evidence on this issue, and there are many myths created about this matter. In particular, the myth has been created that in every case Filipino brides come to Australia under false pretences and are very unhappy. That is not a correct representation of the facts. There are problems; we recognise that. But we do not believe that these problems have led to disasters or catastrophes as so many people have suggested. On the contrary, many of the marriages between Australians and Filipinos have been highly successful and happy.

It is a mistake to label the whole Filipino bride phenomenon as wrong and a mistake when in fact in many cases it is working out. That does not mean there are not some individual cases where there are problems, and there are actions we can take as a government to try to resolve some of these. The Aquino Government has expressed its desire for co-operation in this matter to try to ensure that people are fully briefed and understand what is involved in living in Australia and what is involved in marriage to Australians so that the relationship is not based on myths. If that spirit of co-operation continued, we could look forward to closer social relations with the people of the Philippines, and let us hope that people like Mr Enrile do not get their way and that the Philippines continues along the path of democratisation and becomes a dynamic, socially just society in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the report of the Committee entitled `Poles apart: Telecom's zonal and charging policies in rural and remote areas', together with extracts from the minutes of proceedings, the transcripts of evidence and submissions authorised for publication.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am pleased to present this, the second report by the Expenditure Committee on Telecom Australia's zonal and charging policies. The Committee's earlier report, `Ringing in the Changes', dealt with metropolitan and near-metropolitan areas while in this report the Committee discusses the service provided by Telecom to residents of rural and remote areas. The two reports comprise a thorough review of Telecom's performance as compared to its statutory responsibilities. In both reports the Committee has concluded that Telecom's technical performance has been generally good but that the Commission has been insufficiently responsive to the needs of the Australian community in the 1980s. Telecommunications are particularly important among the needs of Australians who live outside the capital cities. A reliable telephone service is more than a convenience in many rural and remote areas; it is a necessity. This report, which focuses on the telecommunications needs of country people, is particularly important. The Committee has recommended a package of improvements which I believe will greatly benefit rural and remote telephone users at minimal cost to Telecom.

SPEECH.PARA: Service Centres

The first group of improvements relates to Telecom's Community Access 80 scheme which provides rural telephone customers with access on a timed local call basis to a service centre. Telecom defines a service centre as a community providing certain basic services such as schooling, medical services, banking and similar basic necessities. The Committee applauds Telecom's initiative in providing this scheme, which we recognise as a major concession for many rural subscribers. Most country people who gave evidence shared this view but there were some problems with the scheme.

We have recommended that Telecom's list of minimum services available in a community selected as a service centre should be expanded to include agricultural service facilities, that medical services be specified as meaning at least one doctor and that schooling be defined as at least primary level. The Committee has also recommended that Telecom review a number of anomalies in the selection of service centres and in the allocation of subscribers to particular centres. Most importantly, the Committee recommends that subscribers in more remote areas have untimed local call access to their service centre. Telecom has estimated that this recommendation would cost $1.5m in capital expenditure and reduce call revenue by $1.8m per year. These costs are clearly not material to an enterprise reporting an operating surplus last year of $464.6m and the concession recommended is fully in accordance with Telecom's social obligations set out in its charter. The small number of subscribers affected by this recommendation would be given access at local call rates to a limited number of basic services; most of their telephone usage will remain at truck call rates. The Committee firmly believes that this concession should be made.

Telecom argued strongly before the Committee that this would be the thin end of the wedge; that the concession would flow on to fringe metropolitan areas at very great cost. The Committee could not accept this argument; we did not believe that it would be impossible to quarantine the concession as Telecom argued. The Australian Taxation Office, by a system of zoning, is able to restrict remote area concessions to deserving cases. We see no reason why Telecom cannot do the same.
Extended Zones

As part of its program of modernising rural and remote telephone facilities, Telecom has introduced a system of extended zones covering most of rural Australia. The Committee understood the necessity for this approach but, again, we have recommended some minor improvements affecting such matters as the naming of some zones and anomalies caused by boundary changes. Many people living in the new extended zones sought untimed local call access to apply to all calls within the new zones. The Committee could not support this claim but we have recommended that some concession be made by extending the time period on which call charges are based. The present community rate calls are charged at the rate of one local call per three minutes. We have recommended that this time period be extended to as much as six minutes.
Part-Privately Erected Lines

Some thousands of rural telephone subscribers over the years have had to supply part of the line connecting their service with the Telecom network. Many of these privately erected lines have been of low quality. One witness told the Committee:
In the old days, as long as you could hook onto the top wire of the fence and drop the shutter in the Post Office, you had communications.

The Committee in fact saw photographs of at least one boundary fence still doubling as a telephone line. Telecom is now replacing these unsatisfactory lines with equipment capable of connection to the automatic telephone network. The Committee endorses this decision but has recommended some changes in the way it has been applied. In particular, we have recommended that applications by subscribers on former part-private lines for services which were not technically available on those lines be charged as conversions rather than new installations. We have also recommended that the charge for conversion from part-private lines to the new Telecom facilities recognise the contribution made by subscribers to maintenance costs of the former equipment since 1969. In addition, the Committee recommended that Telecom review some anomalies which have led to particular subscribers being connected to new exchanges far from their historic community of interest.
Cross-Subsidy

An important result of the inquiry was the production by Telecom of a district profitability study showing the extent of cross-subsidies between geographical districts. The study, which is reproduced as an appendix to the report, shows that about $460m of indirect costs attributed to rural and remote areas are met by revenue from metropolitan services. This represents a cross-subsidy from urban to rural areas averaging $259 per service for each of 1.5m rural telephone services.

The average figure, of course, conceals some extreme examples. The Roma district, in south-western Queensland, for example, runs at an annual loss of almost $1,100 per telephone service. The scale of these figures shows the possible impact on country people if the cross-subsidy were to be replaced by totally cost-related pricing in the interests of a highly debatable economic theory. The Committee found that a reliable telephone service is a basic need in rural and remote areas, and it is an obligation of the telecommunications service to meet this need at an affordable cost.

The Committee accepted the conclusions of the Ergas report on `Telecommunications and the Australian Economy' that the cross-subsidy to rural areas in the Australian telecommunications system is consistent in extent and direction with those applying in comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We also accept Mr Ergas's conclusion that the present cross-subsidy is the most economically efficient way of meeting the Government's social obligations in regard to telecommunications. We recommend that Telecom reaffirm its commitment to cross-subsidising the rural and remote sector but that full information on the extent and direction of the subsidy be reported annually to Parliament.
Telecom and the Public

The Committee's two reports on Telecom represent a thorough overall review of the Commission. In our many public hearings and meetings across the country, we found that Telecom's field staff and local management were generally well regarded. There was some feeling that the Commission's head office in Melbourne was seen to be remote from customer needs and opinion. This is, of course, a common problem in large organisations and, although the Committee sees the need for some improvement in this area, we do not believe that Telecom's performance has been so bad as to justify severe condemnation or to require major changes.

The Committee has recommended that Telecom markedly improve its processes for consulting with customers before introducing changes which affect them. We have recommended that Telecom properly research the social impact of its decisions and pay appropriate attention to the results of that research. We have recommended that the Commission pay greater attention to the quality and accuracy of its publicity material, including the advisory sections of telephone directories. We have repeated a recommendation contained in our earlier report that Telecom should establish complaints bureaus in each State. Most importantly in the customer relations area, we have recommended that Telecom make better use of its greatest asset-its networks of field staff-by ensuring that they are fully aware of the Commission's policies, practices and corporate objectives so that they can serve as a first line of information and defence.
Billing Arrangements

A section of the report which will be of interest to metropolitan as well as country subscribers relates to billing arrangements. The report points out that Telecom already has the facility to provide itemised accounts to a large proportion of its customers and is testing a new metering system which will improve this. The Committee has recommended that Telecom work towards providing acceptable detailed billing facilities to all subscribers as soon as practicable. It would probably be technically feasible for Telecom to provide for single line users a telephone record keeping facility which would allow the cost of calls to be monitored. Such a facility is already available for PABX and PBX customers and extension to single line users would clearly benefit farmers and small businessmen. The Committee has recommended that Telecom develop and provide such a facility.
Conclusion

This report is the outcome of 600 submissions by individuals and groups and extensive travel by the Committee to rural and remote communities throughout Australia. During the inquiry the Committee took the opportunity to hold public meetings in many areas to hear from country people about the quality of Telecom's performance. The Committee has fulfilled an important role in establishing the needs of these isolated groups and developing feasible proposals for meeting those needs. None of the recommendations implies any great cost to Telecom, but many of them will provide important benefits to particular groups of subscribers. In its two reports the Committee has shown that Telecom, while admirably meeting its public obligations in terms of technology, could improve its knowledge of and responsiveness to the needs of its customers. I hope that this report will help Telecom in that process.

In its two reports the Committee has shown that Telecom, while admirably meeting its public obligations in terms of technology, could improve its knowledge of and responsiveness to the needs of its customers. I hope that this report will help Telecom in that process.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank my fellow members of the Committee who undertook a rigorous and demanding program of travel, often a long way off the beaten track, to collect the evidence for this inquiry. The Telecom project team which co-ordinated the Commission's response to the inquiry showed great professionalism and I would particularly like to thank Mr John Taylor, who is in the Parliament tonight, who headed that team and who not only answered the Committee's many questions but also braved the numerous public meetings we organised. There are many other people associated with Telecom who are too numerous to mention in this context but I also place on record the Committee's appreciation of their support. Thanks are also due to the Committee secretariat, especially to Sue Harlow, Anne Hazleton, Dorothy Miles, Peter Ratas, Peter Hamburger and Penny Maher. Most of all, I would like to thank the many hundreds of residents of rural and remote Australia who took the trouble to make submissions and attend public meetings and hearings to give the Committee their views.

This inquiry has drawn more public interest and response than almost any other conducted by the Expenditure Committee. The level of interest shows clearly how important the telecommunications network is to rural Australians. I commend the report the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As Chairman of the Standing Committee on Expenditure I would like to add some comments to those of the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) who, I must say, did an excellent job as chairman of the sub-committee on Telecom's zonal charging policies in rural areas. Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice states that the functions of parliamentary committees include the sifting of evidence to draw reasoned conclusions to `in a sense . . . ``take parliament to the people''.'. This inquiry, which has been one of the largest undertaken by the Expenditure Committee, fulfilled both of those functions. The Committee heard and considered a large amount of evidence, much of it technical in nature, and produced recommendations which will provide important benefits to many of Telecom's rural customers at minimal cost. Fewer of the Committee's inquiries have done more to take parliament to the people.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as receiving 600 submissions, the vast majority from individuals in rural and remote areas, the Committee travelled throughout Australia and convened both public meetings and formal hearings to allow country people to have their say on Telecom's performance. Telecom representatives, to their credit and probably to their benefit, attended the public meetings arranged by the Committee and were able to resolve some of the problems raised. The honourable member for Calare has mentioned that the Committee visited many areas off the beaten track. It was very useful for the Committee to hear the views of residents of such areas as Charleville, Richmond, Hughenden and Flinders Island, to mention just a few of the rural communities visited.

I would like to thank those members of the Committee who took part in the rigorous program of hearings, meetings and inspections required in this inquiry, including you, Mr Deputy Speaker, when you were Chairman of the Committee. Like the honourable member for Calare, I would like to thank those members of the rural and remote communities who offered their opinions and advice to the Committee. This report, together with the Committee's earlier report on Telecom's zonal and charging policies in urban areas, provides a useful overview of Australia's largest public authority. Focusing as it does on rural and remote areas, this report draws particular attention to the effect of uniform national pricing for Telecom services. The effect is, of course, a cross-subsidy from low cost to high cost services.

As Telecom advises the Committee, there are cross-subsidies from metropolitan to non-metropolitan areas, business to non-business users and telephone services to telegram services. Transfer from metropolitan to non-metropolitan areas is the largest of these and the report shows that Telecom's latest assessment of its value is about $460m per year, or an average of $259 for each telephone service in rural areas. This is a very large concession to country people. The Committee accepted that it is justified both for social and economic reasons. The Telecom district profitability study included as an appendix to the report shows that if Telecom's services were priced closer to cost almost all country people would face large increases in telephone charges. The Dubbo district, for example, runs at a loss of $508 per telephone service per year. In Armidale it is $531; in Darwin, $587; and in Roma, $1083. The Committee could not accept that the social costs of imposing charges of this level on rural and remote residents would be outweighed by any benefit available under a somewhat dubious economic theory. The Committee saw at first hand that a reliable telephone service is not a luxury in these areas; it is necessary. For country people a telephone is necessary for normal social contact, for many forms of business and, in some cases, literally to save lives.

Like comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, Australia, under successive governments, has recognised this and made some concession in charges. It has been argued that if the concession is justified it should be given openly rather than hidden in Telecom's charges. The Committee supported the need for openness and recommended that Telecom explicitly report to Parliament on this issue each year. We did not accept, however, that there would be any value in replacing the cross-subsidy with a direct subsidy. We accepted the arguments of the OECD administrator Henry Ergas that, if a subsidy is desirable, a cross-subsidy is the most economically efficient way of providing it. As Mr Ergas argues, the cross-subsidy has several advantages over a direct subsidy; it is more fiscally neutral, it is more equitable in the way it accounts for externalities available from the telecommunications network and it is less costly to administer. This, of course, has been recognised by successive governments for many years. It is encouraging to see the principle reaffirmed by a committee comprising members of all three parties.

In the evidence presented to it, the Committee found a tendency for some to argue that, because rural and remote residents benefit from the cross-subsidy, they should not complain about the standard of Telecom's service. We rejected this view; country people have as much right to a reliable telephone service as do their city cousins. There are several recommendations in the report which give force to this principle. In particular, the Committee has recommended that Telecom recognise the contribution made over many years by those rural subscribers who have had to erect and maintain part of the telephone line to their property. We have also recommended that Telecom give sympathetic consideration to a number of cases where modernisation of equipment has led to subscribers losing local call access to their traditional community of interest. The Committee has also recommended small additional concessions to many rural subscribers; specifically, untimed local call access to a service centre for all subscribers, and a maximum charging rate within extended zones of the community call rate of 18c per three minutes. These concessions would lead to small losses of revenue or slightly increased costs to Telecom but would not significantly reduce the Commission's operating surplus or the extent of the cross-subsidy. They are targeted at particularly disadvantaged groups in rural and remote areas. They would provide an important benefit to the relatively small number of country residents that they would affect.

The Committee found that Telecom could improve its performance somewhat by making greater efforts to identify the needs of its customers and improving its customer relations. A typical example of the type of problem we identified was Telecom's replacement of the red coin telephones available for lease by private customers with the new gold phone. The gold phone has many technical advantages but is only available for sale, not lease. The purchase price puts it out of the reach of many welfare organisations, such as refuges and hostels, which have a particular need for coin telephones. If Telecom had recognised the effect that a transfer from rental to purchase would have on such customers it could easily have made alternative arrangements.

I said earlier that this inquiry was a good example of the valuable work that parliamentary committees can do. The quality of committee work is affected by the standard of staff available to assist members in their work. During the years that I have been a member of the Expenditure Committee I have been impressed by the quality of its staff. This year the Committee has tabled a record number of reports, several of them covering large and important issues.

The Committee greatly benefited during most of the year from the professional support of its former Secretary, Mrs Sue Harlow. Her predecessor in that position and first Secretary to the Committee, Mr Malcolm Aldons, kindly agreed to return to the position on a temporary basis on very short notice when Mrs Harlow left in September. We would have had great difficulty in completing the Committee's heavy work load for the year without his support. The position of Secretary to the Committee is most important and the Expenditure Committee has been fortunate in having very able parliamentary officers in that position throughout its existence. This report will be a useful contribution to the telecommunications debate in Australia. I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In speaking to this report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, I also will confine my remarks to the topic of cross-subsidy. Before doing so, I commend the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), who has done an excellent job in chairing the sub-committee. He has been extremely conscientious. He has been very accommodating and very willing to listen to all points of view at all times. The way he handled the sub-committee, and the general impression that has been given to people wherever we have visited during this fairly large inquiry, certainly became him. In fact, he was even prepared to travel all the way to Hamilton, in the middle of the Western Districts of Victoria, to hold a special hearing. I thank him for that.
—There is a good member down there, isn't there?

—My word, there is. I also point out the tremendous value of the Committee travelling around as it did. As the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford) said, it has allowed the Committee, as part of the Parliament, to visit the people rather than the people having to visit Canberra to see what the Parliament is all about. Apart from the fact that the Committee was always willing to listen to and inspect problems at first hand, it demonstrated that members of parliament are prepared to obtain their knowledge first hand. I think it also demonstrated to these groups the enormous value of having an all-party committee, a committee made up of members from both sides of the House. It showed that, away from the spotlight of this chamber, Federal members of parliament from all parties can work together for the betterment of our fellow Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the question of the cross-subsidy, I was rather heartened, I might say, Mr Deputy Speaker, to hear both you and the honourable member for Calare talk about the value of the cross-subsidy being about $450m. It interested me that over the period of the hearing the figure initially started at $490m, and then fluctuated. The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) in a recent Press release referred to it as $459m. During the inquiry it became more and more obvious that the figure was an approximation. That is not a criticism of Telecom Australia, because I think it was obviously expected to try to come up with a reasonably precise figure, and so it did. In fact, as the inquiry proceeded, we found that the figure was a good ballpark figure. During the inquiry it became obvious that it was in the range of $400m to $500m. I make this point because I think it is important that it is understood that it is an approximation. In future, when the Government or whoever is speaking about the level and value of the cross-subsidy gives an approximate figure, we will know that it is about $450m or $460m; but that it is very difficult to be more precise than that. As the matter has already been canvassed at some length, I do not want to go into it in a great deal more detail.

As the honourable member for Calare said in his tabling speech, when we talk about cross-subsidy, and I refer to chapter seven of the report, it can just as easily be argued that private users in metropolitan areas, because they use Telecom less than most commercial customers, are cross-subsidised at the expense of business users. So the whole question of cross-subsidy is quite complex. While it is recognised that people in the country do receive a cross-subsidy, it is a little more complex than it might initially appear. When we talk about the difficulty in working out the level of cross-subsidy, we should consider the comments of Mr Ergas and some of the transcripts of the inquiry. At one stage Mr Pitt, the Manager for Financial Studies and Development, said:

. . . our best estimate of the cross-subsidy, metro to country, in 1984 and 1985 was of the order of $400m to $500m. I think that is sufficient for our purposes because it does indicate the general extent of the transfer.
That really puts it in perspective and we should recognise that point.

I draw attention to another point mentioned by the honourable member for Calare when he spoke about recommendation No. 18, that Telecom should produce a district profitability study. In other words, every district should be able to produce a figure to show how profitable it was and whether it was receiving a cross-subsidy. While I certainly support that, I also caution the Parliament against expecting too much detail because we could end up asking for more detail than it is worth Telecom's while trying to compile.
The other point I wish to mention briefly relates to paragraph 7.24 of the report. Talking about the question of cross-subsidy again, the report said:

If the overall level of cross-subsidy is to be reduced, subsidies to metropolitan private users at the expense of business users would be as much in question as the transfers to rural and remote customers.

As the honourable member for Calare rightly pointed out, the social effects of any changes in Telecom's cross-subsidies could be very substantial. I think that comment sums it up. I wish to put that point on the record because there may well be some time in the future when people may question the value of these cross-subsidies.

In conclusion I very much support the words of the Chairman of the sub-committee and also yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, as Chairman of the Expenditure Committee. I also commend the staff of the Expenditure Committee for doing a marvellous job. I think the Parliament and the Committee have gained a lot. Telecom also must have gained a lot from the inquiry. As well as being a good public relations exercise for both Telecom and the Parliament, I feel that if the recommendations of this report are accepted and adopted many people in the country will feel that this inquiry has been well worth while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Unfortunately the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) has just left the House. He and I share a somewhat dubious distinction of being the only two telephone technician members of this House at present. Obviously the honourable member for Aston had a more interesting life in the Department than I did because in the last few years, while the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure has been looking at Telecom Australia, the honourable member for Aston has become a great apologist for Telecom. Sometimes I go to bed at night and pray that I will not lose my seat in Parliament because I am pretty sure that I would never get my job back in Telecom. I must pay a compliment to the Chairman of the sub-committee, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), and his colleague the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free) who was the Chairman of the sub-committee that investigated the first part of this inquiry into Telecom's zonal policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Telecom, being the largest public authority and probably the largest business in Australia, posed a daunting task for any parliamentary committee charged with looking into it. Telecom has great battalions of people to tell others what they are doing and where they are doing it, but parliamentary committees, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, have only quite small staffs. While the Expenditure Committee may have been the David going into bat against Goliath at the beginning of this inquiry some three years ago, the outcome has been quite an experience for the Committee, of great benefit to the Parliament and, I believe, of benefit to telephone subscribers in Australia. I think it has also been of some benefit to Telecom because it would have required Telecom to look at its relationship vis-a-vis the Parliament and its subscribers.
As a member of the Committee I travelled to many of the places mentioned in this report, to outback parts of Queensland, southern parts of Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Mornington Peninsula.
—And even to the more exotic parts of Melbourne on the Mornington Peninsula, with the honourable member for Dunkley.
—And with the honourable member for Flinders.

—With the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale). Telecom really got its money's worth out of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee. I hope that Telecom's response to this report will be a little more positive than its response to the previous report, because I think the Committee did identify a number of areas where Telecom has to have a close look at what it is doing. It is no good the largest public authority in Australia deciding that its main function is to deliver the best engineering services and to make money. Telecom also has a social objective in its charter and I think that, in many of the areas where the Committee went, subscribers of Telecom were of the firm belief that it was not actually living up to parts of that social commitment in its charter.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it was a great experience for the Committee members to travel to those outback parts of Australia, to visit Aboriginal settlements on Bathurst Island in the Northern Territory, and to find out how important Telecom is to people in a large country like Australia. Even the members of the Opposition who travelled around with the Committee became of the firm view that a privatised Telecom might not be the smartest thing to do. Even the honourable member for Deakin, although he may not admit it, saw some small positive benefits in Telecom while we were travelling around looking at its activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was not on the sub-committee. He was a fellow traveller.

—He was not on the sub-committee, but he took an interest. I believe that committee reports such as this add to the sum of knowledge of all members of parliament and show that the committee system in the Parliament plays a very important role in the education of members and in identifying areas in the community that are of interest to all our constituents. Of the parliamentary committee reports to be tabled in the House tonight, only one contains a dissenting report. In the other four committee reports-one from the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, two from the Expenditure Committee and one from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts-all members agreed with the recommendations of their various committees. On all those committees are members of the National Party, the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. Too often we see newspapers write up the areas where we are all in disagreement, but the parliamentary committee system, in my opinion, is the last remnant of the Westminster system in the parliamentary system in Australia in that people get together to work out something for the benefit of all Australians. That is done pretty well unanimously. As I said, in only one of the five reports was there disagreement amongst the members and in that report there was not disagreement on all matters in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In the seven years that I have been a member of the Expenditure Committee I can recall only one report where the members of the Committee disagreed. All the other reports that that Committee has brought down in those seven years-there must have been at least 20 of them-have had the unanimous agreement of members of parliament. The outcome of those reports has been of considerable benefit to all the people in Australia.

I congratulate the honourable member for Calare and the honourable member for Lindsay on the two reports they have brought into this Parliament on Telecom's zonal and charging policies in both rural and remote areas and in metropolitan and provincial areas. I think members of the Committee have learned a lot and they have been very ably assisted by staff members. Parliamentary committee staff do a lot of hard work often running to deadlines with our pushing them along. It is pleasing to see in the officials' box tonight two current members of the Committee's staff, one who left recently and one who left three months earlier. Those people put in the work; they do most of the background work for the members and ensure that the briefing papers are there on time, that travel arrangements are made properly and that witnesses are lined up to attend the hearings. The outcome of reports is very much a partnership arrangement between the members and staff who serve the Committee.

I put on record, as you did earlier, that when I was Chairman of the Expenditure Committee the staff were more than up to scratch. As you said earlier this evening, the Expenditure Committee has been exceptionally well serviced by the staff whom it has had. That is a credit to both Mrs Harlow and Mr Aldons who have been the two secretaries to that Committee in the 11 years that that Committee has been in existence. The staff have kept up a consistently high standard of reporting and I guess, in some ways they have also kept the members up to a high standard of interrogation of witnesses.

In closing, I also thank the people from Telecom who, I think, sometimes thought I was the worst tormentor they had ever had. I would like to seek some assurance from them that if I were ever unfortunate enough to lose my seat I would be welcomed back to a job. I would probably be doing banks and wipers for the rest of my life. John Taylor, who was an engineer in the Department of Communications, would remember what that was like. All in all, the report that the Committee has brought down tonight on Telecom and the report that the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) will be tabling in a few minutes on the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) show that the Expenditure Committee has kept up a high degree of reporting. The reports are of benefit both to the Parliament and the people of Australia. As I said earlier, I am sure even Telecom learned something of the way both the Parliament and some of its internal operations work and that may be of benefit to it as well. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the report of the Committee entitled `Call us again: Review of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit report on the control over manpower and property by the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia)', together with extracts from the minutes of proceedings, the transcripts of evidence and submissions authorised for publication.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The efficiency audit report of the Auditor-General on the control over manpower and property by the OTC is the seventh review that has been undertaken by the Expenditure Committee. The objectives of the Committee were, as in the case with other reviews of efficiency audits, to examine the response of the Commission to the audit report, and to assess the substantive content of the audit exercise and the quality of the efficiency audit report. In April 1985 the Committee inspected OTC's international radio operating room in Martin Place, Sydney and its facilities in Paddington. Evidence was taken at two hearings in Canberra in April and September 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: The efficiency audit of OTC examined several matters, namely, the procedures used by OTC to control the use of technical manpower and property resources and areas of declining activity and areas incurring losses. In relation to technical manpower, the Audit Office examined OTC's methods of estimating technical staff requirements and made recommendations covering new systems for this activity. It expressed concern about the fluctuating intakes of technical trainees and suggested that a more efficient use of resources could be obtained if the intakes were more regular. Audit considered that the four-year training period for technical trainees could be reduced by one year without any diminution of quality or standards.

Audit also examined radio operations and suggested that efficiency would be improved with the application of new technology and that an improved management system would reduce losses. Finally, Audit looked at OTC's utilisation of property resources and recommended that it regularly review its property needs to ensure that it disposes of any unused properties. It also considered that the Commission should keep under review opportunities to obtain lower cost head office accommodation than the present site in Martin Place, Sydney.

If an assessment of the success or otherwise of an efficiency audit rests on the fact that the majority of the recommendations have been implemented or resulted in action being taken, I think we can say that this audit was successful. Fourteen of the 16 recommendations identified by the Committee in the audit report have been implemented; one has been partially implemented; and some action has been taken on one; but further action rests with another agency.

However, what does this tell us about OTC, the organisation? It tells us that there were some matters in some areas of OTC that required some updating. In response, the Commission claimed that most of these matters were receiving attention and, for example, a new financial management information system was on the drawing board before the audit was even contemplated. This tends to be the standard response of organisations under external review and it is obviously quite difficult to be certain about the causal connections between what an external review identifies and what action is taken or the speed or direction of that action. It does seem, however, that the audit was the catalyst that resulted in OTC disposing of 16 surplus properties and taking action to dispose of a further 11.

But then, the audit took two years to complete and this does seem to be an inordinately long time for a report that is quite narrow in scope. OTC is a dynamic commercial organisation that must be responsive to rapid technological change. For an audit report to avoid the risk of being outdated and irrelevant it would seem essential that the report be prompt and timely. It was the Committee's view that the time span of the audit reflected, at least in part, the Audit Office's lack of familiarity with government business enterprises, a deficiency that could have been remedied by the use of consultants.

In examining the fluctuating yearly intakes of technical trainees the auditors did not question why the fluctuations had occurred and the intake had dwindled to zero, or whether there was even a need to continue with the intakes. This is another instance of Audit's failure to appreciate the technological aspects of OTC's products. A drop in wastage rates coinciding with an increase in salaries and the development of new technology gave rise to a situation where OTC not only did not need to take on any more trainees in the short term, but also would require fewer people in the years to come.

In another area Audit's lack of skills about markets and market behaviour was apparent. In examining the substantial losses of the telegraphic service Audit identified the wrong problem. The losses of the international telegram service should have been examined by means of a market analysis. This would have shown that the market share was falling because consumers preferred other services such as facsimile and international subscriber dialling. Audit should have then suggested a market survey to test the long term viability of the telegraphic service.

Overall, the Committee was disappointed with the narrow scope of the audit, especially when considering the length of time it took. OTC is a large enterprise earning more than $400m a year. One would think that an examination of OTC's specific services, with an emphasis on the efficiency of resource use, as well as a wider examination of its financial structure, could have been a worthwhile exercise. As I said earlier, if Audit felt that it lacked all the skills necessary for such an exercise, consultants could have been used.

It is four years since Audit commenced its examination of OTC's control over manpower and property and the Committee fully appreciates that the Commission has undergone considerable change since then. There has been some debate in the media about the telecommunications authorities, especially since the publication of a report to the Department of Communications by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development economist, Mr Henry Ergas. The report is called `Telecommunications and the Australian Economy'. The debate has centred on the levels of investment funds that are needed by the authorities if they are to recover from past shortfalls that occurred as a result of financial constraints in the early 1980s and keep pace with worldwide developments in telecommunications.

OTC is a profitable organisation funded from internal sources and, unlike most other Commonwealth statutory authorities, it pays all Commonwealth taxes and duties, including corporate income tax and a dividend. In fact, in the past five years income tax payments and dividends to the Commonwealth totalled more than $267m out of pre-tax profits of $341m; that is, 78 per cent of its profits have gone back into the public purse.

So, whilst its financial performance is strong, it has a relatively low level of equity capital invested in the business. In 1983 the Government agreed to set a dividend target for the five-year period to 1987-88 of 10 per cent of capital and reserves. However, the 1985-86 target was altered to 12.5 per cent and the 1986-87 target has been set at 15 per cent. All this makes it difficult for the Commission to plan its capital expenditure program and utilise a combination of debt and equity to finance large projects. OTC has suggested that a more equitable basis would be an agreed percentage of after-tax profits and suggests 40 per cent as appropriate. This would allow growth to continue without increasing new debt finance; costs and hence prices could be kept down. Honourable members can be sure that if the dividend continues to go up, so will the tariffs. The Committee felt that this view was reasonable and recommended that the Government review the basis for determining the dividend and, in so doing, take into account the requirements for capital reinvestment.

Finally, the Committee learned that OTC has a submission before the Government seeking a widening of its powers to enable it to diversify into activities beyond its current charter which allows it to provide only international communications. These would include areas such as consultancies, design of equipment and joint ventures. Given the obvious advantages, such as reducing dependence on overseas technology and increasing the utilisation of skills already existing in OTC, the Committee wholeheartedly supports the thrust of OTC's submission.

I conclude by noting, however, that it would be self-defeating for the Government to amend OTC's legislation to allow it to branch out into other activities but at the same time shackle it by requiring increased payments of dividends without new injections of capital. I thank my fellow Committee members. In particular I thank the Committee secretariat who worked on this report-Mrs Harlow, who was the Secretary of the Committee until the beginning of September; Mr Aldons, who has taken over since then; Ms Cathy Stobo; and also Ms Alison Standord and Ms Heather Chapman. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: But tonight there has been the presentation of three reports of committees of the Parliament and another one, from the outstanding honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), will be tabled from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

—Very much so, Mr Deputy Speaker. The particular report to which I am making reference is the report that was tabled by the honourable member for Wannon.
