TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 260th report of the Committee, relating to the medical fraud and overservicing inquiry-response to report on pathology (Department of Finance minute on the Committee's 236th report), and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the fourth and final report of the Committee's medical fraud and overservicing inquiry. It contains responses from the Government, the medical profession and others to the Committee's report on pathology-PAC report 236. The Committee welcomes the Government's response to the 236th report. As I make reference to the Government's response, let me say that I think the Government has set a new record in the speed of its response to a parliamentary report-the Public Accounts Committee report. In 11 months the Committee had the support of the Government, the recommendation enshrined in legislation and administration. That is a new record in the Government implementing the recommendations of a parliamentary committee. I want to thank the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) for his timely response.

SPEECH.PARA: The response is timely and established an appropriate legislative framework to address many of the problems outlined in the Committee's report. The development and introduction of this legislation represents a major step forward for the Government in tackling the issue of pathology laboratory accreditation and creating effective mechanisms to review the rendering of excessive pathology services. Frameworks have been established for the administration of approved pathology practitioner undertakings, approved pathology authority undertakings, the creation and operation of a Pathology Services Advisory Committee and Medicare participation review committee. In particular it is noted that the provisions of section 129 of the Health Insurance Act, covering false statements relating to Medicare benefits, have been revised. I am sure that all honourable members would welcome that.

As previous reports for this inquiry have emphasised, a legislative response to medical overservicing is appropriate only to establish the framework within which professional review mechanisms can operate effectively. It remains that medical overservicing is a problem where the judgment of providers by their peers is required. The continued development of co-operation and consultation between the profession, the Minister and the Commonwealth's administration is essential if improvements are to be made in this area. This report also details other responses to the Committee's pathology report. The support for the Committee's recommendations of the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia, the Australian Medical Association, major specialist pathology practices, practitioners generally and members of the public is welcomed.

The Committee remains resolute in its opposition to those medical entrepreneurs who rank the pursuit of profit and market control over and above patient care. The Committee believes it is now the responsibility of Commonwealth and State governments, in conjunction with the medical profession, to examine the activities of these so-called medical entrepreneurs and bring them to public account where their actions are judged not to be in the public interest.

The Committee is concerned that the problems that it has uncovered in the pathology area also appear to be developing in radiology and psychiatry. In particular, some medical entrepreneurs appear to be moving to exploit these areas. The Committee believes that it is the joint responsibility of the medical profession and the Government to pre-empt these moves.
The Committee has also carefully examined the responses of Dr Edelsten. Because of sub- judice principles, comment on Dr Edelsten's submission will be tabled at a later date.

I take this opportunity to thank the staff of the Public Accounts Committee and members of the Committee for their support. I would like to make particular reference to the clerk of this Sub-committee, Mr Peter Mason. He has pursued this area over many years and I thank him for his continued support and efficient handling of this very complex issue. I recommend this report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the dinner break this evening I was talking about plant variety rights and the benefits they would bring to Australian farmers, to consumers and to Australians in general with the increase in export income. I also mentioned some of the arguments put by some honourable members opposite who seem to be against plant variety rights but who obviously will not vote against the Plant Variety Rights Bill. I can put their minds at ease; their fears are not founded on sound ground. In fact, if they analysed the legislation carefully they would relax, because plant variety rights will not cause any of the problems mentioned by some groups which have been against plant variety rights. They think that for some reason or other we should be against it. As far as I am concerned, the down side is virtually nil and the advantages will improve the whole aspect of plants and crops in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the point that Professor Lazenby made in his report on Australia's plant breeding needs and how we could best correct the lack of resources being directed into plant breeding. The House might recall that earlier I mentioned the fact that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) seemed rather appalled by the lack of resources going into plant breeding. I pointed out that I was rather galled by the Minister's comments; if he was so appalled he might have moved a bit faster rather than taking 3 1/2 years to bring in legislation which had already been tabled once before in this chamber in 1981. If we see what Professor Lazenby had to say on this matter we may get the answer. He said:

Evidence, largely from other countries, leads me to conclude that incentives based on protection would probably ameliorate many of the constraints facing our crop improvement program. These include increased breeding resources; better use of germplasm; better access to varieties bred overseas; better use of public, and total, breeding resources; possible better integration with breeding of basic research and new developments in technology; and a more vigorous and stable seed industry. On balance, therefore, I believe that some form of proprietary protection provides a better means of developing Australia's crop improvement programs than do the options not involving such protection . . .

That sums it up very clearly. Let us look at some of the comments Professor Lazenby made. When we talk about whether Australia should be involved in PVR and when we consider that many other countries have also been involved, we see that New Zealand has been involved in plant variety rights for over 12 years. Professor Lazenby said:
Further, it is neither desirable nor logical for Australia to stand outside the mainstream of developed countries in the hope of providing intangible benefits to Third World countries.

I think that sums up some of the fears that some honourable members opposite seem to have. On the question of how we might go about it, whether it be by plant patenting or some other form, Professor Lazenby said very clearly:
. . . I am strongly of the view, that in Australia, PVR is much to be preferred;

What are the benefits of plant variety rights? Very briefly, as I see that the clock is running on, they can be summed up in four ways. Firstly, it will give farmers access to better varieties from overseas, something which at the moment is restricted. It will also provide incentives for farmers to breed better varieties locally. That will also provide the opportunity to open up new export markets. Consumers will also benefit because we will have better varieties of fruit and vegetables, and in many cases, I suspect, they will be cheaper because of the increased productivity.

I will expand on some of those points. The overseas market is worth about $1.3 billion in western Europe and the United States of America alone. This market is growing at about 8 per cent per annum and it is anticipated that Australia could easily penetrate it to the tune of $12m in the first year. The opportunity to export material from Australia is enormous, but we have an additional advantage which may not be immediately obvious. As we are in the southern hemisphere, there will be a tremendous opportunity for what is known as bulking up of seeds, that is, seeds that have been grown in the northern hemisphere but are in short supply can be sent to the southern hemisphere and, as our growing seasons are opposite, we can produce that additional seed, which can then be exported back to the northern hemisphere. I guess the process could happen vice-versa, subject of course to our quarantine laws.

I would like to make some other points about the critics of plant variety rights. As I have already mentioned, the fears are really rather unfounded because farmers are a group more than blessed with common sense. People who are critical of the system do not understand the farmers. If farmers have learned one thing, it is that one does not put all one's eggs in one basket. I received a letter from someone very concerned about plant variety rights who referred to the problem of a virus that wiped out most of Ireland's potato crop last century. Farmers have certainly learned from experiences like that and I do not think we will have a problem of farmers sticking to one particular variety for that reason and also, as I have already mentioned, because we have a wide variety of climates, a type of plant suited to one area will not be suited to another area.

I also noted that the Minister, in his second reading speech, talked about the improvement of plant genetic resource centres. Of course, these resource centres would be there to preserve existing varieties and to ensure that we do not lose them. I certainly agree with the comments of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) earlier when he said that we should encourage the setting up of privately owned plant genetic reserves. It is interesting to note that in the Press a couple of days ago Australia's two largest consumer groups attacked the idea of PVR. If one looks at some of their arguments, one finds that they are really very hollow and that they demonstrate a complete lack of understanding of what plant variety rights is all about and what the likely impact will be. The point that they seem to miss all along is that, because PVR is introduced and new varieties are brought in, it does not automatically follow that the existing varieties in use in Australia will suddenly disappear. They will not; they will continue to be used and will be available for anyone who wants them. In many cases, those varieties have been around for decades, and they will still be available. Any fear about the foreign multinationals or whoever getting hold of new varieties is really rather unfounded and it is a very hollow argument.

Another comment was that Australian farmers could lose money planting varieties suitable for European and North American soils but not for Australia's diverse climatic conditions. That was from a spokesman for the Australian Consumers Association. Frankly, that is a load of rubbish. It is insulting and patronising. The Australian Consumers Association should do its homework before it comes out with stupid statements like that.

We could also look at what effect PVR will have on public plant breeding. As Professor Lazenby said, there is every reason why public plant breeding should continue. He made some points about the current arrangements. He said, in part that present arrangements do not sufficiently recognise the high cost and long term nature of plant breeding programs. The Victorian Government would be the worst offender in this regard. It has cut back senior staff in the Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs by something like 100 in each of the last two years. This is a rather serious matter. Professor Lazenby goes on to talk about funding for and the use of public breeding. He says, in part:

. . . these activities in no way justify the fragmented and dispersed nature of plant breeding programs existing in Australia. There is no doubt that this fragmentation prevents the most effective utilisation of breeding resources in this country.

He calls for better integration, I sincerely hope that the Minister will take up and consider this point because obviously there is quite a deficiency. As he has been bold enough to take the step of bringing in plant variety rights, he should go one step further and work on public plant breeding programs. The other bonus that will result from the introduction of the plant variety rights legislation is that the opportunity will be there for private plant breeders to take advantage of the Government's 150 per cent tax write off for research and development. I believe that the introduction of plant variety rights will be a great step forward for agriculture. It will be a great step forward for this nation and of great advantage to the farmers. It will be of benefit to consumers. It will help our export earnings. The delay in introducing plant variety rights is quite disgraceful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in the comments of the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). I did not disagree so much with some of his last comments, but I profoundly disagreed with some of the earlier comments he made in his speech, as I disagreed with some of your comments, Mr Deputy Speaker, when you spoke on the Plant Variety Rights Bill. In a speech in the House on 21 April 1982 when the previous Liberal-National Party coalition Government introduced a plant variety rights Bill I spoke against it. The case I made against the Bill at that time applies in general measure to the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1986 which is presently before the House. In essence, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has claimed that the legislation will not have a detrimental effect on public plant breeding producers and consumers. I find it difficult to accept that view.
—Why?

—If the honourable member will listen, he will hear why. As I said, I find it difficult to accept that view. I have mounted my argument against such claims, together with other honourable members and senators, including the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) and the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) who preceded me in this debate, through all the forums of the Australian Labor Party with the final defeat at the hands of the Federal Caucus primary industry policy committee. Nevertheless, I believe that I would be evading my responsibilities if I did not express my concerns during the debate on this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In joining the debate tonight, I have mixed feelings, as I am aware that the Federal Labor Party policy platform states that the Australian Labor Party will not introduce plant variety rights where this would have a detrimental impact on the public breeding program, producers or consumers. I am also aware, as the Minister for Primary Industry claimed in his second reading speech, that the Government's objectives in introducing legislation for a plant variety rights scheme are to stimulate plant breeding effort in Australia and to encourage the development of new varieties of plants for our domestic industries and for export. He also claims that the legislation incorporates particular provisions for the protection of the food supply to consumers and that proprietary rights will provide plant breeders, both public and private, with the means to recover some of the high research and development costs involved in breeding new varieties.

In other words, the Minister has assured the House that there will be no detrimental impact as a result of the legislation. Labor Party policy has always recognised that a comprehensive inquiry into plant variety rights schemes would be undertaken before a Labor government introduced such legislation. I am aware that two inquiries have taken place into plant variety rights schemes. The inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources was completed in May 1984. In February 1986 Professor Alec Lazenby, who has been commissioned by the Minister for Primary Industry, presented his report. Both reports recommended the introduction of a plant variety rights scheme in Australia, although the Senate Committee recommendation was not accepted by two Committee members, Senator Zakharov and Senator Georges. The problem with both inquiries was that they were not sufficiently wide ranging or comprehensive and did not cover all the aspects of public and private plant breeding. In the case of the Senate Committee report, although my name was not mentioned in appendix 1 as a result of a printing oversight, submission No. 80 was jointly made by Mark Cole, of the Free Access to Seeds Committee, and me. The bulk of the work was undertaken by Mark Cole while working temporarily on my staff, but I had some input into paragraph (b) of the submission which proposed an alternative means of satisfying the requirements of plant improvement work in Australia without the need for a plant variety rights scheme.

In an individual submission to Professor Lazenby's inquiry I elaborated on the proposed establishment of an Australian plant improvement organisation which would report to the Parliament and perform four main functions: First, to collect and maintain germ plasm for all plants of significance to Australian consumers; secondly, to control the importation of improved plant varieties from overseas through a consultative process involving existing State and Federal bodies and secure the imported varieties with a lump payment covered by a levy on the purchase price of the reproductive material; thirdly, to ensure that the level of the levy encompasses the need for funding support to maintain and if necessary expand the quantity and quality of plant improvement schemes, in both the public and private sectors; and, fourthly, to oversee, if the Government deemed appropriate, a royalty reward incentive scheme for private breeders based on across-counter sales of varieties registered under the existing registration system.

The Australian plant improvement organisation should be a statutory body with a managing board representing industry, State and Territory departments of agriculture, the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the tertiary education institutions. It should be given sufficient financial support by the Commonwealth Government, and it would be expected to be able to undertake the presently neglected functions of co-operation and co-ordination in relation to the plant improvement work of the various public bodies throughout Australia. Regrettably, Professor Lazenby rejected my proposal and, as I indicated in a letter to the Minister on 19 May, I was basically disappointed with the report because Professor Lazenby made it clear that he has a profound faith in the market-place as the medium by which any adverse effects of plant variety rights can be remedied. Whilst I concede that a free market-place could give the consumer the opportunity to reject undesirable varieties of food or plants, I do not concede that a free market-place exists in the real world.

In the context of my above comment it is important to note that Professor Lazenby has dismissed the evidence of monopolisation by agro-chemical companies contained in the submissions by myself and others to the Senate Standing Commitee and to the Lazenby inquiry with little investigation as to the merits of our arguments. His report indicates an ideological faith in free market forces which is not supported by the facts. In this respect it is also regrettable that the Lazenby report has not made mention of a most important recent critical report of the operation of plant variety rights in Europe contained in working documents of the European Parliament, and mentioned by the honourable member for Cowan. I submit that it is vital that the findings of the European report be studied before any move is made to introduce plant variety rights legislation in Australia. The Minister, in his reply of 8 August to my letter, pointed out that Professor Lazenby was not asked to inquire into plant variety rights, which was the subject of an earlier inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee, but to report on the expected impact on plant breeding with the possible introduction of plant variety rights or its alternatives. In view of the Minister's reference to the Senate Standing Committee report, it is important to look at that report and to note the critical comments contained in the minority report submitted by Senator Zakharov and Senator Georges, with which I concur. Whilst I do not have time to quote all their remarks, I will quote three major criticisms. First, in paragraph 9 of the minority report, it is stated:

In the Committee's report, the claim that PVR will stimulate plant breeding is backed up by reference to European and UK experience, where there is some evidence that private corporations noticeably increase their plant breeding activities after the passing of Acts granting PVR (e.g. Plant Varieties and Seeds Act 1964 in UK).

The assumption of PVR proponents is that this increase in private breeding activity has had universal benefits. I ask: Benefits for whom? It is clear that the United Kingdom and the United States Acts have allowed large agricultural chemical corporations to make considerable profits out of plant breeding. The evidence offered does not establish that there have been proven benefits to the consuming public or the growers. Some evidence suggests that there has actually been a deterioration in the flavour and nutritional properties of food which has been improved by breeding under plant variety rights legislation. In paragraph 12, it is stated:
Even if it were shown conclusively that PVR has increased private breeding overseas, Australia's situation is not parallel.

There has been a long history of strong direct government intervention in the economy, which is exemplified by the existence of large numbers of government-financed plant breeding research agencies. Unless the activities of these agencies are severely restricted subsequent to the introduction of PVR, the small size of the Australian market will certainly restrict opportunities for profit-making from private plant breeding which is aimed at this market. Given the long successful history of government plant breeding and improvement in Australia, and the unconvincing nature of the evidence tendered concerning the likelihood of benefits of increased private plant breeding in Australia, it would be an act of the most wilful vandalism to diminish the plant breeding activities of such agencies as the CSIRO or State departments of agriculture. Finally, one of the most telling criticisms was contained in paragraphs 15 to 17. They state:

The second supposed benefit advanced by the supporters of PVR legislation is also not supported by convincing evidence, that is, the claim that with PVR the Australian seed and nursery industries will have vastly increased access to overseas varieties. The DPI document `Restriction of Access to Overseas Varieties' . . . lists instances where Australia has been refused access to plant varieties (on the basis of our lack of PVR) which, according to the Department, are held under patents in overseas countries.

In all of the instances listed there is a lack of documentation . . . to support the Department's contention that these varieties have been refused to the Australian industry because of the absence of PVR here.

Coming back to my criticisms of the Lazenby report, it also does not deal with the lack of specific documentation relating to the claim that Australia has been denied access to overseas varieties. If there is overwhelming evidence, as stated in section 4.6, paragraph 3 of the inquiry's report, why is it not listed? While the evidence may exist, neither report publishes it and, as this argument is central to the PVR question, specific documentation must be made public for the argument to be substantiated.

I would now like to deal with the Minister's claim to me that the European parliamentary report, which, incidentally, covered 20 years of the practical effects of PVR legislation, was not a criticism of the operation of plant variety rights in Europe. I find the Minister's comments surprising as the report identified a number of major areas of concern, all of which have been voiced by PVR critics from all over the world for the past decade and which have been detailed by the honourable member for Cowan. In my view, and I think in the view of unbiased observers, it is clear that the report referred to the effects of plant variety rights. I am sure that that was the majority view of the European Parliament, where 205 members out of a total of 211 voted in favour of the motion. The report specifically refers `to the seed trade being increasingly concentrated in a few hands thereby eliminating the small-scale producers from the market'. All the evidence shows that plant variety rights legislation supports and encourages the control of seed production in the hands of a few powerful multinational companies. The monopoly control of food resources is particularly dangerous for the consumer and should not be dismissed as just being a universal problem, as the Minister has indicated in his letter to me. He wrote:

Multinational companies have developed in many industries, not just the seed industry over the past 20 years. While some of their practices are of concern, the benefits in terms of technology transfer and communication must also be recognised.

In all fairness to the Minister, his criticism of the European report extended to two pages of detail which I do not have time to cover at length in this debate. Suffice to say that the Minister said that he was disappointed to find the argument of the European report unsubstantiated, superficial and very one-sided. He also made a number of technical points which, of themselves, do not, in my view, detract from the conclusions of the report. With regard to the claim of unsubstantiality and superficiality I can provide the Minister with a bibliography of articles and other documents which would support the conclusions contained in the report. If the Minister perceives the report as being one-sided, it is only because he has been convinced that plant variety rights can be beneficial when the conclusions of the European report indicate a contrary result.

Since my time to speak in this debate has been limited, I will not say very much more. I would like to bring to the attention of the Minister a number of amendments to the Bill but, as I have run out of time, I might be given the opportunity to deal with some of these matters in Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would rather hear you speak.
—The honourable member would like me to carry on, but I had better keep to my agreement with the Whip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) for limiting his speech to the minimum time suggested. I would dearly love to speak in counter to some of the comments made by the honourable member for La Trobe and the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) and suggest that some of their comments are purely mumbo-jumbo. However, due to the limited time that I have available tonight I will resist the temptation to engage in that, and I will speak more to the Plant Variety Rights Bill. This Bill has been quite hotly debated in the electorate of Gilmore. On balance, I am quite sure now that the feeling in the electorate is that it is, indeed, a most beneficial one and something that will give a great impetus to a number of the industries in the electorate. Many agricultural industries will benefit as a result of plant variety rights legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate of Gilmore has a very large cherry industry. In fact, my home town of Young is considered to be the cherry capital of Australia. I think it is a very accurate description. The cherry industry will benefit substantially from this piece of legislation. For some time now a strong lobbying exercise has been undertaken by the cherry growers of Young to encourage people such as me and other honourable members on both sides of this House to agree to this legislation. I congratulate those people because, as a result of their diligence and their intelligent use of their democratic right, they have been successful in reaching their goal, and that is to get this Bill through the House.

If the Plant Variety Rights Bill goes through all stages in both Houses, the cherry industry will benefit because it will enable the industry to be much more competitive and a more viable option on the export markets. At present the cherry growers of Young export to South East Asia, Germany, parts of Europe-France and the United Kingdom-and even to Israel. There is hope that eventually they will be able to export to Japan when the various quarantine restrictions that currently apply are lifted. Hopefully, with the co-operation of the New South Wales Government and the Federal Government, that will be within about four years.

Plant variety rights legislation will ensure that we have better varieties of cherries grown in Young so that we will be able to market better our cherries overseas. Presently only a very small number of cherry varieties can be brought into Australia to try to improve the existing varieties. Because of the very small numbers, the industry really cannot get any clear example of what different varieties of cherries will be like in different circumstances in Australia. Plant variety rights legislation will enable us to bring in large quantities of different varieties of cherries, and this will speed up the improvement of the gen- etics of the cherries in Australia.

One of the great advantages will be the fact that we will be able to reduce the incidence of cherry splitting. When the cheeries are ripe for harvest and it rains the cherries split. That is taking place at present. Sadly, in the last three or four days the cherry growers of Young have experienced serious bouts of hail. There have been substantial falls of rain and a large quantity of the cherries have been ruined as a result of the recent late seasonal rain and, unfortunately, hail. This is a big impost on the cherry growers of Young because, even though the cherries have no commercial value, they still have to be picked. They cannot be left on the tree; they have to be disposed of. Plant variety rights will enable the Australian cherry growers to develop cherry varieties which will not have the high incidence of splitting when there is late seasonal rain. That will be a substantial benefit to the cherry growers of Young and indeed to the economy of Young, which depends so much upon the cherry industry for its survival.

Some other things would greatly help the cherry industry at the moment. My friends in the cherry industry in Young tell me that such things as high interest rates and spiralling wage costs have also added to the difficulties of trying to survive in very difficult economic circumstances. I hope the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) will take that into consideration and see whether he can work towards reducing interest rates and keeping spiralling wage costs down because they leave very little margin for people in the cherry industry to survive in the long term.

Plant variety rights will give the people in the cherry industry just that little edge to enable them to survive in the long term. It is not only the cherry growers in the electorate of Gilmore who will benefit from this legislation. Quite a substantial wine industry exists in the electorate. The Hilltops wineries near Young, the Barwang wineries, the Cartobe wineries and Cowra wines are quite well known now. The wine industry will benefit from plant variety rights, as will a whole range of agricultural pursuits. I congratulate the House on having this Bill put before it because I think it will be of great benefit to all people, not only those in agricultural industries but people throughout the country.

It has taken an extraordinarily long time for plant variety rights to get into this House. I think it was 15 years ago, in 1971, when the debate started. It is extraordinary that in those 15 years 22 countries have adopted plant variety rights but Australia has not. New Zealand, one of our closest neighbours, in 1977 introduced plant variety rights. The performance of New Zealand's stone fruit industries has given testament to the great financial benefits which can accrue from plant variety rights. There has been a dramatic increase in stone fruit exports from New Zealand because New Zealand producers now have access to high quality varieties through plant variety rights. According to the third report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade, Australia is now New Zealand's largest market for stone fruits. Stone fruit imports from New Zealand by Australia have risen from 215.9 tonnes in 1980-81, valued at $298,000, to 1,549.9 tonnes in 1984-85, valued at $3.568m. There is a clear example that the New Zealanders have shown us here in Australia what can accrue as a result of plant variety rights. I find it extraordinary that it has taken this Parliament so long to introduce this Bill into the House.

There are many obvious examples of why we ought to have plant variety rights. I shall take just a few moments to outline those. They will protect the rights of breeders of new varieties and so will provide a boost to private plant breeding. They will provide a stimulus to develop varieties of Australian native plants for domestic consumption and export. They will provide benefits to the consumer in the form of a wider range of better quality products, and they will stimulate plant breeding and lead to the development of plants with greater genetic resistance to pests and diseases, and therefore reduce dependence on agricultural chemicals. They will enable Australian breeders to enter into reciprocal schemes giving protection for seeds in overseas countries and will allow Australians to multiply seed for export. All reasonable people in the electorate of Gilmore consider that this Bill is of great benefit to agricultural industries and, indeed, to Australia.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Wages Policy-HMVS Cerberus-Northern Districts Education Centre-Reconditioned Automotive Engines-Government Policies-Europe: Nuclear Free Zone-Hume Weir-Warilla High School-Australian Citrus Industry

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do how adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this point in Australia's history many people throughout the country are asking the very serious question: What is likely to happen to wage fixation mechanisms in Australia? I think that is a very serious question that needs to be posed to the Government, and the Government is obliged to provide meaningful answers not only to business people but also to the rest of the working community throughout Australia. We are aware that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is presently conducting its inquiry into the wage fixing system and its national wage hearing, and we understand that there has been an agreement between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government that a joint policy or proposal should be put by those two bodies suggesting that Australia should in fact move to a two-tier wage fixing mechanism. Many of us, particularly on this side of the House and throughout the business community, are uncertain as to what a two-tier wage fixing system or mechanism will be and what precisely is being proposed by the Government and the ACTU. We have yet to know the details of that proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: It concerns me and many people throughout this country that that wage-fixing mechanism may do nothing more than give malcontent unions unrestrained opportunity to demand wage increases far beyond the capacity of the economy and the country to pay. I believe that if unions-either with the blessing of the ACTU or otherwise-pursue unrestrained wage increases it will be extremely detrimental to this country. It has been pointed out by the Business Council of Australia that Australia is not in a position to afford wage increases at the moment. I believe that it is unrealistic to expect that the Arbitration Commission will not grant any wage increase as a result of its present hearing. But I believe that there is every need to restrain wages to the maximum extent possible. That is not to say that people on this side of the House are trying to deny workers their genuine right to have meaningful wage increases; but it is a realistic reflection of the serious economic problems that this country faces. We are all too well aware of Australia's massive overseas debt and the massive problems that we face with servicing that debt. We are also very conscious of the fact that our balance of trade and our balance of payments are very precarious. In those circumstances, when Australia is desperately trying to improve its position in world trade and in the world economy, it is most unrealistic to expect that unrestrained wage increases be granted or demanded on behalf of workers throughout the country. If that were to happen it would no doubt set the economic recovery of this country back many years. No doubt it would bring about a lowering of the standard of living for all workers and their families throughout the country.

I urge the Government not only to advocate the loose two-tiered system that it seems to be advocating at the moment but also to tell the country and the business community what mechanisms will be put in place to ensure that unions do not go beyond the decisions granted by the Arbitration Commission and go into the market-place demanding wage increases that industry is simply unable to pay. What mechanisms can the Government establish? What guarantee can the Government give us that that procedure will not be pursued by individual trade unions? I agree with the arguments that the Government is presently putting before the Arbitration Commission hearing that increases should be limited to the capacity of the economy to pay. But if the Government is to propose this mechanism and pursue that argument it must also have procedures in mind to ensure that unions do not go beyond that system and demand further increases in the market-place. Unless it has that mechanism and unless it can enforce it, I do not believe that the policy of the Government has any credibility whatever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity this evening to inform the House of the efforts of some of my constituents towards the rescue of a unique and endangered piece of Australia's maritime history. HMVS Cerberus, the former flagship of the Victorian Navy-I repeat, it is the HMVS Cerberus of the Victorian Navy-holds an unrivalled place in maritime architecture and in the formation of the Royal Australian Navy. It is a vessel of world significance. Its colourful past continues an important chapter in the history of what was then known as the Port Phillip district. The Cerberus today represents a singular opportunity for us to reclaim and restore an irreplaceable part of our heritage for succeeding generations.

SPEECH.PARA: The City of Sandringham has joined with local residents, community groups and the National Trust in a campaign to restore the Cerberus, and to have the vessel displayed alongside the famous Polly Woodside as a permanent feature of a maritime museum. There is a degree of urgency involved, however, in the battle to save the Cerberus. After more than 50 years of service in and around Port Philip Bay, the Cerberus was sold for scrap in 1926. Fortunately, rather than being dismantled, it was purchased by the Sandringham Council and scuttled-although largely intact-off Half Moon Bay, where it continues to serve as a breakwater no more than a straight hit for four from where the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) used to live in Sandringham.

A detailed submission for the restoration of the ship prepared by the City of Sandringham contains a report by an independent firm of naval architects, confirming that the Cerberus can be salvaged. However, the cumulative effects of time, tide and neglect are catching up with this remarkable vessel. Another extended period of inaction could see the hull deteriorate to the point where salvage is rendered impossible. Time is running out for local citizens and groups and municipal, State and Federal governments to find the funds needed for restoration, which is estimated at about $3.5m.

Age alone makes the Cerberus important. Over 115 years have passed since it was completed in September 1870. The Cerberus, a steam-powered iron-clad warship, is 17 years older than the sailing ship Polly Woodside. Perhaps of more significance is her unique design. The first naval vessel built specifically for a colony, it was ordered by the Victorian Government in 1866. This was an experimental era in naval architecture, a time when wood, sail and cannon were gradually being replaced with iron, steam and turrets. Designed by E. J. Reed, chief constructor for the Admiralty, the Cerberus was a prototype of a new type of warship, referred to as a turret ship or breastwork monitor. It was the first armoured ship and the first designed without sails or masts to serve in Australian waters.

The arrival of Federation saw the transfer of HMVS Cerberus, the flagship of the Victorian Navy, to the fledgling Royal Australian Navy, of which it become a major element. Decommissioned in 1911, it was used as a floating explosives store during World War I. It was renamed HMAS Platypus II and used as a submarine depot ship until being sold in 1926. The RAN naval base at Flinders was named after the Cerberus in recognition of the importance of the ship to the formation and development of the Navy and the Port Phillip area. Of course, the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), who raised this matter last night, is a keen follower of this project. In the 60 years that the Cerberus has languished off Black Rock, in the northern part of my electorate of Isaacs, numerous attempts have been made to raise public awareness of the value of and urgent need for restoration. Regrettably, these previous attempts have been fragmented and poorly funded and promoted. Previous State and Federal governments remained totally oblivious to appeals for salvage and renovation.

We now have, at long last, a detailed submission on the cost and method of restoration. We have an active and co-ordinated campaign to make the public aware of this long neglected and little publicised relic, so unique by world standards. Most importantly, we have a government which is actively working towards the realisation of an Australian maritime museum. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) visited the area earlier this year and made a personal inspection of the Cerberus. It is my hope that, as a result of the wider campaign being created by my constituents, members of this House and the Australian people will have a greater appreciation of the urgent need for action in this matter. It is not, however, a matter solely for the Federal Government. Citizens, community groups and bodies such as the National Trust need to work with local, State and Federal governments if the Cerberus is to be saved from destruction by the elements. Its unique historical significance will ensure that it becomes a tourist attraction of world proportions. It is Australia's-and the world's-first iron clad war ship. Aside from its value as a tourist attraction, the restoration of the Cerberus would be a worthwhile endeavour--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have wanted to speak for some time about the funding cuts for the Northern Districts Education Centre which is the centre of education in my electorate of Dundas. It serves the northern districts of Sydney and probably half of Sydney's population. Honourable members may not be fully aware of the nature of education centres. The Northern Districts Education Centre was a co-operative of a semi-autonomous nature in the suburb of Cheltenham. The centre was founded in 1974 after a public meeting attended by educators, teachers and a large number of community people. It is involved in the professional development of teachers and the provision of services to the education community of Sydney, particularly the northern suburbs and nearby areas and, in fact, it contributes significantly throughout New South Wales. It has a small staff including three full time people-a director, a librarian and an administration officer-and eight part-time teachers and clerical staff. Amongst those are four consultant project officers and four clerical staff.

SPEECH.PARA: It was announced in the recent Budget that the Northern Districts Education Centre will receive no further recurrent grants from the Commonwealth Schools Commission from the beginning of 1987. The centre was not alone in this, but it has relied on this grant as its major source of income. In 1986 the grant represented 62 per cent of the centre's annual turnover of $230,000. The announcement was totally unexpected. In fact there had been discussions previously with representatives of the Schools Commission which indicated that if there were to be any reductions in grants to education centres, these would occur in centres with fewer than two full time professional staff. Larger organisations would not be affected. The Northern Districts Education Centre has always employed two professional full time staff and was not considered to be under threat.

There are 32 Commonwealth-funded education centres around Australia-six in New South Wales, seven in Victoria, 11 in Queensland, three in South Australia, two in Western Australia, two in the Northern Territory and two in Tasmania. From January 1987 the Commission's grants to education centres will be reduced from $2.5m to $1.7m, a reduction of 33 per cent. Nine centres, including the Northern Districts Education Centre and the Inner City Education Centre at Stanmore in Sydney, will no longer receive a Commonwealth Schools Commission recurrent grant. Of these nine, two are in New South Wales, one in Victoria, four in Queensland, one in Tasmania and one in South Australia. The 24 remaining centres will receive on average 10 per cent less next year. New South Wales has 35 per cent of the students and 32 per cent of the schools and teachers in Australia, yet it has received through education centres less than 28 per cent of the total funds for that program. The decision to cut nine centres nationally, including two in New South Wales, means that in future less than 23 per cent of the available funds will be spent in New South Wales. One of my concerns is that in the aftermath of the Budget, decisions appear to have been taken to restore funding to some centres and it seems that the funding was held out first as a carrot to try to get organisations to stop protesting about the extent of the cutbacks in the grants they received. In fact, I would like to been assured that the amounts that have been made available have not been distributed on a political basis. It has been suggested that one of the centres that is being retained after an amount of lobbying, is in a marginal Labor seat in Queensland. If that were the case and if that were the criterion on which funding decisions were reviewed I would be appalled.

During 1986 the Northern Districts Education Centre published new indexes to the collection of programs and developed an information network for community members. It has marketed four new computer programs, run in-service activities in a number of curriculum and skilled areas and managed a major evaluation project for the regional participation and equity program. Undoubtedly it has fulfilled a first class role. I am aghast at the decision that was taken and I would like answers to the large number of outstanding questions as to the way in which decisions were made in this instance. The answers I have received from the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) have been quite unsatisfactory. This centre will not close. The community is determined to see that it continues to operate. It has rationalised its activities to this point but, if it is to fulfil a useful role in the community, ongoing support will be required.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight about the dumping of used secondhand Japanese reconditioned automotive engines in Australia. I do this for two reasons: Firstly, because the Government has just received the Industries Assistance Commission report on reconditioned automotive engines and, secondly, because it has been brought to my attention by four prominent local small business constituents in my electorate that the Australian market is being undermined by the dumping of cheap Japanese engines. The Australian reconditioned engine industry has declined over the last five years from a vibrant, efficient industry to an industry facing real problems. The cause of the decline, in very large measure, has been the massive and accelerated dumping of secondhand engines from overseas and especially from Japan.

SPEECH.PARA: My constituents have pointed out a number of disturbing matters that arise from the dumping of Japanese engines. There is no quality control of these engines which results in an inefficient use of Australia's natural resources such as petrol and oil. The engines do not meet State pollution control laws. On this point, the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment made a submission to the IAC that there be no reduction in import duties for used engines relative to other engines so as not to encourage their use. Tests undertaken by the Victorian Government's Environment Protection Authority reveal that emissions from secondhand engines are also considerably greater than those from reconditioned engines.

There is no protection for Australian consumers, for example, when purchasing these secondhand imported engines, as consumers have no guarantee as to how many miles these engines may have done. Also, it is often difficult for consumers to get spare parts for these dumped Japanese engines. Further, it must be said, they take work out of the hands of Australians, which concerns me very much in regard to the local small businesses in this industry in my electorate. For example, the constituents who have approached me have been established for 30 years or more in their respective workshops and currently employ some 60 people. This is all now under threat from the dumping of Japanese engines.

The impact on domestic industry investment by the influx of overseas secondhand engines has been dramatic. Estimates suggest that retrenchments as a result of imported engines are occurring at the rate of 1,000 per annum. The deskilling of the industry is becoming critical, especially in the area of apprenticeships. My constituents have expressed concern that some importers of engines are engaged in arrangements which reduce their sales tax obligations, although I stress that this requires much further investigation. My constituents tell me that these Japanese engines are being dumped in Australia at as little as $A70, and retail at anywhere between $350 and $795. Evidence provided by my constituents shows that used Japanese engines are selling at up to $200 below the Australian market equivalent. At present a general rate of 25 per cent applies to imports of engines irrespective of whether the engine is new, used or reconditioned. The IAC has now recommended that imports of used and reconditioned engines be dutiable at a general rate of 15 per cent.

Figures in the IAC report show that imports of used spark ignition automotive engines from the United States of America and elsewhere have tapered off since 1982-83, while imports from Japan have risen from 767 in 1979-80 to 33,574 in 1985-86-a massive 43-fold increase in just five years. The consequences are reflected in national statistics which show that the total reconditioned engine market in Australia fell by 6.27 per cent between 1980 and 1982, while over the same period the level of imported engines increased by a massive 300 per cent, with their share of the domestic market tripling.

The flood, and it is a flood, of used Japanese automotive engines into Australia is the result of the introduction in Japan of stringent vehicle regulations. The result is that many automotive engines, having failed to satisfy Japanese legal requirements, are discarded and therefore end up being dumped in Australia where the regulations are less demanding. In conclusion, let me say that there is a clear distinction between fair competition and unfair competition. At present the Australian engine reconditioning industry is experiencing what I believe amounts to unfair competition. These imported Japanese engines are not being landed in Australia because of a desire to compete in or supplement the Australian market. They are simply being dumped here because their usefulness has been exhausted elsewhere. They are being dumped here with no consideration for our environment, our economy, our consumers or our industries, and all in the name of making a financial killing at the expense of the Australian industry. These imported engines are not competing freely. Their disregard for environmental consideration--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I would say a few words tonight for the people who vote in the Australian electorate, in the hope that whoever listens to me might get a better deal in getting some information from the government of the day. In the last fortnight we have had substantial evidence of the Government demonstrating its great political skills but denying any opportunity for anyone to discover whether it has any economic or practical skills at all. I have said frequently in recent times that if this Government could match its political skills with an upgrading of its economic skills the country would probably be run quite well.

SPEECH.PARA: I am talking about Question Time. Some very serious issues are before the Parliament at the moment. The identity card would present great problems for certain people in the community. Many of the people who would be affected by the requirements of the card are people who vote for the Australian Labor Party. They could be confronted with a $100,000 fine just because they happen to be the secretary of a club. They could be responsible for their club, an incorporated body, being fined $100,000 because they mistakenly employed someone without sighting his identity card. I think that is an issue worth debating in this place. A householder may find himself in a similar position.

We certainly have not had any explanation from the Government on what would happen to a real estate agent, an employer, a produce merchant or a stockbroker who got a piece of paper in the mail purporting to be from a `community leader'. How would that person know whether that piece of paper was genuine? How would he explain at a later date to the Commissioner of Taxation or one of his officers, or some new policeman whose job it is to police the identity card, that he accepted that certificate on face value? Would he be fined $20,000, or as a corporation $100,000, for failing to get proper evidence and record it before transacting business with someone?

Those are reasonable questions but we have not had answers to them. Is it all because the Government thinks that this request for information is some Opposition plot? The Government does not think it is obliged to give this information to the Opposition. I am drawing to the Government's attention that the Opposition, for better or worse, also represents the community and, in seeking and obtaining that information, for whatever reasons, it is supplying information to the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have to be for the worse.

—The Minister should not be smart about it, because I am not being smart. If he would listen for once he might learn something to his political advantage. People in the community are being hurt, as the Government learned with its fringe benefits tax. The stupidity of it was that, when all the dust settled over the fringe benefits tax, we discovered that the wealthy people are advantaged under the Government's law but the poor people have lost the use of the company utility.
—That is not right.

—It is no good the honourable member arguing with me. I can give him the figures. After I have finished speaking I will give them to him in black and white. The Government, through its fringe benefits tax, has created a regime that now requires those on high incomes to take the benefit instead of the money-it makes it advantageous to them to do so.
—Get back to the Australia Card.

—The honourable member will not listen, will he? We have seen the honourable member for La Trobe show his courage tonight. He has criticised the Government on a Bill. Why? It is because he knows that the Opposition will support it. That is the first time he has come out of his burrow since his Party has been in government. The reality is that these circumstances are bad. Ministers are procrastinating. As I have said, if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) could only match his economic skills with his political skills he might be able to run Australia. We know a little about that. In the last couple of days he has called for price watches on small business people. He wants them persecuted. It is just too bad when the price watchers do their surveys because they do not price everything in a shop. They take a selected group of articles; they have a checklist. If a person happens to be in the know and reduces the price of the goods that are on the check list, he gets his name in the paper with the words: `A good retailer'. If he happens to be running a special on a product that is not on the check list that day, he is a bad retailer. But who knows better how difficult it is to make a profit in retailing than the Prime Minister? He went broke in one of those stores, didn't he? He failed with Bourke's store.
—I take a point of order.
—Don't give me that, you silly little man.
—Order!
—He went broke, didn't he?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following upon the most commendable action of the Australian Labor Government in initiating a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific, an equally commendable joint initiative is taking place in Europe between the Social Democratic Party of West Germany and the Socialist Unity Party of East Germany. A joint communique draws attention to the Palme Commission's warnings of the danger which the large number of North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and the Warsaw Treaty Organisation deployed nuclear weapons close to the dividing line posed for the peoples of central Europe. In order to raise the nuclear threshold and to reduce the temptation to make early use of nuclear weapons, the Palme Commission recommended the creation of an area free of nuclear weapons initially extending 150 kilometres on each side of the border.

SPEECH.PARA: As a consequence, the Chairman of the SDP, Willy Brandt, and the Chairman of the State Council of the German Democratic Republic, Erich Honecker, agreed to set up a joint working group to discuss the setting up of a nuclear weapon free corridor in Europe in accordance with the Palme Commission's recommendations. During a number of sessions, the joint working group explored the possibilities of implementing the proposal. The discussions resulted in a set of principles for a nuclear free corridor in central Europe which was accepted by the Social Democratic Party and the Socialist Unity Party.

Whilst I do not have time in this debate to deal with all of the details contained in the set of principles, I would like to give an outline of this most historic agreement. Part I is a preamble which makes it clear that this new initiative has a place in the process in global and European endeavours for arms limitation and disarmament. It is intended to create greater trust and greater security in central Europe without calling into question the alliance membership of the sides involved.

Part II defines the objective of the principles: A nuclear weapon free corridor is to be established along the dividing line between the two alliances in central Europe. It is to encompass parts of the territories of the German Democratic Republic, the Federal Republic of Germany and Czechoslovakia and to extend initially to 150 kilometres on each side-that is to say 300 kilometres in total. On the territory of the GDR, it would run approximately along a line connecting Stralsund, Berlin, Wittenberg and Dresden; on the territory of Czechoslovakia, along a line still to be defined; and, on the territory of the FRG, along a line connecting Cuxhaven, Bremen, Bielefeld, Siegen, Mannheim, Ansbach and Munich. Three years after the corridor is established, the governments are to negotiate about extending the corridor to become a central European nuclear weapon free zone.

Part III defines the weapons which are to be removed from the corridor or zone. This refers to all delivery systems capable of carrying nuclear munitions, as well as the munitions proper, including atomic demolition munitions. Since the development of modern weaponry has made it impossible positively to distinguish nuclear and non-nuclear weapons systems, all dual-capability weapons systems will be classified as nuclear weapons. This applies to artillery, aircraft and missiles. This is also an initial and important step towards conventional disarmament.

Part IV sets out the obligations of the participating states, including those which have deployed nuclear weapons on the territory of the corridor. Part V contains comprehensive stipulations on national and international verification which are entirely suited to guarantee abidance by a future treaty.

The working group also considered the following complementary measures: First, the establishment of an early-warning system concerning nuclear incidents of any kind, taking into consideration the decisions of the International Atomic Energy Agency; secondly, the establishment of data banks in connection with the creation of the nuclear weapon free corridor and with the verification of strict observance of its status; thirdly, annual treaty conferences; and, fourthly, the marking of the localities belonging to the corridor, for example by a place-name sign of a different colour or an extra sign.

The principles refer to weapons systems in central Europe which are currently not the subject of negotiations, either in Geneva or in Vienna. It is precisely these weapons systems which would keep the nuclear threshold very low in case of a military incident. Their inclusion in a treaty and its implementation would harm nobody and benefit everyone.

Coming as it does after the meeting in Reykjavik, the initiative is based on the precept that the Soviet Union and the United States of America must have a shared interest in reducing the extremely high concentration of weapons in central Europe.
I hope the Government and, indeed, the Parliament can endorse the proposed nuclear weapons free corridor in central Europe, coming as it does so close on our own nuclear free zone in the Pacific.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to offer to the House and to the nation a salute to a water storage in my electorate just upstream from Albury, namely, the Hume Weir, on the eve of next week's celebrations to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the construction of the Hume Weir and the creation of Lake Hume. It has conferred a massive economic benefit over so much of south-eastern Australia, including the many towns and cities of southern New South Wales, northern Victoria, and indeed, South Australia, ranging right through to the provision of water in this day and age to the capital city of Adelaide in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is very commendable that the House pause for a moment to recognise the significance of five decades of service rendered by the Hume Weir storage and by Lake Hume. This service has generated economic benefit across the board through massively increased irrigation activity in three States. Economic activity has prevailed as a consequence of hydro-electric power generated through the hydro-electric power station built at much the same time at the foot of the Hume wall. Economic activity has also been generated by the recreational and tourism dimension of the area immediately surrounding Lake Hume-Albury and Wodonga and beyond-and of the enhanced flows of the Murray River, a tourism and recreational dimension which exists right along the Murray Valley.

There will be an appropriate ceremony at the Hume Weir storage wall next week. If Parliament were not sitting, I know the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), myself and others would have been at the Hume storage wall to participate in that ceremony because we rate very importantly indeed the fiftieth anniversary of this great storage.

It is also worth recording that the storage has given its first birthday present by spilling not once but twice during November, its fiftieth anniversary month, since it was originally completed in 1936. This time last year the storage was at only 71 per cent capacity-some 1 million megalitres less. As a consequence, the salinity factor crept up, there were irrigation restrictions downstream, and there were great difficulties for many tourist operators on Lake Hume. I am pleased to say that Hume will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary with 100 per cent capacity, with some water spilling through valves and possibly over the main spillway, over the top gates. There could be no better way to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of this vital storage. Madam Speaker, I know you pass over this weir at least twice a sitting week as you travel to and from Melbourne. There could be no better way to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary than by its being 100 per cent full.

Related to the operation of Hume storage is the complex question of the activity associated with Dartmouth Dam and its operation. It has now reached an all time record of 76 per cent capacity. I am sure the authorities are aware of the need to operate those storages to maximum advantage in accordance with the charter of the River Murray Commission. We do not want to see any irrigation shortfall, but within that constraint we do want to see a maximisation of recreational and tourist pursuits associated not only with the two storages I have named but also with all the other storages right along the Murray Valley within the purview of the River Murray Commission. I salute the Hume storage on the tremendous role it has played in the economy of three States and in the economy of the nation as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sometimes wonder whether there is no end to the benevolence of the Hawke Labor Government. Not only have we filled the Hume Weir for its fiftieth anniversary, but we have even managed to have it overflowing. What a magnificent achievement that has been for the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to speak about tonight is the fact that today many in the community are quick, and in my opinion, too quick to criticise schools and to criticise both teachers and students. I regularly visit the schools in my electorate of Throsby, and I am always impressed with the students and their dedication. Indeed I-and I guess many honourable members-am looking forward over the next three weeks to going to all the speech nights that I can possibly manage in my electorate.

The Warilla High School is in the electorate of Throsby. This school caters for a largely working class area in the Shellharbour municipality. I have in my hand a book produced by the students of that school entitled First Take. This book is part of a set of three books that have been written and illustrated by students from Year 12, Senior A at Warilla High School. The book is designed to provide suitable reading material for intellectually disabled teenagers. It is age specific and involves Australian content. I think this is very important because many of the books that these children, especially the intellectually disabled children, get do not have Australian content; but this book does. The project forms part of a community service course at the school. Since this set of books was launched in October over 300 sets have been distributed to libraries, special schools and activity therapy centres in New South Wales. Next year the students at this school hope to promote further copies to cope with the demand that has already been generated. Since the book was published in October there has been a tremendous response to it.

This group also assists in a voluntary capacity at the Kiama riding school for the disabled. I have a particular interest in this group. It recently obtained some land not far from where I live and it is developing a school there which will cater for riding for the disabled. These students from Warilla High also run an extremely innovative program of computer awareness for developmentally disabled students from the Balgowrie Human Resources Centre at Peterborough Special School. My congratulations go to the students of Warilla High, not only on the publication of this book but also on the voluntary work they do in the community, especially that for the disabled.

While I am speaking about Warilla High, I mention that I have here yet another book published by this school. This is a computer book entitled Apple Bytes for use by students in high schools. The book was written by Mr W. Erven to fill the need in many schools for a student workbook in computer studies and computer awareness. It deals primarily with the use of Apple computers in secondary education. This book will be distributed free of charge to all secondary schools in the South Coast region as well as every regional computer consultant in New South Wales. This will ensure that most secondary schools will come into contact with this book in 1987.

Warilla High is a state high school. These are examples of only two of the activities that this school has engaged in over the last 12 months. I am extremely proud of this school and the work it has done-time and time again we hear teachers and students being criticised-but Warilla High School is not an exception. There are many schools and students doing work such as this and community and other work, not only in the electorate of Throsby but also in the electorate of my friend the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) and other schools throughout New South Wales. I say well done to the students and teachers at Warilla High School.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was prompted to rise tonight following the comments of the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) and the concern he expressed about the dumping of inferior quality Japanese engines on to the Australian market. I felt that his speech gave an appropriate backdrop to the comments I would like to make tonight, which follow the decision of the citrus growers of Australia to hold a mock funeral on the lawns of Parliament House on Monday this week. The citrus growers were protesting at the dumping of Brazilian juice on to the Australian market. They were suggesting that the funeral was marking what might well be the end of the Australian citrus industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware that concern about this matter has already been aired in this House by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) and the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest), but I think the point that the House needs to appreciate is that citrus juice is currently being dumped in Australia and that its source country is Brazil. Too few people realise that the Australian nation as such fails to produce enough citrus of its own and must be an importer of concentrated juice. Too little citrus fruit is grown in Australia to meet the demands of the Australian community. We must be importers. But the current position that growers find themselves in is that the Brazilians have been prepared effectively to dump concentrated juice on to the Australian market.

I want to make the point that the citrus industry is a rather extraordinary one in that, as I understand it, it is not seeking any protection for whole Australian oranges. The citrus industry is prepared to export whole Australian oranges to any destination in the world against any one of its world competitors. Of course, it is important that we encourage the Australian citrus industry to continue to develop its export market. So successful have South Australian exports of citrus fruits been that last year, while horticultural exports from South Australia rose by 63 per cent, a large proportion of that increase was made up of citrus fruit. However, in order to export citrus fruit or put citrus fruit on the local market, in an effort to acquire the best quality fruit one inevitably has a quantity of overrun that results from the export pack or, in some cases, from the local market pack. This overrun finds its way into the juice market. Unless there is a viable Australian juice market there is no outlet for the overrun that results from effectively accumulating fruit for export. Sixty per cent of Australia's citrus fruit finds its way into the juice market while only 40 per cent finds its way into either the export market or the local market.

The protest on the lawns in front of Parliament House on Monday was all about 1c per orange. Growers are quite happy to grow whole oranges for the juice market for 2c each-no more. In recent years, in what have been relatively good times, they have been getting 3c for each orange that finds its way into the juice market, which is effectively $150 a tonne. Growers claim that their cost of production is something like $120 a tonne but I put it, for the convenience of the Parliament, that 2c would be the sort of price that growers would be prepared to accept for what is the base juice market. As a result of dumped Brazilian juice coming into Australia, growers have found themselves receiving only 1c for every orange produced. This has been a totally unacceptable situation in which the growers have found themselves.

During Monday morning's protest the Government announced that the Australian Customs Service, on a quick evaluation of the Australian citrus scene, had found that a case could reasonably be made for the simple truth that Brazilian fruit was being dumped in Australia and announced that some short term protection would be offered to citrus growers. What growers now seek from the Government is an indication of some longer term protection from dumped juice in the Australian market so that they can ensure that, this season, they face realistic prices for their juice fruit.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I assume the honourable member is referring to the Wool Research and Development Council (WRDC). I am aware of the concern of the Wool Council of Australia regarding selection of members to serve on the WRDC and have discussed these with the President of the Wool Council.

(4) The AWC nominees to the WRDC have experience in production, processing, marketing and business management. The Selection Committee nominees complement the AWC nominees with expertise in the areas of science, technology, economics and the administration of research and development. The WRDC members, therefore, possess the skills specified in the legislation.

(5) The selection and appointment procedures for the WRDC have been developed with attention to the desires of the wool industry. The seven man WRDCSC has three members appointed on WCA nomination, one on National Farmers Federation nomination (WCA is a commodity council of NFF) and one scientific appointee whose academic career has primarily been involved with the Australian wool industry.

I have advised the President of the WCA that I am prepared to consider proposals from him on this matter and I will discuss the industry desires with the Chairman of the WRDCSC before it next considers persons for selection to the WRDC.
(6) The estimated woolgrower contribution to the funds which are to be allocated by the WRDC in 1986-87 is $13.5 million.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 17 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his Department provided finance for the Ashley Computer Aviation Maintenance System (ACAMS); if so, (a) what funds were provided, (b) over what period of time and (c) what funding mechanism was used.
(2) Is he aware of any other Department providing finance to ACAMS; if so, is he able to provide details.
(3) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Aircraft magazine of September 1986 associating him and his Department with favourable comments concerning ACAMS.
(4) What non-financial assistance has he or his Department given to the group developing the system.
(5) Has there been any commitment by the government to promote this system.
(6) Are similar systems already operational in Australia; if so, has he considered offering them financial or other assistance.
(7) If he has not considered assisting similar systems, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. However following an inquiry to my Department it was suggested that the company might consider applying for a grant from the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentive Board.

(3) Yes. The article contained a number of factual inaccuracies concerning financial assistance to ACAMS. However my Department does support the use by the Aviation industry of any systems which may improve the efficiency of maintenance operations and thereby enhance the safety of aircraft operations.
(4) My Department has from time to time provided technical advice to Ashley Computers when requested.
(6) Yes. I understand Lloyd Helicopters in Adelaide operate a similar system, using the Daniels Columbia Aviation Management System. No assistance has been sought from my Department.
(7) My Department would provide technical advice to assist any company with a similar system when requested.
